column4: Should You Feel Moved to Wax Rhapsodic at the Mall ... (Published 2017) - The New York Times
column5:
Amtrak has run such a program for the past three years, offering ‚Äúcreative professionals who are passionate about train travel‚Äù round-trip tickets on a long-distance route and the use of a private sleeping roomette, ‚Äúequipped with a desk, a bed and a window to watch the American countryside.‚Äù

Not all the musings of these residents have been as bucolic as one might expect. Rachel Monroe of Marfa, Tex., wrote of her experience on Twitter:

‚ÄúThis Amtrak writing residency thing has been cool, except for when the train I‚Äôm on just killed someone.‚Äù

(A fatal accident involving a train was reported in Fresno, Calif., that day.)

The Mall, for its part, is inviting ‚Äúa special scribe‚Äù to ‚Äúspend five days deeply immersed in the mall atmosphere while writing on-the-fly impressions in their own words.‚Äù

Before midnight Central time on March 10, applicants can submit their pitch in 150 or fewer words, after which 25 semifinalists will be invited to expand on their ideas in a 500- to 800-word essay.

‚ÄúWould it be a personal story? A blow-by-blow account of your experiences? The mall as seen through the eyes of a first-time tourist or a regular guest?‚Äù the contest asks. ‚ÄúHeck, if you can make the assignment work as a musical-comedy screenplay, by all means make it so!‚Äù

The goal of the contest, according to the mall‚Äôs news release cited by The Star Tribune, ‚Äúis to come away from this project with an evocative story about Mall of America that represents the contemporary guest experience after 25 years of evolution as a leading retail and entertainment establishment.‚Äù

column4: Woman killed after driving through lowered crossing arms identified - Fresno Bee
column5:
Woman killed after driving through lowered crossing arms identified
The woman killed by a train after she drove through crossing arms was identified Saturday as a Madera resident.
The CHP said Monica Gil Maciel, 29, drove west through the tracks on Avenue 15 1/2, east of Road 29, and went around after she saw one train pass. Maciel was unaware that a northbound train was coming down the main line behind the initial train. It broadsided her 2006 Chevrolet as it crossed, and although she was wearing a seat belt, Macias sustained fatal injuries, CHP said.
The Burlington Northern Santa Fe freight train had minor damage, and was cleared to continue its trip. Neither of the two crew members on board were injured.

A spectacular crash Tuesday in the North Valley between a speeding freight train and a trailer truck.

ATWATER, Calif. (KFSN) -- A spectacular crash Tuesday in the North Valley between a speeding freight train and a trailer truck.

According to Atwater police, the crash happened at noon at the Applegate Road rail crossing. Somehow the semi's trailer got tangled up on the tracks.

Traffic started backing up and #abc30insider Anthony Zambrano caught video of the train striking the truck.

As the train barreled down the tracks on a collision course an officer quickly tries to get out of the way. You can see him in the video running in reverse.

The train smashed into the trailer but no one at the scene suffered any injuries.

The intersection remained closed for hours as workers tried to clear the wreck from the tracks and the roadway.

column4: Family and friends mourn the loss of local foodie - ABC30 Fresno
column5:
Family and friends mourn the loss of local foodie

Adrian Loza's family says the 29-year-old cook was always there, whether you needed a friend, or a great meal.

Adrian Loza's family says the 29-year-old cook was always there, whether you needed a friend, or a great meal.

Adrian Loza's family says the 29-year-old cook was always there, whether you needed a friend, or a great meal.

Adrian Loza's family says the 29-year-old cook was always there, whether you needed a friend, or a great meal.

FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- Adrian Loza's family says the 29-year-old cook was always there, whether you needed a friend, or a great meal.

On the GoFundMe page they've set up for him, a family member says, "Many knew Adrian for his vibrant personality, his kind heart, and of course, his love of food and cooking."

He died Saturday after being hit by a train in Fresno County. Authorities say he was jogging on the tracks with headphones on. He likely didn't hear or see the train. "Everybody really just loved Adrian," said Fresno Grizzlies General Manager Derek Franks. "He touched a lot of people in what he did, and he'll be missed by many."

He connected to the community through cooking authentic Mexican food at his family's restaurant El Premio Mayor. He also cooked on their taco truck, at events like Gazebo Gardens and the Fresno Grizzlies Taco Truck Throwdown. It was a family affair, but Franks says Adrian was the face of the truck. "He's an easy guy to get behind, an easy guy to vote for based on just his personality and his passion," Franks said.

Franks also said they had tastier tacos than the rest, and that lead Loza and his family to winning the Throwdown twice, in 2012, and 2015. Franks says the Grizzlies have been in touch with Loza's family, who assure them they're keeping their restaurants open. The Grizzlies just hope they can compete again in the sixth Taco Truck Throwdown-- this time, in Loza's honor.

Franks says they are working on ways to team up with other organizations to honor Loza in the near future.

You can find the family's GoFundMe account here.

column4: Winner of Fresno Grizzlies Taco Truck Throwdown fatally struck by train - Fresno Bee
column5:
Local Winner of Fresno Grizzlies Taco Truck Throwdown fatally struck by train

Adrian Loza, right, receives the Taco Truck Throwdown trophies after his family business wins the annual Fresno Grizzlies event last August. Loza died Jan. 23 after he was struck by a train. Special to The Bee

A popular member of Fresno‚Äôs local food truck scene and the winner of last year‚Äôs Fresno Grizzlies Taco Truck Throwdown died on Jan. 23 after he was hit by a train while jogging near his home in Fresno County.

The death of Adrian Loza, 29, shocked his family and friends over the weekend. The Fresno Grizzlies and Gazebo Gardens, where Loza often manned his mother‚Äôs food truck, shared remembrances on social media after learning of the accident.

Loza‚Äôs younger sister, Bianca, said he was training for a marathon. He ran a similar 6-mile route each day.

Loza‚Äôs mother, Bel√©n Ram√≠rez, owns two El Premio Mayor brick-and-mortar restaurants and one food truck. She first started the business nearly 20 years ago.

In August, the mobile El Premio Mayor beat out 22 other taco trucks in both the judges‚Äô and people‚Äôs choice competitions at the annual Grizzlies event, which drew a record-breaking crowd of nearly 17,000 people.

Loza‚Äôs family has set up a Go Fund Me page to help pay for funeral expenses. As of Wednesday night, it had raised nearly $5,000 of its $12,000 goal.

This story was originally published January 27, 2016 at 6:51 PM.

column4: 2 dead after crash involving Amtrak train, van in Fresno County - ABC7 San Francisco
column5:
2 dead after crash involving Amtrak train, van in Fresno County

FRESNO, Calif. -- Authorities are investigating a deadly crash involving an Amtrak train and a van in Fresno County. The crash happened around 9:30 a.m. Wednesday near Conejo and Peach avenues.

The California Highway Patrol has confirmed that two men were killed. Officers say both men were riding in the van, when it attempted to cross the train tracks and was hit by the train.

An Amtrak spokesperson says the train, 702 San Joaquin, left from Sacramento and was headed to Bakersfield with a stop in Hanford scheduled. The train was delayed for a few hours before continuing to the South Valley.



The CHP says none of the 181 passengers on board was hurt in the crash, but investigators were checking the area to make sure no one else was in the van who may have been ejected during the collision.

The cause of the crash is unclear at this point. Some roadways in the area are shut down as the investigation continues.

Stay with Action News and ABC30.com for the latest information on this story.

column95: Victims ID'd in fatal Fresno County crash involving an Amtrak train and a van. The men who died in the crash involving an Amtrak train and a van in Fresno County have been identified by the California Highway Patrol. Nicholas Spurling, 29, and 47-year-old Michael Reyna. FRESNO, Calif. (KFSN) -- A woman clipped by an Amtrak train near Clinton and Maroa has died. It happened at about 12:30 p.m. near Fresno City College.

Witnesses told police the 58-year-old woman was trying to cross the tracks, but she was walking with a cane and not moving fast enough. The train clipped the woman and knocked her to the ground.

Investigators say the woman suffered a fractured forearm, a broken leg and internal injuries. The woman was taken to Community Regional Medical Center where she died from her injuries.

column4: Train crashes into car with woman inside in Selma - ABC30 Fresno
column5:
Train crashes into car with woman inside in Selma

A woman escaped any serious injuries on Sunday after her car was hit by a train while she was still inside.

A woman escaped any serious injuries on Sunday after her car was hit by a train while she was still inside.

A woman escaped any serious injuries on Sunday after her car was hit by a train while she was still inside.

A woman escaped any serious injuries on Sunday after her car was hit by a train while she was still inside.

SELMA, Calif. (KFSN) -- A woman escaped any serious injuries on Sunday after her car was hit by a train while she was still inside.

Selma police say the woman was crossing the railroad tracks at Highland Avenue and Golden State Boulevard around 6 p.m. She had driven past the crossing arms as they started coming down. But instead of backing up, police say she panicked and drove forward, trying to make a U-turn.

The woman couldn't get out of the way in time, and the train collided with her car. Luckily, she didn't suffer any injuries but was taken to a local hospital as a precaution.

column4: NTSB: Truck involved in Metrolink crash not stuck on tracks - ABC30 Fresno
column5:
NTSB: Truck involved in SoCal train crash not stuck on tracks

National Transportation Safety Board investigators have determined that the truck involved in the Metrolink train crash in Oxnard was not stuck on the tracks as initially believed.

National Transportation Safety Board investigators have determined that the truck involved in the Metrolink train crash in Oxnard was not stuck on the tracks as initially believed.

National Transportation Safety Board investigators have determined that the truck involved in the Metrolink train crash in Oxnard was not stuck on the tracks as initially believed.

National Transportation Safety Board investigators have determined that the truck involved in the Metrolink train crash in Oxnard was not stuck on the tracks as initially believed.

OXNARD, Calif. -- National Transportation Safety Board investigators have determined that the truck involved in the Metrolink train crash in Oxnard was not stuck on the tracks as initially believed.

"Our information is the collision occurred about 80 feet down the railroad track toward Oxnard. It had to travel there somehow. It was not stuck, bottomed out on the track or something like that, it had actually traveled down the railroad track itself," said Robert Sumwalt with the National Transportation Safety Board.

About 2,100 crossing accident occur each year, but Tuesday's derailment drew NTSB attention because the truck was found having driven down the tracks. Investigators are expected to remain on scene for five to seven days.

"Our objective is to collect perishable evidence," Sumwalt added. "We are not here to speculate. We never speculate at the NTSB. We're not here on scene to determine the cause of the accident. We're not here on scene to analyze. I know everybody wants to know what happened, and we will determine that, but our goal here is to collect that information that will go away with the passage of time."

As part of the investigation, NTSB plans to do a sight distance test, which means they will set up a mock situation to see how far down the track each person could actually see from both the train and pickup truck.

The NTSB is also looking at video and data equipment on the train that should reveal the moments before the crash.

PHOTOS: Metrolink commuter train derails in Oxnard

Information from the control cab showed the train engineer managed to hit the brakes early, but could not avoid the crash.

Ramirez's lawyer Ron Bamieh called the collision an "accident." Ramirez was driving his company's truck and trailer. He has been employed by the same produce trucking company, The Grower's Company, Inc., for 12 years.

"The arrest of Mr. Ramirez is the unfortunate result of law enforcement attempting to cast blame on a man who was caught in a tragic situation with no way to stop the oncoming tragedy. He does not know how or why the truck he was driving stopped on the tracks, and wishes there was something he could have done to prevent this accident," Bamieh said.

Bamieh added that his office's investigation showed that Ramirez's truck did become "entangled and unable to move off the railroad tracks. The truck and the trailer were somehow stuck."

About 50 people were on board. Twenty-eight people were taken to a hospital, including four in critical condition. No fatalities were reported.

On Wednesday, clean-up efforts continued. All derailed cars had been removed from scene. Track repairs and crossing light and arm function checks were ongoing. Authorities were hoping to get the site cleaned up by the end of the day.

Commuting around the area

Delays were expected for commuters traveling near the crash area.

Metrolink riders for Ventura County Line Trains 102, 104 and 106 will be bused around the crash site between the Camarillo, Oxnard or Ventura-East stations and the Moorpark station. Regularly scheduled service resumes for passengers traveling between Los Angeles Union Station and Moorpark station.

VIDEO: Metrolink commuters to be bused around Oxnard train crash site

Oxnard drivers are urged to avoid the derailment site, located at 5th Street and Rice Avenue, which is expected to stay closed until at least 8 a.m.
column95: National Transportation Safety Board investigators have determined that the truck involved in the Metrolink train crash in Oxnard was not stuck on the tracks as initially believed. About 2,100 crossing accidents occur each year, but Tuesday's derailment drew NTSB attention because the truck was found having driven down the tracks. Investigators are expected to remain on scene for five to seven days. The NTSB is also looking at video and data equipment on the train that should reveal the moments before the crash. Information from the control cab showed the train engineer managed to hit the brakes early, but could not avoid the crash. Ramirez's lawyer Ron Bamieh called the collision an "accident." Ramirez was driving his company's truck and trailer. He has been employed by the same produce trucking company, The Grower's Company, Inc., for 12 years. "The arrest of Mr. Ramirez is the unfortunate result of law enforcement attempting to cast blame on a man who was caught in a tragic situation with no way to stop the oncoming tragedy. He does not know how or why the truck he was driving stopped on the tracks, and wishes there was something he could have done to prevent this accident," Bamieh said. Bamieh added that his office's investigation showed that Ramirez's truck did become "entangled and unable to move off the railroad tracks. The truck and the trailer were somehow stuck." About 50 people were on board. Twenty-eight people were taken to a hospital, including four in critical condition. No fatalities were reported. On Wednesday, clean-up efforts continued. All derailed cars had been removed from scene. Track repairs and crossing light and arm function checks were ongoing. Authorities were hoping to get the site cleaned up by the end of the day.

column4: East Bay Girl May Have Been Retrieving Dropped Phone Before Train Killed Her - NBC Bay Area
column5:
More than 1,000 people gathered Tuesday to pay tribute to a 14-year-old Martinez girl who was struck and killed by a train.

Jenna Betti, an 8th grader at Martinez Junior High School, was remembered at a candlelight vigil as a great soccer player, a great friend and for her contagious smile.

"Heaven gained one of the most beautiful angels and she is now in a better place protected by God," said Julia Betti, Jenna's sister.

A social media post by Jenna's mother said the teen was killed by a train while trying to retrieve her dropped cell phone.

Jenna was hit around 5 p.m. Sunday on the railroad tracks near Old Orchard and Howe roads. The Burlington Northern Santa Fe train that struck her was heading from Richmond to Fresno, and had three crewmembers aboard at the time of the incident, a railway spokeswoman said.

The spokeswoman said Jenna and another person were on the tracks but moved away as the train approached. The girl then returned to the tracks and was hit.

According to a Facebook message from Jenna's mother, Dena Betti, that was reposted on social media sites, Jenna was with her boyfriend on the tracks just before she was hit. The mother wrote that Jenna apparently dropped her phone and was killed when she went back to grab it as the train approached.

Tuesday's vigil was held near the location of where Jenna died.

Grief counselors were at the school Tuesday and will remain there all this week, a campus secretary said.

 

 On social media, messages about Jenna have been pouring in since her death. One poster, who appears to be Jenna's boyfriend, wrote, "She is so important to me and I am just devastated. I love her so much."

 

 Jenna has two younger sisters and played club soccer. Her mother was involved in her daughters' school communities, according to the Martinez Unified School District superintendent.
‚Ä¢ Purported Victim Says Sexual Assault at School Never Happened
column95: Jenna Betti, a 14-year-old girl, was struck and killed by a train while trying to retrieve her dropped cell phone near Old Orchard and Howe roads. The train, heading from Richmond to Fresno, had three crewmembers aboard. Jenna and another person were initially on the tracks but moved away as the train approached. Jenna returned to the tracks and was hit.

column4: Jenna Betti, 14, killed by train while reaching for her phone - upi.com
column5:
MARTINEZ, Calif., March 5 (UPI) --  A Martinez, Calif. middle school held a vigil Tuesday to honor the death of 14-year-old student Jenna Betti.
Betti was hit by a Burlington Northern Santa Fe train at around 5 p.m. on Sunday as she hung out by the railroad tracks near Old Orchard and Howe roads. 

A railway spokeswoman said the girl was on the tracks with another person, but that the two moved when they saw a train approaching. Betti later returned to the track and was hit. 
She added the train was heading from Richmond to Fresno, and had three crewmembers aboard at the time of the incident.
In a message posted to Facebook, Betti's mother Dena Betti explained her daughter had been at the tracks with her boyfriend and that she had returned after realizing she had dropped her phone. 
"She didn't judge the approach, and the train creates a vacuum, we were told, and it sucks you in...," Betti's mother wrote.
Around 1,000 friends, classmates and teachers attended Tuesday's vigil in Betti's name. The school secretary said that grief counselors had been at the school and will remain there throughout this week. 

Betti was a soccer player and had two younger sisters. 


[ABC]
column95: 14-year-old student Jenna Betti was hit by a Burlington Northern Santa Fe train at around 5 p.m. on Sunday as she hung out by the railroad tracks near Old Orchard and Howe roads. Betti was on the tracks with another person, but they moved when they saw a train approaching. Betti later returned to the track and was hit. The train was heading from Richmond to Fresno, and had three crewmembers aboard at the time of the incident. Betti's mother explained her daughter had been at the tracks with her boyfriend and that she had returned after realizing she had dropped her phone. "She didn't judge the approach, and the train creates a vacuum, we were told, and it sucks you in...," Betti's mother wrote.

column5:

Update 1 a.m.
FREMONT ‚Äî At least two people are dead following a train collision in Fremont on Sunday.
At approximately 7 p.m., first responders were called to the area of the Hayes Avenue railroad crossing on the Miles Newton Bridge for the report of a train versus pedestrians crash.
Two women were confirmed dead according to Sandusky County Sheriff Chris Hilton.
Mayor Danny Sanchez said the women were a 58 year old and a 38 year old who were mother and daughter, according to a WTOL story.
The adults appeared to have been fishing, Sanchez said.
Their names have not been released as of early Monday.
A child about one year old was pulled from the Sandusky River by a person who witnessed the collision. CPR was started on scene and the child was transported to St. Vincent Medical Center in Toledo. The child's current condition is unknown.
In addition to the one year old, at least one other person was transported to the hospital.
The Ballville Township Volunteer Fire Department was on scene with a boat to search the river for a missing five year old.
Multiple dive teams were also on scene according to Sanchez.
For about two hours a helicopter aided in the search for the five year old.
The train blocked the crossing for about four hours. It was finally cleared from the crossing just after 11 p.m. It was a northbound Norfolk Southern train.
Update 9:35 p.m.
The two people who died are both adult women, Sandusky County Sheriff Chris Hilton said.
An infant was pulled from the river by a witness and CPR was started, Hilton said. The child was taken to the St. Vincent's hospital in Toledo.
A 5-year-old remains missing and authorities are searching for the child.
It appeared that the train was traveling north.
Update 9:25 p.m.
Two fatalities are confirmed, according to Fremont Mayor Danny Sanchez.
Multiple people have been transported to the hospital.
A search is currently underway for anyone else who might have been struck.
Original post 8:47 p.m.
FREMONT ‚Äî A train struck five pedestrians in Fremont Sunday evening, Sandusky County Sheriff Chris Hilton said.
First responders at the scene of the incident near the Miles Newton Bridge at the Hayes Avenue crossing. The bridge is closed.
"Stay clear," Fremont police posted online. "State Street is open. "
Multiple agencies are on scene and the Ballville Township fire has a boat in the water looking for additional individuals.
**This is a breaking news story, check back for updates.

column4: Shafter residents come together to honor student hit by train, push for change - 23ABC News Bakersfield
column5:
SHAFTER, Calif. (KERO) ‚Äî Members of the Shafter community stood near where a Shafter High School student was hit by a train to honor them as they recover from their injuries, and advocated for change along the railway.
‚Ä¢ Shafter High School Principal Russell Shipley confirmed to 23ABC that it was a student who was hit by a train on Thursday, but said the school would not be releasing the name of the student out of respect for the family. Shipley added that the school was notified that the student made it through surgery and was in critical but stable condition.
‚Ä¢ On Friday, 23ABC met Suzette Gama, a parent of a student in Shafter, who knew the teen who was hit. She said the situation was frustrating because, in her mind, without change, it could happen again.
‚Ä¢ During the demonstration, Jesus Sanchez, a friend of the student, said he was in disbelief when he heard the news and fully expected to see the teen later that afternoon. Now, a day later, Sanchez said he hopes his friend has a speedy recovery and hopes the demonstration they put on starts the conversation surrounding change at the railroad crossing.

BROADCAST TRANSCRIPT:

Members of the Shafter Community and friends of the Shafter High Schooler who was hit by a train came together to not only rally around them, but advocate for change

The teen was hit by an Amtrak train Thursday afternoon at the rail crossing near Central Avenue and Central Valley Highway, also known as Highway 43.

Shafter High School Principal Russell Shipley confirmed a Shafter High School student was hit by a train, but said they do not plan to release the identity of the student out of respect for the family.

Less than 24 hours after the tragic news hit members in the Shafter community, residents were planning ways to honor the teen, while advocating for change along the railway.

Suzette Gama, a parent in shafter, said she knows the student who was hit, tand hat her children are friends with him.

"I feel mad, angry, sad, because I know him personally. My kids know him personally, they're really close to each other, and something needs to be done because it's going to continue happening if nothing is done."

Near the spot where their friend was hit, several shafter high school students and shafter community members took to the street to advocate for their friend, donning signs advocating for a pedestrian bridge, the slowing of trains that run through Shafter and more, all while wearing necklaces and bracelets adorned with photos of their friend who was hit.

Jesus Sanchez, a freshman at Shafter High, says he‚Äôs known the teen since kindergarten, and the two were slated to meet up at the gym that evening. When Sanchez heard the news, he was in disbelief.

‚ÄúThey said someone got hit, but when I found out it was him, I was still in denial because he was supposed to meet me at the gym. So I was thinking, ‚ÄòOh he‚Äôs going to walk through the doors of the gym any second,‚Äù but he just didn‚Äôt,‚Äù said Sanchez.

Sanchez adding he hopes the demonstration pushes change through Shafter.

‚ÄúI hope to slow the train down and bring awareness to this situation that happened, and if possible, make a bridge so people feel safer when crossing.‚Äù

According to Shipley, the high school was told that the Student who was hit is in the intensive care unit, successfully had surgery, and is in critical but stable condition.

column4: Man dead after being struck by a train in Delano - KGET.com
column5:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) ‚Äî A man was killed after a being hit by a train Monday evening, according to the Delano Police Department.

On March 10, Delano police responded to reports of a Union Pacific train hitting a man in the 1100 block of Glenwood Street, at about 6:30 p.m. Officers say they located a man dead when they arrived.

Union Pacific Railroad Police arrived on scene and took over the investigation.

The identity of the man will be released by the Kern County Coroner‚Äôs Office at a later date.

No other details have been released by officials at this time.

column4: Coroner identifies Wasco train collision victim whose leg was taken from the scene - KGET.com
column5:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KGET) ‚Äî The Kern County Coroner‚Äôs Office identified a man who was killed in a train collision in Wasco and whose leg was later taken from the scene.

The coroner identified the victim of March 22 collision as Horacio Ayala-Penaloza, 48, of Wasco. The collision occurred just after 8 a.m. in the 700 block of G Street. Ayala-Penaloza died at the scene.

The incident took an even more grisly turn when Ayala-Penaloza‚Äôs severed leg was taken from the scene after the collision. Video of the incident went viral and was shared and seen thousands of times online.

A man was seen carrying the limb near the scene as he was surrounded by Kern County deputies and taken into custody. The man who took Ayala-Penaloza‚Äôs leg pleaded no contest to charges stemming from the incident and was sentenced to a year in jail.
column95: The incident involved a train collision in Wasco, where Horacio Ayala-Penaloza, 48, was killed. His severed leg was taken from the scene, and a man was arrested for this act. The man pleaded no contest and was sentenced to a year in jail.

column4: GoFundMe identifies two people killed after car crashes into train in Wasco - KBAK
column5:
UPDATED (4/23/2024, 5 P.M.):



The other two people who were killed in Sunday's fatal Wasco train crash have been identified by friends and family in a GoFundMe.



Eric and Sebastian Tellez were killed early Sunday morning on Kimberlina Road, east of Highway 43 when CHP said the driver, Mckinley Jordan Toliver, 19,hit the railroad crossing arm and then hit the train. Their vehicle rolled over.



The GoFundMe for Eric and Sebastian Tellez can be found .

















---------------







UPDATED (12:55 P.M.): Three men died after one of the men, identified as a 19-year-old man, was driving a car when he hit the railroad crossing arm and struck a train passing by early Sunday morning.



The California Highway Patrol said on April 21, 2024, at around 3:03 a.m., officers received a call from the Wasco Police Department and were called to Kimberlina Road, east of Highway 43 for a crash involving a vehicle and train.

CHP said a preliminary investigation found that a 19-year-old man, identified as Mckinley Jordan Toliver, was driving a 2021 Honda, traveling westbound on Kimberlina Road, east of Highway 43 towards the railroad tracks/train, at an undetermined rate of speed.



The train was traveling northbound on the tracks ahead of the Honda.

Powered By 10 Sec High school football faces heat wave safety concerns in Kern County Next Stay

CHP said for reasons still under investigation, the driver hit the railroad crossing arm, and then hit the train. The Honda rolled over and traveled out of control in a northerly direction.

As a result of this crash, the driver and his two passengers, one identified as a 27-year-old man and the other also as a man, died.

An Eyewitness News crew saw a memorial made for the three men involved in the crash.

An Eyewitness News crew saw a memorial made for the three men involved in the crash. PHOTO: KBAK/KBFX

According to a photo frame, a candlelight vigil was held the same day.

An Eyewitness News crew saw a memorial made for the three men involved in the crash. PHOTO: KBAK/KBFX

The use of alcohol and/or drugs as a factor in this crash is under investigation, according to CHP.

CHP said any witnesses with information are asked to call the California Highway Patrol, Bakersfield Area at (661)396-6600.
column95: The California Highway Patrol reported that on April 21, 2024, at around 3:03 a.m., officers were called to Kimberlina Road, east of Highway 43 for a crash involving a vehicle and train. A 19-year-old man, Mckinley Jordan Toliver, was driving a 2021 Honda westbound on Kimberlina Road towards the railroad tracks/train at an undetermined speed. The train was traveling northbound on the tracks ahead of the Honda. For reasons still under investigation, the driver hit the railroad crossing arm and then the train, causing the Honda to roll over and travel out of control in a northerly direction. As a result, the driver and his two passengers, a 27-year-old man and another man, died. The use of alcohol and/or drugs as a factor in this crash is under investigation. An Eyewitness News crew saw a memorial made for the three men involved in the crash, and a candlelight vigil was held the same day.

A man was arrested for allegedly taking a severed body part from the scene of a collision between an Amtrak train and a person on the tracks in Kern County.

The incident happened in Wasco, a city just north of Bakersfield.

A graphic video going viral on social media shows the man who authorities say took the body part from the scene. In the footage, he is seen carrying a severed lower leg and foot down a street in the area.

At one point, the man bent over and appeared to sniff the apparent body part.

Kern County sheriff's deputies quickly swarmed the area and arrested that man. They are now studying that video for what could be numerous criminal charges.

column4: Man arrested for consuming severed leg at fatal train accident scene in US - Times of India
column5:
NEW DELHI: A tragic
train accident in Wasco, California, took a horrifying twist as a man was arrested for consuming the severed leg of a pedestrian who had been fatally struck by the train. The Kern County Sheriff's Office has launched an investigation into the disturbing incident, which has left the community in disbelief.
The incident occurred at the local Amtrak station in Wasco, situated approximately 25 miles northwest of Bakersfield. According to authorities, a pedestrian was struck by a passing train, resulting in their untimely death and the severing of one of their legs.
Eyewitnesses were left stunned as they watched the perpetrator, identified as 27-year-old Resendo Tellez, brazenly approach the scene of the accident. In wild footage captured by onlookers, Tellez can be seen closely inspecting the severed leg, even appearing to sniff it, before callously absconding with the gruesome evidence.
Despite the presence of law enforcement officers and bewildered bystanders, Tellez showed no signs of remorse or concern. He reportedly waved casually at cameras as he made his escape, swinging the severed leg with nonchalance.
Tellez was swiftly apprehended by authorities and now faces multiple charges, including the theft of evidence from the accident scene, in addition to outstanding warrants. Meanwhile, the identity of the victim remains undisclosed, pending notification of their next of kin.
The Kern County Sheriff's Office is continuing its investigation into the tragic incident, grappling with the disturbing circumstances surrounding the fatal train accident and the bizarre actions of the perpetrator. The community of Wasco is left reeling from the shock of such a gruesome and unsettling event, as they grapple with the aftermath of the tragedy.

column4: US: Man Arrested In California For 'Eating Amputated Leg' From Victim of Fatal Train Accident - News18
column5:
US: Man Arrested In California For 'Eating Amputated Leg' From Victim of Fatal Train Accident

Curated By :

News18.com

Last Updated: March 24, 2024, 10:57 IST

Video circulated on social media showing the incident

A US man takes a human leg from a fatal train accident scene and starts eating it. (Screengrab)

A US man was arrested on Friday after appearing to carry and eat a body part from someone who was killed by a train in the state of California.

This incident happened in Kern County‚Äôs Wasco area in the San Joaquin Valley. In an unsettling video circulated on social media, a man, later identified as 27-year-old man Resendo Tellez, appears to be taking a human leg from a fatal train accident scene and starts eating it.

Recommended Stories

In Wasco, CA the Kern County Sheriff‚Äôs Office is investigating a fatal incident in the Wasco area where a pedestrian was struck by a train, resulting in their death and the severing of their leg and this person stealing it and eating it‚Ä¶.. pic.twitter.com/QsyzF7rYUc‚Äî Reese (@peanut7724) March 22, 2024

Wasco Amtrak station

The Kern County Sheriff‚Äôs Office is investigating a fatal incident where a pedestrian was struck by a train at Wasco Amtrak station on Friday morning. US media reports said one unidentified individual lost his life in a tragic incident, sustaining severe injuries, including limb amputations.

top videos View all Swipe Left For Next Video View all

Reports said that a witness recounted seeing someone pick up a detached leg at the scene. Shockingly, a video captured the suspect carrying the limb on the roadside, even sniffing it before proceeding down the street. Eventually, surrounded by police cars, Tellez was apprehended near the Amtrak station for allegedly tampering with crime scene evidence.

US Authorities noted the pedestrian was struck near the train platform. Tellez faces charges for unlawfully removing human remains. His initial court appearance is scheduled for Tuesday. Details about the victim and Tellez‚Äôs motives remain undisclosed. This marks the second instance this year of someone absconding with body parts from a train accident site in US.

A California man is competing with Florida Man for weirdest headline of the week -- 'cause he got arrested for walking around and apparently chomping on a human severed leg.

The dude's name is Rosendo Tellez. and he got busted Friday out near Bakersfield -- in a small town called Wasco -- after eyewitnesses saw him strolling through town with what looked to be an entire limb that was attached to a person just earlier in the day.

Kern County officials say the leg was illegally taken from the scene of a train accident that morning -- when Tellez is alleged to have swooped it up after a man was hit and killed at the Amtrak station in town. Not too long after that ... citizens say they spotted Tellez holding it.

Some even claimed to FOX26 News that Tellez was taking bites out of the leg ... which seemed to be the case based on this video of the guy that's circulating on the internet.

It's a gruesome sight ... as you can see the flesh dangling from the chopped-off leg, and sure enough -- you can also see this man, identified as Tellez, seemingly going in for a nibble.

Tellez was eventually intercepted by Sheriff's deputies ... and he was reportedly arrested without incident. He was booked on several charges -- including outstanding warrants, possession of drug paraphernalia and for removal of human remains from a location other than a cemetery. If you're curious ... that's considered a misdemeanor in California.
column95: A California man named Rosendo Tellez was arrested for walking around and biting a severed human leg. The leg was taken from the scene of a train accident in Wasco, where a man was killed at the Amtrak station. Tellez was seen holding the leg and allegedly taking bites out of it. He was arrested by Sheriff's deputies and booked on several charges.

column4: Deadly train crash kills one person near Shafter - 23ABC News Bakersfield
column5:
BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KERO) ‚Äî A deadly train crash claimed one person's life near Shafter.

Earlier Friday night just after 2 p.m. the Kern County Fire Department responded to a call for a vehicle accident on Santa Fe way between Orange and Burbank Street.

When firefighters arrived on scene, they found a vehicle on fire wedged underneath an Amtrack train.

137 people total, including all passengers and Amtrack employees, were safely evacuated.

The driver of the vehicle involved was pronounced dead at the scene, and three train passengers were treated for minor injuries.

column4: 1 dead, 3 injured after vehicle hit by Amtrak train in Shafter - kmph.com
column5:
UPDATE (8:30 p.m.)



Three passengers were minorly injured in the Amtrak crash with a vehicle at Sante Fe Way between Orange and Burbank streets, according to the Kern County Fire Department.



Just after 2 p.m. firefighters responded to the Shafter cross streets regarding a report of a passenger vehicle and a passenger train collision.



Upon arrival, firefighters saw a vehicle wedged under the train, fully engulfed in flames. The fire was heading toward the passenger areas of the train, said the department.



A total of 137 passengers were evacuated safely and firefighters began searching extensively throughout the train for anyone left on the train. Everyone was confirmed to be out of the train.



Twelve people required some medical assessment but only three were confirmed for minor injuries. No passengers were sent to the hospital.



Fire officials said the person that died inside the vehicle was a solo occupant.



The Kern County Sheriff's Office, Shafter PD, CHP andBNSF (Bakersfield Terminal) police assisted.





---



A vehicle struck by an Amtrak train in Shafter Friday afternoon killed a person, according to the Kern County Fire Department.



At approximately 2:08 p.m. a rescue incident was reported at Sante Fe Way and Orange Street on Pulse Point.



Emergency personnel and Shafter police arrived and found a vehicle on the tracks, engulfed after it was struck by the Amtrak train.

Over 100 passengers were on the train during the crash but no other injuries were reported. The passengers were taken off the train after the crash.



The identity of the person killed is pending.



Traffic closed in both directions on Sante Fe Way, between Orange and Burbank streets.Avoid the area if possible.



This story is developing and will be updated once more information is provided.

column95: An Amtrak train struck a truck in Richmond Tuesday morning, according to police. Train No. 711, which runs from Bakersfield to Oakland, struck the vehicle around 10:30 a.m. in the vicinity of Cutting and Carlson boulevards, according to Amtrak spokeswoman Vernae Graham. No injuries were reported by anyone on the train or in the truck, Graham said. "At this point we're trying to do a bus bridge, trying to secure alternate transportation," Graham said. "We do have mutual aid from BART at Richmond." Cutting Boulevard has been closed because of the crash, police said around 11 a.m. They expect the roadway to remain closed into the early afternoon hours. Carlson Boulevard is unaffected, according to police.

column4: Car struck by train, one person injured - Hanford Sentinel
column5:
CORCORAN ‚Äî One person was injured Monday after a car was struck by a train, Corcoran Police Department officials said.

Just before 7:30 a.m., Corcoran police officers were dispatched to the railroad crossing intersection of Orange and Otis avenues regarding a train colliding with a vehicle.

Officers arrived on scene and made contact with the driver of the vehicle, a 41-year-old man from Exeter, officials said.

The man was the sole occupant of the vehicle and officers said he complained of pain to his abdomen due to the impact from the collision. They said he was later transported to a local hospital for medical treatment. His condition was unavailable.

Based on the investigation, officers said they determined the man was traveling eastbound in his vehicle when it was struck in the rear passenger side by a Burlington Northern Santa Fe train traveling northbound at the intersection.

Police said the man‚Äôs vehicle, a 2005 Chevrolet Malibu, sustained major damage to the rear end and a railroad crossing arm was also damaged due to the collision.

Officials said the conductor of the train told officers that the man‚Äôs vehicle was seen entering the crossing while the railroad arms were down as the train was approaching. The conductor also said they sounded the train‚Äôs horn several times before it struck the vehicle, police said.

Authorities said no one on the train was injured and there was no damage to the train.

The Corcoran Police Department reminds motorists and pedestrians to follow these railroad crossing safety tips:
‚Ä¢ Slow down when approaching a railroad crossing and look both ways twice.
‚Ä¢ Never race a train to cross the tracks.
‚Ä¢ Never pass another vehicle within 100 feet of a railroad crossing.
‚Ä¢ Watch out for vehicles that must stop at railroad crossings, such as school buses or trucks carrying hazardous materials.
‚Ä¢ When approaching a crossing, roll down your windows, turn off the radio or air conditioner and listen for whistles or bells.
‚Ä¢ Always yield to flashing lights, whistles, closing gates or stop signs.
‚Ä¢ If you must stop, keep a distance of at least 15 feet from the tracks.
‚Ä¢ Teach children that the railroad is never a place to play, walk, run, bike ride or use as a short cut.
‚Ä¢ Always cross the tracks at the designated railroad crossing or pedestrian crossing.
‚Ä¢ Only use the crossing if you can be sure your vehicle is high enough to completely clear the railroad crossing without stopping.
‚Ä¢ Don‚Äôt be fooled, a train is always moving faster and is much closer than you think.

column4: Teacher Killed After LIRR Train Strikes Car | Northport - Patch
column5:
Crime & Safety
Teacher Killed After LIRR Train Strikes Car
A fundraiser is collecting donations for the Long Island woman's funeral service. About $12,000 has been raised in one day.
A teacher has been identified as the person who was killed after her car veered onto train tracks and was struck by a Long Island Rail Road train early Saturday in East Northport. Elizabeth Gallagher, 29, of Centereach, struck a guardrail, which caused her vehicle to go down an embankment and get struck by an eastbound train at about 2:10 a.m., the New York Post reported.
Gallagher, who was discovered dead outside of her vehicle, would have turned 30 March 6.
A former middle school teacher in the Roosevelt School District, according to the Post, Gallagher was on her way home from her second job at a restaurant when the high winds caused her car to veer off the road, the New York Daily News reported.
Find out what's happening in Northportfor free with the latest updates from Patch.
Watch NY Jets Fumble Pronunciation Of NJ Town‚Äôs Name
A fundraiser collecting donations for Gallagher's funeral service raised about $12,000 in one day.
On the donation page, one person commented, "This is truly crushing. My thoughts and prayers go out to you all. She was a beautiful soul. Going to miss all her upbeat facebook posts!"
Find out what's happening in Northportfor free with the latest updates from Patch.
Another wrote, "You were a true ray of sunshine in my life. I'm forever grateful to have the memories I have growing up with you. Still can't believe it. My deepest condolences to your family."
Image via GoFundMe

column4: 'Train vandal' hit and killed near Kingsgrove Railway Station - The Sydney Morning Herald
column5:
By Megan Levy
A man who was struck by a train and killed in Sydney's south overnight was believed to have been running across the railway tracks after vandalising another stationary train, police say.
The 25-year-old man was hit by the passenger train near Kingsgrove Railway Station just after midnight.
Police and paramedics arrived at the station a short time later but could not revive the man, who died at the scene.
A NSW Police spokesman said an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the man's death was ongoing.
Initial inquiries, however, suggested the man may have just vandalised another stationary train before he ran across the train tracks and was struck.
It is believed he did not see the south-bound passenger train that hit him. That train was carrying scores of passengers from the city towards Macarthur at the time.
All south-bound trains between Turrella and Macarthur on the T2 Airport Line were suspended while officers from the St George Local Area Command established a crime scene, which was examined by forensic officers overnight.
Passengers had to remain on the train for more than an hour after the collision, before they climbed from their carriages onto the tracks and were put on to buses to continue their journeys.
Police said the man who died had not been formally identified on Monday morning.
The T2 line reopened about 3.30am on Monday, and Sydney Trains said services had since returned to normal.
Police will prepare a report for the coroner.

column4: Amtrak train crashes into forklift in Kings County - ABC30 Fresno
column5: Amtrak train crashes into forklift in Kings CountyAn Amtrak train crashed into a forklift in Kings County on Tuesday morning.KINGS COUNTY, Calif. (KFSN) -- An Amtrak train crashed into a forklift in Kings County on Tuesday morning.The Hanford area Highway Patrol says the forklift was crossing the train tracks on Lansing Avenue near 10th Avenue when it stalled. The driver tried to restart it, but was unable to. He then jumped off of it, and the train hit it.The train was coming from Bakersfield when the crash happened. Nobody on the train was hurt, and the driver of the tractor wasn't either. The passenger train has since continued to Sacramento.Copyright ¬© 2025 KFSN-TV. All Rights Reserved.
column95: An Amtrak train crashed into a forklift in Kings County on Tuesday morning. The Hanford area Highway Patrol says the forklift was crossing the train tracks on Lansing Avenue near 10th Avenue when it stalled. The driver tried to restart it, but was unable to. He then jumped off of it, and the train hit it. The train was coming from Bakersfield when the crash happened. Nobody on the train was hurt, and the driver of the tractor wasn't either. The passenger train has since continued to Sacramento.

column4: Big rig hits, derails Calif. Amtrak; 42 minor injuries - USA Today
column5:
Big rig hits, derails Calif. Amtrak; 42 minor injuries
An Amtrak train derailed this afternoon after a tractor-trailer truck drove into it at a crossing in California's San Joaquin Valley. Authorities said up to 50 people suffered mostly minor to moderate injuries.
Hours later, a truck drove into a freight train on tracks several miles from the Amtrak derailment.
Update at 8:31 p.m. ET: About four hours after the Amtrak derailment, a truck drove into a freight train, Kings County authorities say.
The silage truck hit the train around 4 p.m. PT (7 p.m. ET) about 18 miles from the Amtrak derailment, near Hanford, KMPH-TV says. The driver suffered unspecified injuries. The freight train did not derail.
Update at 7:11 p.m. ET: Officials say 42 people were taken to six area hospitals, mostly for minor injuries or complaints of pain, the Fresno paper reports.
Update at 6:40 p.m. ET: Witnesses said the crossing arms were lowered at the guarded crossing, the Fresno Bee says. The truck was carrying cotton trash.
As configured, the engine was the last car, and the truck hit between it and the last passenger car, said Amtrak spokeswoman Vernae Graham.
She said that 169 passengers were aboard and that all injuries were not life-threatening. The train crew was not hurt. The truck driver's condition was not reported.
Update at 6:07 p.m. ET: KMPH reports that a baby was thrown from the train but not seriously injured.
Update at 5:30 p.m. ET: Kings County authorities now say between 40 and 50 passengers suffered minor to moderate injuries, mostly bumps, bruises and possible fractures, KTVU-TV reports.
The sheriff's department also says the southbound train hit the big rig at a crossing. Three of the five cars derailed.
The train left Oakland at 10:05 a.m. (1:05 p.m. ET) with between 120 and 150 passengers.
Original post: An Amtrak train derailed this afternoon in California's southern San Joaquin Valley after an accident involving a big rig, injuring 22 passengers and the truck driver, according to the highway patrol.
The Fresno Bee reports that the tractor-trailer hit the train, while KMJ radio writes that the truck "plowed into" the train. KMPH-TV shows the train's locomotive and several cars tilted at 45 degrees.
The accident happened about 12:20 p.m. PT (3:20 p.m. ET) south of Hanford, in Kings County.
The truck driver was pinned, the director of Kings County Emergency Medical Services told the Bee.
The Sacramento-to-Bakersfield San Joaquin was carrying 120 passengers.
column95: An Amtrak train derailed this afternoon after a tractor-trailer truck drove into it at a crossing in California's San Joaquin Valley. Authorities said up to 50 people suffered mostly minor to moderate injuries. Hours later, a truck drove into a freight train on tracks several miles from the Amtrak derailment. About four hours after the Amtrak derailment, a truck drove into a freight train, Kings County authorities say. The silage truck hit the train around 4 p.m. PT (7 p.m. ET) about 18 miles from the Amtrak derailment, near Hanford, KMPH-TV says. The driver suffered unspecified injuries. The freight train did not derail. Officials say 42 people were taken to six area hospitals, mostly for minor injuries or complaints of pain, the Fresno paper reports. Witnesses said the crossing arms were lowered at the guarded crossing, the Fresno Bee says. The truck was carrying cotton trash. As configured, the engine was the last car, and the truck hit between it and the last passenger car, said Amtrak spokeswoman Vernae Graham. She said that 169 passengers were aboard and that all injuries were not life-threatening. The train crew was not hurt. The truck driver's condition was not reported. KMPH reports that a baby was thrown from the train but not seriously injured. Kings County authorities now say between 40 and 50 passengers suffered minor to moderate injuries, mostly bumps, bruises and possible fractures, KTVU-TV reports. The sheriff's department also says the southbound train hit the big rig at a crossing. Three of the five cars derailed. The train left Oakland at 10:05 a.m. (1:05 p.m. ET) with between 120 and 150 passengers.

column4: Amtrak train derails in Hanford - Porterville Recorder
column5:
HANFORD ‚Äî Three friends driving four-wheel quads experienced an adventure of a lifetime when they witnessed the derailment of an Amtrak train following a collision with a semi truck Monday afternoon near here.

They were the first on the scene when they rushed to help rescue passengers.

Raymie Howard, 23, Andy Saiz, 31, and Leslie Saiz, 39, were in the back yard area of their home ‚Äî empty fields bordering Kansas Avenue and 10th Avenue, just south of Hanford ‚Äî when a semi truck with two trailers hauling cotton trash hit the last car of an Amtrak train heading to Bakersfield.

‚ÄúI was just standing in the back yard while one of the other guys was on the quad when BOOM,‚Äù Howard said. ‚ÄúIt looked like the whole back train was on fire.‚Äù

But what looked like smoke turned out to be black, thick dust.

The crash injured about 40 of the train‚Äôs 170 passengers, but none seriously. Even the driver of the truck suffered only minor injuries.

‚ÄúI ran over there. It was incredible,‚Äù Howard said. ‚ÄúThat truck was going west but after hitting the back end of the train, it flipped 180 degrees and ended up facing the opposite way.‚Äù

Howard and the Saiz brothers were the first on the scene at the railroad crossing on Kansas Avenue. The glanced at the train, they said, and saw it ‚Äúwobbling‚Äù down the tracks.

‚ÄúEverything was gone. His engine was gone. The cab of the truck was gone. All that was left was one small bubble where the driver sat,‚Äù Howard said. ‚ÄúThe dude was just sitting there, not making any noise. He wasn‚Äôt responding ‚Äî he was unconscious.‚Äù

A few seconds later, the man began to moan.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt want to touch him. Just then a probation officer pulled up and said the train had just derailed,‚Äù Howard said. ‚ÄúHe was checking the truck driver and hehad merun up thetracks looking to see if any passengers had been thrown out of the train. We nev¬≠er saw anyone along the way.‚Äù

But as they approached thederailed train,thesight was frightening.

‚ÄúPeople were coming out with broken arms and broken legs ‚Äî you could tell just by looking at them andthewaytheyheldtheir [limbs.] There was a lot of crying. Even people who were not hurt were all crying,‚Äù Howardsaid.‚ÄúEveryone was freaking out.‚Äù

Howard said he saw a lady with a crying month-old baby covered in what appeared to be black soot and dirt.

‚ÄúIt scared me. I took off my shirt and gave it to the lady to clean the baby‚Äôs face up,‚Äù Howard said. ‚ÄúThe baby was not even hers. She had picked it up and was looking for the mother.‚Äù

Andy Saiz said he was on the quad, heard the hit, andlookeduptoseeahuge cloud of dust.

‚ÄúIt was so thick, I could not see in front of me. It was bad,‚Äù Andy Saiz said. ‚ÄúI was shocked. There was no motor left to the truck. It was gone. The drivers‚Äô feet were hanging off the bottom of the cab that was now gone. I kept shouting ‚ÄòCan you hear me?‚Äô but got no response.‚Äù

Saiz rushed to the train and saw a lady with a broken arm, he said.

‚ÄúThe [passengers] were coming out of the doors and getting pulled out of windows,‚Äù Andy Saiz said. ‚ÄúThere were a lot of old ladies and old men covered in black dirt.‚Äù

LeslieSaiz said hetalked to one of the men.

‚ÄúHis face was all bloody and he had dirt and glass all over his face so I ran to help him,‚Äù Leslie Saiz said. ‚ÄúHe said he was sitting looking out the window as thetrain was crossing [Kansas Avenue.] He saw the truck and the way he told it, the truck only slowed. It did not stop completely.‚Äù

Leslie Saiz said the passenger told him hethought the driver miscalculated the train‚Äôs passing.

‚ÄúIt seemed like he slowed to let the train pass but then either he sped up or the train slowed, and the truck hit the last train car,‚Äù Leslie Saiz said. ‚ÄúAt least that‚Äôs what it sounded like.‚Äù

The collision occurred a few minutes after noon on Monday ‚Äî with the first 9-1-1 call received at 12:22 p.m., said Jerry Pierce, California Highway Patrol Public Affairs Officer, Hanford office.

‚ÄúTwo minutes later we got an updatethat thetrain wasinfactanAmtraktrain and that some of the cars had partially overturned,‚Äù Pierce said.

Thecollision was reported as occurring on Kansas Avenue at the rail road crossing, between 10th and 10 and a half.

‚ÄúThe train came to rest about two football fields past the point of impact,‚Äù Pierce said.

The driver was pulling two trailers of ‚Äòcotton trash‚Äô and had minor to moderate injuries.

As Pierce checked on the driver, emergency personnel had been on the scene for an approximate 30 minutes.

‚ÄúThe majority of the passengers were checked and treated just outside the train,‚Äù Pierce said.

Brett Blanchard, who was identified as the engineer of the Amtrak passenger train that collided with the semitrailer, did not appear to be injured.

Pierce placed an initial report of an approximate 150 to 200 passengers on the train, which had just leftHanfordandwasheading to Bakersfield.

‚ÄúThe initial report of the injured is between 30 and 50,‚Äù Pierce said. ‚ÄúMost of the injuries are minor. I have not heard of any major or severe injuries. No one was transported by lifeline ‚Äî indicating serious injuries ‚Äî away from the scene.‚Äù

Pierce also praised the prompt help from numerous entities, including Kings County Sheriff, Hanford Police Department,Kings County Probation, Kings County District Attorney‚Äôs Office, Kings County Fire Department and fire volunteers, Hanford Fire Department and volunteers, and other fire personnel.

Numerous ambulances responded to the site and a triage area sorted passengers based on their need for immediate medical treatment.

The injured were transported to hospitals in Hanford, Tulare and Visalia.

TulareRegional Medical Center reported receiving 10 patients for medical evaluation, and Kaweah Delta District Hospital, Visalia, reported having received nine patients with moderate injuries and four more on enroute at 3:39 p.m.

The majority of the passengers were transported by Hanford Joint Union High School District buses to the Hanford Civic Auditorium.

‚ÄúFrom there, those that choose to, will be transported by Amtrak to a connection in Bakersfield,‚Äù Pierce said. ‚ÄúI was told the [rail] line will be down a minimum of four hours, and that was at 2 p.m., so we‚Äôre looking ‚Äòtill 6 p.m. at least.‚Äù

Members of the public who think they may have a family member involved in the incident sould call Amtrak at 1-800-523-9010.

Contact Esther Avila at 784-5000, Ext. 1045. Follow her on Twitter @Avila_recorder.

column4: At least 20 injured in California train crash - KSBW
column5:
Two cars and the locomotive of an Amtrak train carrying about 169 passengers derailed Monday after colliding with a big rig truck in California's Central Valley, authorities said.At least 20 passengers suffered minor to moderate injuries, authorities said.The crash occurred when the driver of the big rig carrying cotton trash failed to yield and hit the train, authorities said. The impact pushed the two passenger cars and the locomotive off the tracks south of Hanford, a farming town.The train traveled about 600 feet after the collision before hitting a switchback and derailing, according to California Patrol Officer Scott Harris.The crash occurred at a crossing that was equipped with control gates, Putnam said.After the crash, metal pieces from the truck could be seen inside the train, which was covered by cotton seeds. Several pieces of luggage were also scattered about.The injuries to passengers were described as bumps, bruises, scrapes and possibly broken bones by Kings County Assistant Sheriff Dave Putnam.Eight of the injured passengers were taken to Adventist Medical Center in Hanford and five more were enroute, said hospital spokeswoman Christine Pickering. She did not provide details on the extent of their injuries."We did call in additional physicians and staff," Pickering said.Four additional injured passengers were taken to nearby Adventist Medical Center in Selma.The train was on its way from Oakland to Bakersfield, according to Amtrak. It had four rail cars and a locomotive.The truck driver suffered minor injuries, according to California Highway Patrol spokesman Jerry Pierce. The CHP will investigate the crash."This is a big, huge chaotic scene with lots of agencies involved," Pierce said.Pierce said the other passengers have been taken to an auditorium in Hanford, where they will board a train and continue to their destinations or family members will pick them up.

The impact pushed the two passenger cars and the locomotive off the tracks south of Hanford, a farming town.The train traveled about 600 feet after the collision before hitting a switchback and derailing, according to California Patrol Officer Scott Harris.The crash occurred at a crossing that was equipped with control gates, Putnam said.After the crash, metal pieces from the truck could be seen inside the train, which was covered by cotton seeds. Several pieces of luggage were also scattered about.The injuries to passengers were described as bumps, bruises, scrapes and possibly broken bones by Kings County Assistant Sheriff Dave Putnam.Eight of the injured passengers were taken to Adventist Medical Center in Hanford and five more were enroute, said hospital spokeswoman Christine Pickering. She did not provide details on the extent of their injuries."We did call in additional physicians and staff," Pickering said.Four additional injured passengers were taken to nearby Adventist Medical Center in Selma.The train was on its way from Oakland to Bakersfield, according to Amtrak. It had four rail cars and a locomotive.The truck driver suffered minor injuries, according to California Highway Patrol spokesman Jerry Pierce. column36: The driver of the big rig carrying cotton trash failed to yield and hit the train.
column95: Two cars and the locomotive of an Amtrak train carrying about 169 passengers derailed Monday after colliding with a big rig truck in California's Central Valley, authorities said. At least 20 passengers suffered minor to moderate injuries, authorities said. The crash occurred when the driver of the big rig carrying cotton trash failed to yield and hit the train, authorities said. The impact pushed the two passenger cars and the locomotive off the tracks south of Hanford, a farming town. The train traveled about 600 feet after the collision before hitting a switchback and derailing, according to California Patrol Officer Scott Harris. The crash occurred at a crossing that was equipped with control gates, Putnam said. After the crash, metal pieces from the truck could be seen inside the train, which was covered by cotton seeds. Several pieces of luggage were also scattered about. The injuries to passengers were described as bumps, bruises, scrapes and possibly broken bones by Kings County Assistant Sheriff Dave Putnam. Eight of the injured passengers were taken to Adventist Medical Center in Hanford and five more were enroute, said hospital spokeswoman Christine Pickering. She did not provide details on the extent of their injuries. "We did call in additional physicians and staff," Pickering said. Four additional injured passengers were taken to nearby Adventist Medical Center in Selma. The train was on its way from Oakland to Bakersfield, according to Amtrak. It had four rail cars and a locomotive. The truck driver suffered minor injuries, according to California Highway Patrol spokesman Jerry Pierce. The CHP will investigate the crash. "This is a big, huge chaotic scene with lots of agencies involved," Pierce said. Pierce said the other passengers have been taken to an auditorium in Hanford, where they will board a train and continue to their destinations or family members will pick them up.

column4: Metro train collides with vehicle in downtown LA - NBC Los Angeles
column5:
A Metro train and a vehicle collided Saturday night, temporarily halting the public transportation service in downtown Los Angeles.

The Los Angeles Fire Department responded to the crash around 8 p.m. in the 1500 block of South Flower Street.

Stream Los Angeles News for free, 24/7, wherever you are. WATCH HERE WATCH HERE

All occupants were out of the car at the time of the crash, according to LAFD.

No medical transportation was required. It's unclear how many occupants, if any, were in the train at the time of the crash.
column95: A Metro train and a vehicle collided Saturday night, temporarily halting the public transportation service in downtown Los Angeles. The Los Angeles Fire Department responded to the crash around 8 p.m. in the 1500 block of South Flower Street. All occupants were out of the car at the time of the crash, according to LAFD. No medical transportation was required. It's unclear how many occupants, if any, were in the train at the time of the crash.

column4: Pedestrian hit, killed by Metrolink train in North Hollywood - KTLA
column5:
A pedestrian was struck and killed by a Metrolink train in North Hollywood on Wednesday.

The collision occurred shortly after 11 a.m. near the 7000 block of North Tujunga Avenue, according to the Los Angeles Fire Department. The pedestrian was pronounced dead at the scene.

The circumstances of the incident were not immediately available, and no information regarding the identity of the deceased person was released.

At the time of the crash, 33 passengers were on board the train. No injuries to the passengers were reported.

column4: Another Pedestrian Killed by Metrolink Train | News - Outlook Newspapers
column5:
A pedestrian was fatally struck by a Metrolink train in North Hollywood on Wednesday, the fifth death in the last year on a segment of tracks between North Hollywood and Glendale.
The train struck the unidentified person around 11:10 a.m. near the 7000 block of North Tujunga Avenue, according to the Los Angeles Fire Department.
There was no immediate description of the pedestrian or what led to the person being struck. Fire officials said 33 passengers were on the train, but no additional injuries were reported.
The Metrolink tracks between Burbank and Van Nuys were shut down while an investigation was conducted, leading to some trip cancellations by the regional rail service.
In 2024, at least four people were killed in accidents involving Metrolink trains along the segment of tracks between Burbank and Glendale. And in February, a man was killed in Boyle Heights after he was struck by a Metrolink train.
Vehicles have also been involved in collisions on Burbank tracks in recent years.
According to data published by the Federal Railroad Administration, California leads the nation in railroad fatalities, with 185 deaths in 2024, though that number fell from 251 in 2023.
‚ÄúMetrolink continually works to communicate to the community, riders and the general public that people need to be aware anytime they‚Äôre around the tracks or at intersections,‚Äù according to Metrolink spokesman Scott Johnson. ‚ÄúObviously, trespassing is a crime, but we are concerned with the bigger picture issues that result in injury and loss of life.‚Äù
Homeless encampments near train tracks are related to increased cases of death or injury, said Johnson. In fact, he noted, in areas where law enforcement has identified higher rates of homelessness, the rates of pedestrian-train injuries and fatalities are higher.
‚ÄúWe recognize that homeless encampments, or people living near or using rights of way as a thoroughfare, or actually as a place to live, can lead to dangerous situations involving trains,‚Äù Johnson said.
Metrolink has invested significant resources into suicide prevention, rail safety education and awareness, and technology, he said. Recently, Metrolink received funding for a track intrusion detection system.
‚ÄúThis is one example of Metrolink trying to proactively use technologies to keep people off of the right of way. And if, for some reason, they still find their way onto the tracks or along the right of way, this system would allow the engineers of the trains advance notice to either slow or stop their trains,‚Äù Johnson said.
The pedestrian fatality on Wednesday is still being investigated, and a cause of death will likely be determined by the L.A. County coroner‚Äôs office in the next 60 days.
City News Service contributed to this report.

column4: Pedestrian Struck by Metrolink Train in North Hollywood, No Passengers Injured - Hoodline
column5:
Source: Google Street View

A pedestrian was fatally struck by a Metrolink train in North Hollywood earlier today, sending emergency crews to the scene just before the midday sun reached its zenith.

According to KTLA, at approximately 11:12 a.m., the collision occurred in the 7000 block of Tujunga Avenue.

The Los Angeles Fire Department's spokesperson, Margaret Stewart, described the situation as dire, stating that the individual was "struck by a Metrolink train is sadly beyond medical help and determined deceased on scene."

The identity of the person who died in the accident has yet to be publicly shared.

On board the train at the time were 33 passengers who, despite having to unexpectedly stop, did not sustain any injuries.

Further information about the collision has been limited as the incident remains under scrutiny. The Los Angeles Police Department's North Hollywood Division has been engaged and is likely to release additional details once their inquiry advances.

column4: Idaho State Police Investigate Vehicle vs Train Collision in Southern Idaho - Big Country News
column5:
DIETRICH ‚Äì Idaho State Police is investigating a serious collision involving a pickup truck and a freight train that occurred at approximately 6:38 p.m. on April 8, 2025, at 189 South 1000 East in Lincoln County.

A 74-year-old-male from Dietrich was traveling northbound on 1000 E in a white 2012 GMC Sierra. The pickup collided with the train and was struck on his rear passenger side, causing the vehicle to roll.

The driver of the GMC was not wearing a seatbelt. He was transported by air ambulance to a local hospital.

Idaho State Police were assisted by Lincoln County Sheriff and Lincoln County EMS.

The crash remains under investigation by the Idaho State Police.

column4: Pedestrian struck by train in Riverside, hospitalized in unknown condition - CBS News
column5:
CBS News Los Angeles
Live




A pedestrian was hospitalized after they were struck by a train in Riverside on Wednesday.¬†It happened at around 11:15 a.m. on the Burlington Northern Santa Fe tracks near E. La Cadena Drive and Kansas Avenue underneath the 60/91/215 Freeway interchange, according to the Riverside Fire Department.¬†They arrived to the scene and found the victim, who has not yet been identified, suffering from injuries.¬†They were treated at the scene before being taken to a nearby hospital for moderate to major injuries, firefighters said.¬†All train traffic was stopped through the area until just before 1 p.m.


It's unclear why the victim was on the tracks when they were hit.¬†No other injuries were reported.

column4: One person injured after Metrolink train crash in Oxnard - NBC Los Angeles
column5:
Metrolink is back on schedule this morning after a train with 13 people on board hit a tractor trailer in Oxnard Tuesday night.

Officers from the Oxnard Police Department responded to the scene at Rice Avenue and Fifth Street at around 7:15 p.m. on Tuesday.

Stream Los Angeles News for free, 24/7, wherever you are. WATCH HERE WATCH HERE

According to Oxnard police, a woman who was standing at a nearby food vendor was hit by debris.

The woman suffered a head injury and had to be hospitalized. She was said to be in critical but stable condition.

Alcohol did not appear to be a factor in the crash, Oxnard police said. The investigation is ongoing.

Anyone who has information regarding this collision is urged to contact Traffic Coordinator Corporal Manuel Perez at 805-385-7750 or via email manuel.perez@oxnardpd.org.

Tuesday night‚Äôs crash happened at the same intersection where a Metrolink train derailed in 2015 after hitting a truck on the tracks. A train engineer died and 28 others were injured in that incident.

column4: 1 dead after train strikes vehicle in Ventura County - KTLA
column5:
A Metrolink train struck a vehicle near Camarillo on Monday, killing the car‚Äôs driver and halting the train‚Äôs journey to Los Angeles.

The Metrolink Ventura County Line took to social media to announce the crash at about 2:15 p.m.

The Ventura County Fire Department later detailed that the southbound Ventura County Line 118 train hit the vehicle at Las Posas Road and Fifth Street between Camarillo and Oxnard.

The train‚Äôs five passengers and three crew members were uninjured, but the driver of the vehicle was declared dead at the scene.

As a result, the tracks were closed and VC Line 118 to Los Angeles was stopped, and riders were offered alternate transportation to complete their trips.

Information about the cause of the crash was not immediately available.
