column4: Train collides with car in San Bernardino - Fontana Herald News
column5:
A train collided with a car in San Bernardino on April 19, according to the San Bernardino Police Department.

Authorities determined that the driver of the vehicle was traveling at an unsafe speed, resulting in him being unable to stop in time, the San Bernardino P.D. said in a Facebook post.

The motorist collided with the crossing arm, and then his Nissan Altima stalled on the tracks. Additionally, he was unable to exit his driver‚Äôs side door.

The engineer from the train observed the vehicle on the tracks and applied the brakes, which slowed the train's momentum, but was unable to avoid colliding with the car.

‚ÄúLuckily, no one was injured,‚Äù the Facebook post said.

Police did not provide any additional details about this incident.

column4: 11-year-old girl killed, mother hospitalized after Metrolink train hits car in Redlands - ABC7 Los Angeles
column5:
11-year-old girl killed, mother hospitalized after Metrolink train hits car in Redlands

An 11-year-old girl was killed and her mother was injured when they were hit by a Metrolink train in Redlands.

An 11-year-old girl was killed and her mother was injured when they were hit by a Metrolink train in Redlands.

An 11-year-old girl was killed and her mother was injured when they were hit by a Metrolink train in Redlands.

An 11-year-old girl was killed and her mother was injured when they were hit by a Metrolink train in Redlands.

REDLANDS, Calif. (KABC) -- An 11-year-old girl was killed and her mother was injured when they were hit by a Metrolink train in Redlands.

According to the city officials, the car they were in was struck by the train at Alabama Street near Redlands Boulevard shortly before 8:30 p.m. on Tuesday.

It's unclear how the car ended up on the tracks. The train was traveling about 50 mph when the engineer saw the car and applied the brakes. The train was unable to stop and struck the vehicle in its path.

The passenger was ejected from the car and pronounced dead at the scene. The girl's mother was taken to the hospital in critical condition.

According to the initial reports, all safety gates and signals were working and there were no signs of drugs or alcohol in the driver's system.

Anyone who may have witnessed the collision or the moments leading up to it are asked to call police at (909) 798-7681, ext. 1.

column4: 11-year-old girl killed, mother hospitalized in Redlands train crash - KTLA
column5:
This is an archived article and the information in the article may be outdated. Please look at the time stamp on the story to see when it was last updated.

An 11-year-old girl was killed and her mother was left critically injured after being struck by a train in Redlands on Tuesday night.

The fatal collision happened on the railroad tracks at Alabama Street, just north of Redlands Boulevard shortly before 8:30 p.m., according to the Redlands Police Department.

The Metrolink train was traveling at about 50 mph when the engineer spotted the victims‚Äô vehicle on the train tracks, police said. The engineer applied the brakes but was unable to stop in time before crashing head-on into the victims‚Äô car.

The child was ejected from the vehicle and pronounced dead at the scene, authorities said. The mother, who was sitting in the driver‚Äôs seat, was taken to the hospital with critical injuries.

Images from the scene show the victims‚Äô car completely mangled and destroyed at the busy intersection. Debris from the crash was strewn across the tracks and nearby roadway.

The victims were headed northbound when they ended up on the tracks for some unknown reason, police said. Moments later, a Metrolink train traveling westbound struck the vehicle.

There were four people aboard the train at the time ‚Äî two passengers, an engineer and the conductor, said Metrolink. One passenger was taken to the hospital with a ‚Äúcomplaint of pain,‚Äù officials said.

Locals say the intersection where the crash took place is a dangerous one.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very busy and there are often people who don‚Äôt stop when they‚Äôre supposed to at the intersection,‚Äù said Nicolas, who commutes to Redlands for work. ‚ÄúThey stop in the middle of the intersection because there‚Äôs just so many cars lined up, so I can see an accident happening pretty easily.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe just heard a loud bang,‚Äù said Saalim Scott, a man who worked nearby and heard the crash. ‚ÄúI thought it was something falling off the truck. We all came out and we saw the car and somebody off to the side. It‚Äôs just pretty sad, honestly, because life is short. You want to hold your family a little closer.‚Äù

‚ÄúI got in my car and I came right here and that‚Äôs when I realized the car was hit by the train,‚Äù said resident Victor Medford. ‚ÄúIt hurts. It hurts bad. Last night when I saw it, I cried.‚Äù

Police are still investigating how the vehicle ended up on the tracks in the first place.

‚ÄúThe initial investigation indicated that all safety gates and signals were working properly and there were no signs of drugs or alcohol in the driver‚Äôs system,‚Äù police said.

The crash happened in a quiet zone where train horns do not sound off at crossings unless it‚Äôs an emergency situation. It‚Äôs unclear whether the Metrolink train‚Äôs horn went off before the deadly collision.

The mother remains hospitalized in critical condition. No identities have been released by authorities.

Anyone who may have witnessed the collision or the moments leading up to it is asked to contact Cpl. Martin Gonzalez at mgonzalez@redlandspolice.org or Redlands Police Dispatch at 909-798-7681, ext. 1.
column95: An 11-year-old girl was killed and her mother was left critically injured after being struck by a train in Redlands on Tuesday night. The fatal collision happened on the railroad tracks at Alabama Street, just north of Redlands Boulevard shortly before 8:30 p.m., according to the Redlands Police Department. The Metrolink train was traveling at about 50 mph when the engineer spotted the victims‚Äô vehicle on the train tracks, police said. The engineer applied the brakes but was unable to stop in time before crashing head-on into the victims‚Äô car. The child was ejected from the vehicle and pronounced dead at the scene, authorities said. The mother, who was sitting in the driver‚Äôs seat, was taken to the hospital with critical injuries. Images from the scene show the victims‚Äô car completely mangled and destroyed at the busy intersection. Debris from the crash was strewn across the tracks and nearby roadway. The victims were headed northbound when they ended up on the tracks for some unknown reason, police said. Moments later, a Metrolink train traveling westbound struck the vehicle. There were four people aboard the train at the time ‚Äî two passengers, an engineer and the conductor, said Metrolink. One passenger was taken to the hospital with a ‚Äúcomplaint of pain,‚Äù officials said. Locals say the intersection where the crash took place is a dangerous one. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very busy and there are often people who don‚Äôt stop when they‚Äôre supposed to at the intersection,‚Äù said Nicolas, who commutes to Redlands for work. ‚ÄúThey stop in the middle of the intersection because there‚Äôs just so many cars lined up, so I can see an accident happening pretty easily.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe just heard a loud bang,‚Äù said Saalim Scott, a man who worked nearby and heard the crash. ‚ÄúI thought it was something falling off the truck. We all came out and we saw the car and somebody off to the side. It‚Äôs just pretty sad, honestly, because life is short. You want to hold your family a little closer.‚Äù ‚ÄúI got in my car and I came right here and that‚Äôs when I realized the car was hit by the train,‚Äù said resident Victor Medford. ‚ÄúIt hurts. It hurts bad. Last night when I saw it, I cried.‚Äù Police are still investigating how the vehicle ended up on the tracks in the first place

column4: 2 hospitalized after crashing into train in San Bernardino - KTLA
column5:
This is an archived article and the information in the article may be outdated. Please look at the time stamp on the story to see when it was last updated.

Two people are in critical condition after crashing into a Metrolink train in San Bernardino on Wednesday.

The collision happened on Rancho Avenue as the victims drove their pickup truck across the railroad tracks, according to the San Bernardino Police Department.

Over 30 passengers were aboard the train during the crash, police said.

Images from the scene show the crash left the truck in a mangled mess, sending debris strewn across the railroad.

Officers say the truck driver was traveling eastbound towards the tracks at an ‚Äúunsafe speed.‚Äù

The driver ‚Äúfailed to stop for the guard crossing arm and collided into the Metrolink train which was traveling Eastbound,‚Äù authorities said.

Both the truck driver and passenger were transported to a local hospital where they remain in critical condition, police said.

Only one Metrolink passenger suffered minor injuries after the crash, officials confirmed.

column4: Train severs leg of man crawling between rail cars in Gaslamp - NBC 7 San Diego
column5:
An incident on Monday night is shedding light on a dangerous situation that seems to be happening more near the Gaslamp.

Just after midnight, a man tried to crawl between the cars of a freight train after it had stopped on the tracks near the convention center. As he tried to do so, police say, the train began to move, severing the man's leg below the shin.

Stream San Diego News for free, 24/7, wherever you are with NBC 7. WATCH HERE WATCH HERE

Several videos have gone viral in recent months that show impatient pedestrians climbing on and under trains to get from Harbor Drive to the Gaslamp.

A few months ago, another victim lost her leg at 5th and Harbor while trying to crawl between rail cars.

"These freight trains come through the area," SDPD Lt. Anthony Reese said. "They periodically just stop and pedestrians get a little frustrated not being able to cross because you can't cross while the trains are there stopped, so they take it [upon] themselves just to cross, and, unfortunately, some of them don't make it before the train starts, and they get stuck or they fall and, you know, they succumb to these injuries."

Police are urging people to obey the flashing lights and wait for the train to pass, or to use the pedestrian bridge.

The victim from this latest incident was rushed to the UC San Diego Medical Center. It's not known if surgeons were able to reattach the limb.

San Diego police are handling the investigation.

column4: ME report reveals details about deadly crash between Sprinter train, truck in North County - NBC 7 San Diego
column5:
The San Diego Medical Examiner's office on Thursday released new details about a deadly crash involving a North County Transit District train and a truck in Escondido.

The driver of the pickup truck was identified as 86-year-old Walter Robbins of San Marcos. On Tuesday afternoon, Robbins was attempting to cross the railroad tracks near Enterprise Street at about 1 p.m. when, for unknown reasons, he drove through a lowered automatic gate, the ME report said, citing preliminary information.

Stream San Diego News for free, 24/7, wherever you are with NBC 7. WATCH HERE WATCH HERE

The driver of the gray Toyota then stopped on the train tracks, where the vehicle was struck by an eastbound Sprinter train, the report said. First responders arrived shortly after 911 calls and declared Robbins dead at the scene.

The ME's office found Robbins' cause of death to be blunt force injuries and the manner of death to be an accident.

The San Diego County Sheriff's Department is handling the investigation.

The crash affected rail service along the corridor that stretches east and west from Escondido to Oceanside.

column4: One Dead After Truck Collides with Sprinter Train in Escondido - Times of San Diego
column5:
Firefighters leave the area where the pickup truck settled after the fatal crash in Escondido. (Photo courtesy of OnScene.TV)

A motorist died Tuesday after a pickup truck collided with a Sprinter train in an Escondido intersection.

Authorities received reports of the crash, at Mission Road and Enterprise Street, shortly before 1:10 p.m., according to OnScene.TV.

Escondido firefighters had to extricate the driver from the truck. The person was pronounced dead at the scene.

There were no immediate reports of injuries among passengers or North County Transit District personnel aboard the Sprinter, a commuter train that runs between Escondido and Oceanside. The accident, however, has caused service delays, NCTD said.

The collision damaged a bar at the train crossing. Authorities said it appears the vehicle drove past the barrier before the collision.

City News Service contributed to this report.

column4: Man struck, killed by Brightline train while walking on tracks in Cocoa - yahoo.com
column5:
COCOA ‚Äî A man walking along the train tracks in Cocoa late Saturday was struck and killed by an oncoming Brightline train, police said.

The deadly collision happened about 9:30 p.m. in the 800 block of Cocoa Boulevard, also known as U.S. 1, when the southbound passenger train struck the unidentified man. The fatal incident was the third involving Brightline and pedestrians in Brevard since Jan. 1.

Cocoa police report a deadly crash involving a pedestrian struck by a Brightline passenger train late Saturday.

Witnesses told officers that the man ‚Äî whose name was not released but was believed to live in the area ‚Äî was seen walking along the tracks shortly before the train attempted to pass through. It was not immediately known how fast the southbound train was moving at the moment of impact.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The train was allowed to continue on its route shortly after the investigation began. The man‚Äôs body was turned over to the medical examiner‚Äôs office in Rockledge.

Cocoa police report a deadly crash involving a pedestrian struck by a Brightline passenger train late Saturday.

The Federal Railroad Administration reports that there were nine train-related fatalities in Brevard County in 2024. Eight of those fatalities involved Brightline trains.

The first two deadly 2025 Brightline crashes in Brevard occurred last month in Melbourne. Both cases involved pedestrians.

J.D. Gallop is a criminal justice/breaking news reporter at FLORIDA TODAY. Contact Gallop at 321-917-4641 or jgallop@floridatoday.com. X, formerly known as Twitter: @JDGallop.

column4: Pedestrian hit, killed by freight train in South Los Angeles - yahoo.com
column5:
A pedestrian died Monday morning after they were hit by a freight train traveling through South Los Angeles.

The collision happened around 7:20 a.m. near the intersection of Florence Avenue and Graham Avenue in the Florence-Firestone neighborhood.

The pedestrian was hit by a Union Pacific freight train and was declared dead at the scene.

Union Pacific, the second-largest railroad operator in the U.S. and one of the most prominent in the world, confirmed to KTLA that a pedestrian was struck and killed by one of its trains, adding that the crew onboard was uninjured.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

A spokesperson said the company was working with local authorities to ‚Äúunderstand what led up to the incident.‚Äù

The Los Angeles County Sheriff‚Äôs Department and the L.A. County Fire Department were among the agencies to responded to the scene.

Trespassing on train tracks is the leading cause of rail-related deaths in the United States, according to the Transportation Department. It is a misdemeanor in California that can result in jail time or hundreds of dollars in penalties.

Video posted to the Citizen app shows the scene where a pedestrian was hit and killed by a freight train in South Los Angles on Nov. 25, 2024. (Citizen App)

Where on the tracks the collision happened is unclear, but the nearby intersection is at-grade, meaning at street level, and is protected only by crossing gates and lights.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

The DOT urges pedestrians to ‚Äúalways expect a train‚Äù when near tracks, as they don‚Äôt always follow a set schedule, don‚Äôt always sound warning horns when approaching a crossing and can take upwards of a mile to come to a complete stop.

‚ÄúEven when you are not standing directly on the tracks, you risk being hit by a train by being on railroad property,‚Äù the DOT says.

The identity of the person killed has not been released.

The DOT urges pedestrians to always expect a train. The identity of the person killed has not been released.

column4: Person struck by subway train in the Bronx, multiple lines delayed: MTA - yahoo.com
column5:
MELROSE, The Bronx (PIX11) ‚Äì A person was struck by a train in the Bronx Wednesday morning, causing delays on multiple subway lines, according to the MTA.

It happened near the 3rd Avenue-149th Street train station around 6 a.m., according to the FDNY. The person was struck by a southbound No. 2 train and pronounced dead at the scene, police said.

More Transit News

Delays affected the Nos. 2, 3, 4 and 5 lines, the MTA said. Service on the Nos. 2 and 5 trains were severely disrupted, but it returned to normal later Wednesday.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Southbound Nos. 2 and 5 trains ended service at East 180th Street and there were limited trains to Jackson Avenue. There were no southbound No. 5 trains between Jackson Avenue and 149th Street-Grand Concourse and no southbound No. 2 trains between Jackson Avenue and 135th Street.

Northbound No. 5 trains ended at 149th Street-Grand Concourse. Northbound No. 2 trains ended at Times Square-42nd Street, 137th Street-City College or Harlem-148th Street.

The MTA recommended taking the Nos. 1, 3, 4 and 6 trains in Manhattan and the Nos. 3 and 4 trains in Brooklyn while trains got back on schedule. For more information on service changes, check the MTA‚Äôs website.

column4: Pedestrian struck and killed by Amtrak Downeaster train in Exeter - yahoo.com
column5:
EXETER ‚Äî A person was struck and killed by a train Wednesday near the Exeter River Cooperative mobile home park, according to the Exeter Fire Department.

Police and fire responded shortly after 1 p.m. near the wooded area of the train tracks between Front Street and Powder Mill Road, where the pedestrian was hit by the Amtrak Downeaster en route to Boston.

Police and fire crews responded to a call in Exeter near Hilton Avenue shortly after 1 p.m. Wednesday, Nov. 20, 2024 after a person was hit by the Amtrak Downeaster train en route to Boston.

Deputy Fire Chief Ryan Booth reported the unidentified individual died at the scene. The person‚Äôs body remained on the scene as police and fire were waiting for the state medical examiner to arrive and inspect the body before transporting it, he added.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Exeter Police Chief Stephan R. Poulin said the preliminary investigation suggests that the person walking on the tracks was unaware of the approaching southbound train and was struck from behind.

"Exeter Police are currently working with the Amtrak Police and CSX Police Investigators," Poulin stated in a press release. "The case remains under investigation."

The train‚Äôs operation was suspended.

Exeter Deputy Fire Chief Ryan Booth said police are investigating Wednesday, Nov. 20, 2024 after a person was struck by the Amtrak Downeaster train en route to Boston.

Booth said crews and passengers will be transported onto another train shortly.

The Amtrak Downeaster provides transportation from Maine to Boston with Seacoast New Hampshire stations in Dover, Durham and Exeter.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

There have been past recent deaths by suicide on local train tracks involving the Amtrak Downeaster, including one in 2022 in Exeter and one in Durham in 2023.

This story will be updated.

This article originally appeared on Portsmouth Herald: Pedestrian struck and killed by Amtrak Downeaster train in Exeter

column4: Vehicle Collides With Trolley in Chula Vista, Injuring 17, Closing Part of Blue Line - Times of San Diego
column5:
A crash involving a truck and a Metropolitan Transit System trolley left 17 people injured Tuesday and shut down service going both north and south during rush hour in the South Bay.
Three of the patients suffered major trauma in the incident, which took place at around 4:34 p.m. on the Blue Line at Industrial Boulevard and L Street, according to the Chula Vista Fire Department.
The wreck resulted in a shutdown of service for ‚Äúan indefinite period of time,‚Äù a CVFD official said.
L Street also was closed from Broadway to Interstate 5; authorities asked motorists to avoid the area until police gave the all clear.
Multiple units from Chula Vista and National City responded to the scene, along with MTS crews.
Trolley delays will last ‚Äúuntil further notice,‚Äù according to MTS. Riders were advised to use Route 932 instead.
Trolley crash in #ChulaVista pic.twitter.com/A0Rkbc6YRl
‚Äî 619 News Media (@619NewsMedia) November 6, 2024
MTS announced that trolley service between H Street and Iris Avenue would be disrupted throughout the evening, and perhaps until Wednesday morning.
Bus shuttles will run between H Street and Iris Avenue for those who normally rely on the Blue Line.
Riders: This incident is expected to disrupt transit service between H Street and Iris Avenue the rest of service this evening, and may also result in delays early tomorrow morning. Bus shuttles will run between H Street and Iris Avenue. https://t.co/eZevduzXYC
‚Äî San Diego MTS (@sdmts) November 6, 2024
Updated 10:10 p.m. Nov. 5, 2024

column4: Vehicle, trolley crash results in 17 injured - fox5sandiego.com
column5:
This is an archived article and the information in the article may be outdated. Please look at the time stamp on the story to see when it was last updated.

CHULA VISTA, Calif. (FOX 5/KUSI) ‚Äî A collision between a vehicle and a San Diego Metropolitan Transit System trolley injured 17 people Tuesday in Chula Vista, authorities said.

The crash occurred around 4:34 p.m. at Industrial Boulevard and L Street, the Chula Vista Fire Department confirmed to FOX 5/KUSI.

Three of the 17 patients suffered major trauma and were taken to a hospital, according to fire officials. It is unknown if the victims were from the vehicle or trolley.

The area of L Street and Broadway will be shut down for some time.

MTS announced there is no Blue Line service between the H Street and Palm Avenue stations.

‚ÄúRiders can use Route 932 for service between the impacted stations. Expect delays on the Blue Line until further notice,‚Äù the MTS said on X, formerly known as Twitter, at 5:04 p.m.

Crews are working to move the trolley back onto the tracks at this time.

column4: 17 injured after truck collides with trolley at Chula Vista intersection - ABC 10News San Diego
column5:
CHULA VISTA, Calif. (KGTV) ‚Äî Seventeen people were injured Tuesday afternoon Chula Vista Fire officials said after a pickup truck collided with an MTS trolley at an intersection.

Fire officials said the crash happened at approximately 4:30 p.m., at Industrial Boulevard and L Street.

An MTS spokesperson said the truck broadsided a northbound trolley at the L Street grade crossing. One person inside the truck was injured, according to the Chula Vista Police Department.

"Currently there is no Trolley service between H Street Trolley Station and the Iris Avenue Transit Center," a statement from MTS said. "MTS is providing bus shuttles to serve impacted stations between H St. and Iris."

MTS also said it anticipates service to resume in a limited capacity tomorrow morning and is anticipating delays for the rest of the evening and tomorrow morning for those using the Blue Line.

"MTS is investigating the incident and will provide further details when the investigation is complete," the statement said.

column4: Woman Seriously Injured By Train While Trying to Cross Tracks Downtown - Times of San Diego
column5:
Law enforcement at the scene of a train-related injury, Oct. 14 2024. Courtesy Onscene.Media

At least one person was struck and injured in downtown San Diego Monday night when a group of people tried to cross the tracks.

According to police, a group of people became impatient after a train was sitting on the tracks and blocking access to 5th Avenue across the street from the Convention Center and decided to climb over and under the train.

‚ÄúThe trolley arms were down, it was a slow moving train and people‚Ä¶ didn‚Äôt want to wait for the train,‚Äù San Diego police Lt. Anthony Reese told Onscene.Media.

The engineer had no idea that the BNS&F train had struck anybody and thus did not stop, he said. First responders found one person on the tracks.

‚ÄúOne female tried to cross and either got slipped and fell or got stuck underneath the train, and her right leg got run over,‚Äù Reese said, adding that her leg may have to be amputated.

He said that the incident highlights the danger of being around moving trains ‚Äî even slow ones.

column4: First-responders make grisly discovery after female hit by train in Gaslamp Quarter - NBC 7 San Diego
column5:
It's no secret that EMT's and paramedics have one of the toughest jobs out there, but even for them, some days are worse than others.

When an ambulance called out to Harbor Drive and 5th Avenue pulled up last night a little after 10 p.m., the first-responders knew somebody or some people had been hit by a train.

Stream San Diego News for free, 24/7, wherever you are with NBC 7. WATCH HERE WATCH HERE

Very quickly, they discovered that there was only one female victim, and her leg had been badly injured when the train ran over her. The original reporting party had told 911 operators that five people had been injured, but that report was wrong.

Police told NBC 7 on Monday night that the victim had no ID on her when she was struck by the train.

Traffic was shut down in the area while investigators worked the scene. The victim survived her injury and was taken to a local hospital. Her current condition is unknown.

column4: BNSF Railway confirms train involved in incident that ended in woman's leg amputation downtown - ABC 10News San Diego
column5:
SAN DIEGO (KGTV) ‚Äî BNSF Railway confirmed one of their trains was involved in an incident in downtown San Diego Monday night that ended with a woman's leg amputated.

The incident happened on East Harbor Drive near the convention center as people left the Rady Shell after a concert.

San Diego police say a woman and several others were trying to crawl around a stopped train when the train moved, causing several people to fall.

The woman fell under the train and was run over, and her leg had to be amputated.

RELATED: Police: Woman loses leg after being run over by freight train in downtown San Diego

BNSF Railway says the incident is currently under investigation.

1/1 Skip Ad Continue watching after the ad Visit Advertiser website GO TO PAGE

On Tuesday, people who work downtown told ABC 10News that they regularly see the freight trains blocking intersections and crosswalks.

They say people get impatient and start crawling through the train cars or going around them.

"I see people running through that all the time, I see people going around, so if the train is almost to the end to go around it, they'll go around it, I see. People jumping through sometimes, on bikes sometimes like quickly going around it," said Rhiawna Samudio, who works nearby.

Pedicab drivers in the area say they see the same issue with people climbing on and through the trains when they're stationary.

"It takes about 20 to 25 minutes, sometimes even longer, so people get desperate, and they start crossing the train," said Maycl Soto, a pedicab driver who regularly works downtown.

The woman involved in Monday's incident hasn't been identified.

column4: Female Pedestrian Seriously Injured by Sprinter Train at Rail Crossing in Oceanside - Times of San Diego
column5:

A light rail train struck a pedestrian in Oceanside Wednesday, seriously injuring her, authorities reported.

column4: Teen hit, killed by train in Sorrento Valley identified as Torrey Pines High student - NBC 7 San Diego
column5:
A teenager who died after being struck by a train in Sorrento Valley on Friday has been identified by his family.

NBC 7 spoke with the uncle of the teenager who identified the teen as Alex Segal and said they buried him this past weekend.

Stream San Diego News for free, 24/7, wherever you are with NBC 7. WATCH HERE WATCH HERE

The fatal incident occurred last Friday when Segal, on a bicycle, crossed the train tracks and was struck by an oncoming train.

‚ÄúAfter the northbound train passed through, a 17-year-old boy crossed the tracks on his bike, not realizing there was also a passing southbound train,‚Äù the San Diego County Sheriff‚Äôs Department said.

The two other teens were not hurt.

Alex attended Torrey Pines High School and according to the school's website, was a member of the boy's junior varsity soccer team.

In an email to Torrey Pines families, principal Rob Coppo said:

‚ÄúI know we are all deeply saddened by this loss, and we send our condolences to the student‚Äôs family and friends. As you can imagine, the family involved in this tragic accident is going through an extremely difficult time right now. The family is asking that we respect their privacy at this time.‚Äù

"Bike and ebike accidents specifically cause some of the most common injuries Rady Children‚Äôs Hospital treats in the summer, said Matt Derkrikorian a Trauma Program Manager at Rady Children‚Äôs Hospital.

‚ÄúThe state of California has the highest fatalities in the United States,‚Äù said Nancy Sheehan-McCulloch an executive director with the California Operation Lifesaver.

McCulloch says this applies to everything from trespassing on the tracks to people crossing before it‚Äôs safe.

A memorial has been placed to honor the 17-year-old.

column4: Man Walking on Tracks in Bay Park Struck, Killed by Freight Train - Times of San Diego

Officers at the scene after the fatality on the tracks in Bay Park. Photo credit: OnScene.TV

A man was struck and killed by a Burlington Northern Santa Fe freight train in Bay Park early Saturday while walking on the tracks.

Authorities were summoned an area near McGraw Street and Morena Boulevard after the 2 a.m. incident, according to OnScene.TV.

The San Diego County Sheriff‚Äôs Department is investigating. San Diego police and fire crews also responded.

The tracks were shut down temporarily following the incident. According to the @PacSurfliners account on X, the disruption forced some cancellations until the closure, which affected all rail services between San Diego and Los Angeles, was set to be lifted at 8 a.m.

It is not known why the man was on the tracks. The train, heading north, stretched over a mile leading freight cars carrying new vehicles.

column4: Update: 17-year old boy killed by San Diego Amtrak train after riding around crossing gates; 2nd SoCal bike death Friday - BikinginLA
column5:
Sadly, there was more bad news for the Southern California bicycling community on Friday.
According to multiple reports, a 17-year old boy was killed¬†when he was struck by an Amtrak train in San Diego‚Äôs University City neighborhood early Friday afternoon.
The victim, who has not been publicly identified, was crossing the railroad tracks on Sorrento Valley Blvd, between Sorrento Valley Road and Roselle Street, when he was hit by the southbound Amtrak Pacific Surfliner at 12:34 pm.
He died at the scene.
The victim was one of three boys who stopped their bikes at the railroad crossing gates to wait for a northbound train to pass. But as so often happens, he rode around the gates after that train had passed, not realizing another train was coming in the opposite direction.
Tragically, Fox5 reports that the victim‚Äôs parents arrived shortly after the crash, while officials were still removing his mangled bike from the tracks.
The other two boys were not injured. It‚Äôs not clear if they were riding with the victim, or just happened to stop together at the gates.
This is yet another tragic reminder to always wait until the gates go up to cross any rail tracks, regardless of whether it seems safe at the time.
Anyone with information is urged to call the Sheriff‚Äôs Department‚Äôs non-emergency line at 858/565-5200.
This is at least the 24th bicycling fatality in Southern California this year, and the seventh that I‚Äôm aware of in San Diego County.
Update: The victim has been identified 17-year old Alex Segal. He was a student at Torrey Pines High School in the Del Mar Heights neighborhood, and a member of the junior varsity soccer team.
My deepest sympathy and prayers for Alex Segal and all his family and loved ones.
Thanks to Phillip Young for the heads-up.¬†

column4: Teen on bike killed by train in Sorrento Valley - NBC 7 San Diego
column5:
A teenager on a bicycle was struck and killed by a train Friday afternoon in San Diego's Sorrento Valley, according to an Amtrak official.

Stream San Diego News for free, 24/7, wherever you are with NBC 7. WATCH HERE WATCH HERE

"On June 14, Amtrak Train 770 was traveling from Goleta, Calif., to San Diego at approx. 12:45 p.m. when an individual who was trespassing on the track came into contact with the train in the city of San Diego," Amtrak said in a statement released later that afternoon. "There have been no reported injuries to the 254 passengers or crew onboard."

About 5:30, the San Diego Sheriff's Department released the following information about how the boy was killed:

"Witnesses told deputies three boys riding their bicycles were stopped at the crossing arms to allow a northbound train to pass. After the northbound train passed through, a 17-year-old boy crossed the tracks on his bike, not realizing there was also a passing southbound train. The boy was struck by the train and did not survive his injuries. The two other bicyclists were not hurt."

The Amtrak official said that when San Diego police and fire responded to the scene, they found the teen on the tracks, and that he died at the scene.

The victim's identity has not yet been released by officials.

The incident occurred near the intersection of Sorrento Valley Boulevard and Roselle Street.

The train service notified riders at 2:04 p.m. to expect lengthy delays until further notice after "trespasser activity." Shortly after 6 p.m., NBC 7 confirmed that rail service had resumed.

Service Disruption: As of 2:00 pm PT, All services operating in the San Diego (OLT) area may experience lengthy delays and service adjustments due to trespasser activity. Updates will be provided when more information becomes available. #SurflinerAlert ‚Äî Pacific Surfliner (@PacSurfliners) June 14, 2024

San Diego Sheriff's deputies are at the scene investigating the incident. The Amtrak official said that the agency was working with local law enforcement on the investigation.

Anyone with information about the incident is being urged to call the sheriff's department's at (858) 565-5200.

Check back here for updates on this breaking news story ‚Äî Ed.

column4: Investigation of Death on Tracks in Leucadia Leads to Brief Closure of Rails - Times of San Diego
column5:
The Amtrak train stopped on the tracks after striking the victim. Photo credit: OnScene.TV

A person died early Saturday after being struck by a passenger train in Leucadia.

An Amtrak Pacific Surfliner heading northbound at approximately 60 mph hit the victim near N. Coast Highway 101 and Jupiter Street around 7 a.m., according to OnScene.TV. The train stopped about a mile to the north after the incident.

San Diego County Sheriff‚Äôs deputies and the San Diego County Medical Examiner were on the scene to conduct the investigation. Initially, it was unknown whether the victim was male or female.

The tracks were shut down to all train traffic for more than two hours after the accident. Authorities were seeking witnesses to the incident.

A social media account that reports on Pacific Surfliner activity noted that from 7:45 to 9:50 a.m. Saturday all rail traffic was temporarily suspended between Oceanside and Solana Beach.

column4: Woman hit and killed by train in Encinitas; fourth recent death on local tracks - North Coast Current
column5:
Emergency lights. (Ariel Camilo, FreeImages)

A woman was hit and killed by a train in the Encinitas community of Cardiff on Saturday, Feb. 10, the fourth such fatality along North San Diego County tracks since the start of the year.

The incident happened just before 8 a.m. near the intersection of Chesterfield Drive and San Elijo Avenue, the San Diego County Sheriff‚Äôs Department reported. The unidentified woman was hit and killed by a southbound North County Transit District Coaster train.

There were no further details about the incident. The sheriff‚Äôs North Coastal Station handed the investigation to the department‚Äôs Transit Enforcement Unit, which covers incidents on NCTD routes.

The death is the fourth along coastal railroad tracks since the start of the year. A man was killed when he was struck by a BNSF freight train in Encinitas late Jan. 13. Two days later, on Jan. 15, a man was hit and killed by an Amtrak train in Carlsbad. Then, on Feb. 3, a man was struck and killed by a BNSF freight train on Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton.

In addition, on Jan. 11 in Sorrento Valley, a man was struck and killed by a Coaster train while walking his dog during the early morning.

The Sheriff‚Äôs Department asks anyone with potential information about Saturday‚Äôs incident in Cardiff to call its non-emergency line at 858-565-5200.

The San Diego County Sheriff‚Äôs Department reported the incident and handed the investigation to the department‚Äôs Transit Enforcement Unit. column4: Train crash in San Diego kills 26-year-old man - kiiitv.com
column5:
Neighbors said the crash sounded like thunder and shook their homes.

Example video title will go here for this video

Example video title will go here for this video

To stream 3NEWS on your phone, you need the 3NEWS app.

SAN DIEGO, Texas ‚Äî In the tight-knit town of San Diego, Texas, it's not out of the ordinary for the train to pass through late at night.

A portion of the track runs through the front and back yards of some residents' homes, especially those living near North Bexar Street.

"I heard a big bang, screeching noise, I thought the train was going to fall on my house," Madelynn De La Rosa said describing what happened Thursday night.

After their houses rattled, neighbors rushed to the scene which they described as chaotic and heartbreaking -- a car was trapped under the train, with a man inside.

"He was just screaming in there and I couldn't do anything," De La Rosa said.

As neighbors gathered around the car, so did first responders. One neighbor, who requested to be anonymous, said their worst fears were confirmed when police approached the trapped car.

"As soon as we heard his name, we knew, and our hearts dropped because he grew up here with us," she said.

Neighbors said it was 26-year-old Eric Galvan who was yelling and honking his horn to let people know he was alive.

"They tried like, talking to him too, and like being there for him and everything," De La Rosa said.

Neighbors believe Galvan's vehicle crashed with the train at a railroad crossing a block away, and was then dragged by the train until coming to a stop.

First responders said they faced challenges as they tried to remove Galvan. One, train cars are not easy to lift and move; and two, there were live power lines strewn all over the scene.

Bystanders tried to comfort Galvan as they worked to remove his car.

"It was amazing to see like, how all our neighbors got together and try to help this man," San Diego resident Emeree Rodriguez said.

Unfortunately, Galvan passed away at the scene. Bystanders said his family was nearby as the events unfolded.

"My thoughts are with them and I can't even imagine what they're going through," one witness said.

According to neighbors, Galvan had a significant other and a child. They said as they get through this tough time, they'll come together as a small but strong community to support Galvan's family.

column4: 2 killed on same stretch of train tracks - Moorpark Acorn
column5:
DANGER‚Äî‚ÄúThe public may have the misperception that they will be able to hear a train coming in time to avoid it,‚Äù wrote John Frittelli, a specialist in transportation policy, in a 2016 Congressional Research Service report. Courtesy of Amtrak
Two Moorpark men were hit and killed days apart on the same stretch of railroad track near Avenida Colonia and Nogales Avenue.
Both men were struck by Amtrak trains traveling at approximately 70 miles per hour, officials from the Ventura County
Sheriff‚Äôs Office said, and both were pronounced dead at the scene.
Authorities do not know why 38-year-old Robert ‚ÄúBobby‚Äù Melgoza was near the railroad tracks when he was hit and killed Nov. 24.
The second man, 47-year-old¬†Jesse Zepeda,¬†was reportedly laying flowers for Melgoza when he was struck at the same spot Nov. 26.
The first fatality occurred just before 5 p.m. last Saturday when a nine-car passenger train traveling from San Diego to San Luis Obispo struck Melgoza on the railroad tracks south of Avenida Colonia, according to authorities.
Zepeda, the victim of the second crash‚Äîwhich happened at 11:33 a.m. Monday on the same stretch of roadway‚Äîwas placing flowers for the Melgoza, according to witnesses.
Melgoza Courtesy of Anthony Martinez
‚ÄúWitnesses advised the adult male tried to step off the tracks before the train came through but did not get off the tracks in time,‚Äù according to a report from the sheriff‚Äôs office.
Zepeda was struck by the 10-car passenger train traveling from Los Angeles to Seattle.
No passengers or crew members on either Amtrak train was injured. The first train reportedly had 413 passengers and seven crew members on board; the second train had 226 passengers and three crew members.
Each fatal crash shut down the railroad tracks in both directions for more than two hours.
Both fatalities remain under investigation.
Family and friends of Melgoza started a GoFundMe page, gofundme.com/robertmelgozamemorial, to help pay for the Moorpark resident‚Äôs funeral expenses.
According to the online fundraiser, Melgoza was a ‚Äúloving son, brother, friend and, most importantly, a father.‚Äù
‚ÄúHe was one of a kind and the definition of true strength,‚Äù the GoFundMe page reads.
Railroad deaths
Although trespassing on railroad property is illegal in nearly every state, it remains the leading cause of death on or near rail lines.
According to a 2016 report from the Congressional Research Service (CRS), a public policy research arm of the U.S. Congress, trespassing results in more train-related fatalities than derailments and collisions combined.
Of the 9,575 railroad incidents in the United States in 2017, 824 resulted in fatalities, according to data from the Federal Railroad Administration. About 19 percent, or 157, of those fatalities were reported in California.
Nearly all were the result of people trespassing on railroad property, including freight, commuter and intercity passenger lines.
‚ÄúMost pedestrian trespassers are simply taking a shortcut along rail tracks, although some are on the tracks for recreational purposes,‚Äù John Frittelli, a specialist in transportation policy, wrote in his 2016 CRS report. ‚ÄúThe public may have the misperception that they will be able to hear a train coming in time to avoid it.‚Äù
Some may be distracted because they are wearing headphones or looking at their cellphones; others are impaired by alcohol or drugs, according to the report.
Since 2005, the U.S. Department of Transportation and the Federal Rail Authority have worked together to reduce the number of rail accidents caused by human error and equipment malfunction.
The organizations manage the National Rail Safety Action Plan, a blueprint to address safety issues facing the railroad industry.
The action plan works to address worker fatigue, improve track safety, enhance emergency preparedness, strengthen the safety compliance program and improve rail crossing safety.
In addition to their action plan, the industry has devoted time and resources to educating the public about the risk of driving and walking near rail tracks.
This education is done mainly through Operation LifeSaver, a nonprofit that works to reduce fatal train accidents and educate people about railroad rights-ofway and crossing safety.
Active in every state, Operation LifeSaver brings in rail professionals to speak to school groups, driver education classes, professional drivers, law enforcement officers and emergency responders.
The group also tries to prevent rail deaths by fining those who are caught trespassing and by placing warning signs and fences near populated areas.
In 2015, safety improvements were made at four railroad crossings in Simi Valley and Moorpark to reduce the number of train-related accidents in the cities.
The project added crossing gates on busy roadways to ensure cars and pedestrians do not cross in front of an oncoming train.
The gates were added at First Street, Erringer Road and Sycamore Drive in Simi Valley and at Moorpark Avenue in Moorpark.

Authorities do not know why 38-year-old Robert ‚ÄúBobby‚Äù Melgoza was near the railroad tracks when he was hit and killed Nov. 24. The second man, 47-year-old Jesse Zepeda, was reportedly laying flowers for Melgoza when he was struck at the same spot Nov. 26. The first fatality occurred just before 5 p.m. last Saturday when a nine-car passenger train traveling from San Diego to San Luis Obispo struck Melgoza on the railroad tracks south of Avenida Colonia, according to authorities. Zepeda, the victim of the second crash‚Äîwhich happened at 11:33 a.m. Monday on the same stretch of roadway‚Äîwas placing flowers for the Melgoza, according to witnesses. Melgoza was struck by the 10-car passenger train traveling from Los Angeles to Seattle. No passengers or crew members on either Amtrak train was injured. OCEANSIDE, Calif., (KGTV) ‚Äî A pedestrian died after being hit by a northbound Amtrak train under the Harbor Drive overpass.

According to Amtrak Public relations, the Pacific Surfliner train 769 was on its way from San Diego to Santa Barbara. But at 10:20 am, when it was passing through Camp Pendleton, it hit a trespasser. That person died on impact. All 515 passengers and crew members were not hurt.

As a result, all train traffic was stopped in both directions for nearly two hours. Passengers on Train 769 remained inside while four law enforcement agencies conducted their investigation. Under the San Diego Sheriffs Department, Camp Pendleton Police, Oceanside Police, and Amtrak Police secured the scene for hours.

10News met train enthusiast, Kevin Harper, looking down at the Harbor Drive overpass. He said he has come to this very location several times to look at trains pass through. But Sunday‚Äôs scene was tragic.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen accidents before, but nothing like this,‚Äù Harper said.

The accident was a big reminder that his favorite hobby could become dangerous if you are not careful.

‚ÄúStop, look, listen. That‚Äôs all I can say, especially when you‚Äôre around train tracks like this,‚Äù Harper said.

Authorities have not released the identity of the victim.

column4: Train hits, severely injures woman in wheelchair - cbs8.com
column5:
SAN DIEGO (CNS) - A commuter train struck and gravely injured a 57- year-old disabled woman Wednesday after her wheelchair apparently got stuck on a stretch of railway near Old Town.



The southbound Coaster train was traveling at about 50 mph when the engineer saw the pedestrian in its path in the area of Pacific Highway and West Washington Street about 7:30 a.m., according to sheriff's officials.



"The train went into emergency braking, and (the operator) sounded its whistle and horn, " Sgt. Jason King said. "The (woman) was unable to (get) off of the tracks and was struck by the train."



Medics took her to UCSD Medical Center for treatment of life- threatening trauma, the sergeant said. Her name was not released.



A witness told News 8 the woman had been trying to cross the tracks when her wheelchair seemingly got stuck as the passenger train approached.



The crash halted train service in the area for about two hours.

column4: Pedestrian Struck, Killed by Amtrak Train in Del Mar - NBC 7 San Diego

A woman died after being struck by a northbound Amtrak Pacific Surfliner train in Del Mar on Sunday, authorities said.

The accident happened a little before 10 a.m. at the intersection of 15th Street and Coast Boulevard, San Diego County sheriff's Deputy Tyler Eikermann said.

The woman walked past the signal guards at the intersection and was struck by the Pacific Surfliner train 769 heading to San Luis Obispo, an Amtrak spokeswoman said.

The train traveling approximately 48 mph when it struck the woman, Eikermann said. The woman was pronounced dead at the scene, he said.

There were no injuries to the 229 passengers and crew on board and the train was delayed for about two hours, Amtrak spokeswoman Beth K. Toll said.

It was unclear why the woman crossed the tracks. The cause of the accident is under investigation.

About 2,000 people are killed or injured in grade crossing and trespassing incidents nationwide each year, according to Amtrak.

column4: Pedestrian hit by SUV that was hit by train - cbs8.com
column5:
A southbound Coaster commuter train hit a vehicle Saturday afternoon in Del Mar, causing serious injuries to one victim who was hospitalized, according to officials.

DEL MAR (CBS 8/CNS) - A southbound Coaster commuter train hit a vehicle Saturday afternoon in Del Mar, causing serious injuries to one victim who was hospitalized, according to officials.

 

An SUV containing two people in the area where 15th Street crosses the tracks was hit, according to San Diego County sheriff's officials.

 

A woman driving an SUV was attempting to make a U-turn at the train crossing near Coast Boulevard when the crossing arm came down. When she tried to turn around, she got clipped by the train and hit a pedestrian, trapping the victim under the vehicle, according to San Diego County Sheriff's Lt. Dave Schaller.

The pedestrian suffered major injuries and was transported to Scripps La Jolla for evaluation.

About seven deputies responded to the tracks where the Coaster train came to a stop in the area near Ocean Avenue just before 2:30 p.m., Schaller

said.

 

There were apparently two witnesses to the collision, and deputies requested a Farsi translator to respond to the scene, Schaller said.

 

All train service was halted while deputies conducted their investigation.

column5:
San Diego police rushed to Mission Hills Friday morning after an Amtrak Surfliner Train hit a box truck.

The accident was reported just after 9:30 a.m. at Pacific Highway and Washington Street in the uptown San Diego area. The San Diego County Sheriff's Department told NBC 7 no injuries were reported.

Traffic was shut down and diverted in the area, officials said. Amtrak service was temporarily shut down in both directions as well.

Officers from the San Diego Police Department, San Diego Fire-Rescue Department (SDFD) crews and officials from the San Diego Metropolitan Transit System (MTS) all responded to the scene.

The collision caused the box truck to also smash into a fence that runs along the train tracks. The box truck plowed through a cross pole and traffic sign, which wound up wedged between the truck and fence. The truck subsequently struck three other vehicles.

The traffic sign also hit an MTS vehicle parked on the other side of the fence, damaging a window.

NBC 7 spoke with Natalie Fernbaugh, a passenger on the Amtrak train bound for Los Angeles.

She said she was listening to music when, suddenly, the train came to a halt.

‚ÄúIt stopped really abruptly. We were just all kind of confused,‚Äù she explained. "It kind of shook."

Fernbaugh said she and other passengers waited in their seats for 15 minutes or so, until they heard an announcement on the speaker from Amtrak staff. They were notified of the accident, and the subsequent delay of their train trip.

Witness Jasmine Pablo was riding in a car with a friend near the tracks, waiting at a red light behind a line of other cars.

She said it looked like the box truck ‚Äì at the front of the line ‚Äì got stuck on the tracks and the oncoming train was unable to avoid hitting it.

As of noon, officials were still investigating and had not yet released further details of what led to the collision.

column4: Metrolink examining safety of state-of-the-art rail cars in wake of Oxnard crash - Los Angeles Times
column5:
After a Metrolink commuter train slammed into a pickup truck near Oxnard this year, injuring 27 people and killing the engineer, railroad officials were quick to claim that new crash-resistant passenger coaches appeared to save lives and reduce injuries.

Now, however, Metrolink is trying to determine whether a design flaw in one of the state-of-the-art cars played a role in derailing the train.

The evaluation marks a setback in the regional passenger railroad‚Äôs campaign to employ advanced safety technology to help rebuild public confidence after a 2008 head-on collision in Chatsworth killed 28 and injured 135.

Advertisement

On Thursday, railroad officials announced that they will restrict the use of 57 of the new passenger cars that have control cabs for engineers and operate at the front of trains when they are being pushed from behind by locomotives.

The use of such ‚Äúcab cars‚Äù is common practice among the nation‚Äôs commuter railroads when trains reverse direction at the end of a line.

While the railroad, which serves six Southern California counties, reexamines safety features on the cars, built by South Korea-based Hyundai Rotem Co., the vehicles will be replaced with locomotives leased from the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway Co. The cab cars will remain in service as passenger coaches used elsewhere in a train‚Äôs lineup of cars.

Advertisement

‚ÄúWe are taking this additional step as a redundancy to keep our riders safe,‚Äù said Metrolink Chief Executive Art Leahy. He added that the railroad is dedicated to becoming the safest in the nation.

1 / 16 Aerial view of the Metrolink train derailment in Oxnard. The crash occurred at the Rice Avenue crossing, causing three cars to derail and injuring at least 28 people. (Don Kelsen / Los Angeles Times) 2 / 16 Oxnard police Officer Sarah Shobe removes tape in preparation of reopening Rice Avenue on the morning of Feb. 25, a day after the crash. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times) 3 / 16 Crews continued to monitor the rail tracks after a night of repairs at the intersection of Rice Avenue and 5th Street in Oxnard. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times) 4 / 16 The Metrolink track at the intersection of Rice Avenue and 5th Street in Oxnard was operational Feb. 25. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times) 5 / 16 Salvage crews work on the derailed Metrolink train cars in Oxnard on Tuesday afternoon. (Michael Robinson Chavez / Los Angeles Times) 6 / 16 Ventura County first responders at the scene of an overturned Metrolink train car in Oxnard Tuesday, after it collided with a vehicle on the tracks. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times) 7 / 16 An uninjured passenger from the Metrolink train derailment in Oxnard gestures to the media Tuesday, after the train he was riding in colliding with a vehicle on the tracks. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times) 8 / 16 Ventura County first responders at the scene of an overturned Metrolink train car in Oxnard Tuesday. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times) 9 / 16 Firefighters and first responders on the scene of a Metrolink train derailment in Oxnard early Tuesday morning. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times) 10 / 16 Officials examine a Metrolink train that derailed in Oxnard early Tuesday morning. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times) 11 / 16 Firefighters inspect a Metrolink train car that derailed in Oxnard early Tuesday. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times) 12 / 16 Firefighters inspect a Metrolink train car that derailed in Oxnard early Tuesday. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times) 13 / 16 A Ventura County first responder at the scene of an overturned Metrolink train car in Oxnard after it colliding with a vehicle on the tracks. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times) 14 / 16 A firefighter hoses down hot spots after a Metrolink train collided with a vehicle on the tracks in Oxnard early Tuesday. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times) 15 / 16 Metrolink passengers wait to be transported after their train derailed in Oxnard early Tuesday. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times) 16 / 16 A Ventura County sheriff‚Äôs deputy inspects an overturned Metrolink train car in Oxnard early Tuesday. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

Hyundai Rotem officials could not be reached for comment.

In February, a Metrolink train with a Rotem cab car in front derailed after hitting a pickup truck and trailer that strayed into a grade crossing at 5th Street and Rice Avenue outside of Oxnard.

Advertisement

Metrolink officials declared that the new cars with energy-absorbing crush zones, heavier construction and anti-derailing features helped reduce deaths and injuries. The agency‚Äôs $263-million investment in Rotem passenger and cab cars clearly paid off, they argued.

As part of its investigation, the railroad is trying

to determine whether a plow-like attachment on the front of the cab car failed in the collision and allowed wreckage to get under the wheels, triggering the derailment.

‚ÄúWe are taking this step out of an abundance of caution,‚Äù said Moorpark City Councilman Keith Millhouse, a member of the railroad‚Äôs board of directors. ‚ÄúThis is an interim measure until the plow can be evaluated and beefed up if necessary. This is going to be costly for the railroad, but you can‚Äôt put a price on safety.‚Äù

Millhouse estimated that use of the cab cars will be restricted for a year before the issue is resolved.

Leahy said the railroad has been working with the National Transportation Safety Board, which is investigating the Oxnard accident. Though there are concerns about the Rotem cab car plows, the NTSB has yet to determine the cause of the crash.

‚ÄúThis is very interesting,‚Äù said Paul Dyson, president of the Rail Passenger of Assn. of California who has questioned whether the new Rotem cars are as safe as officials say. ‚ÄúThe plow is critical in keeping debris out from under the cars. Something was really wrong in Oxnard with the way the train jack-knifed. Passengers really got tossed around.‚Äù

Advertisement

Dyson contends that the cars‚Äô energy-absorbing crush zones did not appear to lessen the force of the impact and that the couplers between cars did not keep coaches aligned as intended.

Since 2003, Metrolink has had four serious accidents, including three derailments, involving trains with cab cars in front. Sixteen people were killed and almost 360 injured in those crashes.

Though federal studies indicate there is minimal risk from the use of cab cars, some safety experts contend that having heavier locomotives in front reduces chances of derailment in an accident. They also have questioned Metrolink‚Äôs use of cab cars in a 512-mile system that contains hundreds of grade crossings and shares track with freight trains.

Tim Smith, the California legislative director for the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Trainmen, declined to comment on the Oxnard crash. In general, he said the union opposes the use of cab cars.

‚ÄúWe have felt they are dangerous,‚Äù Smith said. ‚ÄúCab cars are light in weight and easy to lift off the tracks. As far as safety is concerned, we would like to have a locomotive out in front.‚Äù

Millhouse, however, defended the use of cab cars and said the new Rotem designs are superior to previous generations of such control cars.

Advertisement

Officials have praised the cars, saying that they include the latest safety features required by the federal government and that Metrolink is at the forefront of deploying the new technology.

Millhouse stressed that the temporary restrictions on the Rotem vehicles relate specifically to how the plow performed in the crash, not the larger debate over the safety of cab cars.

Follow @LADeadline16 for aviation news.

column4: Man killed by train in San Diego may have been attempting filmed stunt - The Guardian
column5:
An unidentified man who tried to roll under a freight train in downtown San Diego during what authorities say may have been a videotaped stunt was killed on Thursday when he was struck by the locomotive.

The man, who was between 20 and 30 years old, was cut into pieces by the northbound Burlington Northern Santa Fe freight train, which was travelling about 10mph (16km/h) at the time and was 62 cars long, Detective Ed Macken from San Diego County Sheriff‚Äôs Department said.

‚ÄúHe was be-bopping back and forth and there might have been phones up recording,‚Äù Macken said. ‚ÄúHe was trying to do a manoeuvre to shoot under a train and it didn‚Äôt work.‚Äù

The train finally came to a stop about 35 miles (56km) north of the fatal incident.

Macken said the crossing gates were down and warning lights were flashing when the accident happened.

The death highlighted an ongoing problem with open, very visible and accessible train corridors in San Diego County, Macken said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had 22 train suicides and accidents in the last year-and-a-half,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt think this one was a suicide, but they all make a big mess.‚Äù

Passenger and freight trains in both directions were stopped for hours while deputies tried to gather evidence and find witnesses.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre still looking for witnesses,‚Äù Macken said. ‚ÄúWhat we know was he was crouched down, bobbing back and forth and then he went for it. Sixty train cars went by and then he rolled under the last two.‚Äù

column4: Del Mar Leaders Honor Former Mayor Killed by Train - NBC 7 San Diego
column5:
Former Del Mar mayor Louis ‚ÄúLou‚Äù Terrell ‚Äì who was struck and killed by a train while running after his dog earlier this month ‚Äì will be honored with a special proclamation at the Del Mar City Council meeting Tuesday.



The city council, led by current Del Mar Mayor Lee Haydu, has declared Jan. 21, 2014, ‚ÄúRemembering Lou Terrell Day‚Äù in the City of Del Mar.



‚ÄúLou was a natural leader who set an example for all of us on how to make Del Mar a better place,‚Äù reads a proclamation from the council honoring Terrell. ‚ÄúHis tremendous positive impact in this community will be significantly missed by all our residents.‚Äù



Terrell was fatally hit by an oncoming train on Jan. 3 near the train tracks in the 100-block of 11th Street, a popular crossing spot in Del Mar for surfers and pedestrians. He was taking part in one of his favorite daily activities, walking his dog, Abe, during the deadly accident.

According to investigators, Terrell was walking his unleashed dog when a northbound Amtrak train approached the area and sounded its horn. Officials believe the horn spooked the dog, which darted across the tracks with Terrell running after it. The train hit Terrell, killing him on impact.



The dog survived and was reunited with Terrell‚Äôs loved ones following the tragic accident.



Friends, family and the Del Mar City Council say Terrell loved body-surfing and would constantly catch waves at the local beach. The avid dog lover would also take daily walks around town, greeting fellow dog owners with a smile and conversation.



According to the city council, Terrell was an active member of the Del Mar community for more than 40 years. He was first appointed to a city committee on Jan. 2, 1979, serving as a member of the Beach Encroachment Committee. On Apr. 8, 1980, Terrell was elected to the city council, a position he held from 1980 to 1984.



On Apr. 20, 1981, the city council unanimously appointed Terrell as the mayor of Del Mar.



‚ÄúLou was an active participant in citizen meetings to develop the community plan and contributed significantly to our city by being the founder and early president of the Del Mar Foundation to help develop a diverse cultural arts program in the city, an endowment for the city and originating the summer concerts in the park, booking top performers to entertain citizens from all over the region,‚Äù cites Tuesday‚Äôs proclamation.



In addition to those duties, Terrell also represented Del Mar on SANDAG in 1980, served as President of Planned Parenthood of San Diego & Riverside Counties, served as a board member of the ACLU of San Diego and Imperial Counties, served as a board member and president of the Foundation for Change and was Chair of the Political Science Department at San Diego State University.



A memorial was held for Terrell on Jan. 5 at the Powerhouse Community Center. There, loved ones, friends and residents remembered the countless hours Terrell dedicated to Del Mar during his lifetime and said his death was a huge loss for the community.

column4: Tow truck driver killed by Amtrak train in Cardiff ID‚Äôd - cbs8.com
column5:
An autopsy was pending Sunday on a tow truck driver who was fatally struck by a southbound Amtrak train at a grade crossing in Cardiff.

Example video title will go here for this video

Example video title will go here for this video

To stream CBS 8 on your phone, you need the CBS 8 app.

ENCINITAS (CNS) - Authorities Sunday publicly identified the tow truck driver who was struck and killed by an Amtrak train at a railroad crossing in Cardiff-by-the-Sea.

Shaun William Riddle, 27, was attempting to hook a vehicle stalled at Chesterfield Drive and South Coast Highway 101 to the flatbed tow truck about 2:35 p.m. Saturday, according to the San Diego County Medical Examiner's Office.

Riddle was apparently assisting the owner of a broken-down SUV just west of the tracks, sheriff's officials said.

A southbound Surfliner train approached the intersection and Riddle got back into the truck to move it out of the train's path, but could not do so, the Medical Examiner's Office reported.

The train was traveling at a high rate of speed when it struck the tow truck, which reportedly was between closed crossing arms, authorities said. The rig was demolished.

Riddle died at the scene, the Medical Examiner's Office said.

The southbound train stopped at the Solana Beach station, where several of the 125 passengers aboard were treated for minor injuries. Passengers were transferred to another train or buses, and the tracks were reopened shortly before 5 p.m.

Passengers were transferred to another train or buses, and the tracks were reopened shortly before 5 p.m.

column4: Tow Truck Driver Killed in Train Crash - NBC 7 San Diego
column5:
An Amtrak train collided with a tow truck in Cardiff Saturday afternoon killing the driver of the tow truck, officials confirmed.

 

 The crash happened around 2:35 p.m. at Chesterfield Drive and South Coast Highway 101.

 

 According to Encinitas deputies, the driver of the tow truck had stopped on the railroad tracks to assist a disabled SUV that was stalled just west of the tracks.

 

 A short time later, an Amtrak train approached. The tow truck was unable to move in time and was struck by the train. 

 

 The driver of the tow truck sustained fatal injuries and died at the scene, deputies said.

 

 The crash is under investigation

 

 At 3:35 p.m., North County Transit took to their Twitter page to also confirm the collision, tweeting: "Due to an incident on the tracks involving Amtrak, COASTER may experience a delay."

 

 One local witness said he saw the SUV on the flatbed tow truck, both stalled on the tracks. The witness said the train crossing arm dropped on the SUV and a moment later, the train slammed into the tow truck.

The witness caught the entire crash on tape. The video shows the truck driver‚Äôs door closing and then the truck turning away from the train just moments before the collision.

A witness who works across the street from the train tracks said the sound of the fatal crash was horrific.

‚ÄúIt's somewhere between an explosion and thunder. You know, when metal hits metal it makes a noise unto itself,‚Äù explained witness Thomas Neely.

The white SUV was left in place at the intersection.

Moments after the crash, people nearby tried to help and scrambled to find survivors.

One witness said the driver was ejected from his tow truck and thrown some 100 yards from the crash site. On the witness video, people seemed to cover the body of the victim while waiting for emergency crews to arrive.

‚ÄúAnybody else back there?‚Äù a person searching for survivors at the crash site says on the video.

 

 Another resident who lives near the site of the crash told NBC 7 that the impact from the collision shook his whole house.

 

 It‚Äôs unclear how fast the train was traveling at impact, but the southbound Amtrak train came to a stop about half a mile away from the Chesterfield Drive crossing.

 

 Pieces of the tow truck were strewn around the train tracks for hundreds of yards after the crash, including the flatbed, a wheel and even the massive engine block that landed about 200 yards away.

 

 Numerous workers from the company TOWEX later arrived at the scene. The towing company responds to AAA calls.

 

 The company told NBC 7 it wants to respect the privacy of the victim‚Äôs family, so his name was not released. One source confirmed the man had a wife and young daughter.

The Medical Examiner‚Äôs office will identify the victim at a later time.

 

 Most people nearby were saddened to hear that a man lost his life in the crash on the train tracks, including Neely.

 

 ‚ÄúI'm sorry to hear that a mother lost her son, especially during the holidays. There's never a good time but it's just, it's tragic,‚Äù said Neely.

 

 The two women who drove the SUV were not injured.

 

 Deputies at the scene Saturday evening were preparing to question the train‚Äôs engineer. Train services resumed later in the afternoon.

column4: Family and friends remember tow truck driver killed by train - cbs8.com
column5:
The wife of the tow truck driver killed in a train accident in Cardiff on Saturday is remembering her husband.


SAN DIEGO (CBS 8) - The wife of the tow truck driver killed in a train accident in Cardiff on Saturday is remembering her husband. 



Mayra Riddle spoke to News 8, but did not want to appear on camera. She told us her husband Shaun was the best man in the world and was dedicated to her and their baby daughter. She says Shaun would come home every night in time to feed their daughter and get her ready for bed.  



Shaun's friends are also remembering him as a great man who was always willing to lend a helping hand. 



"He taught me how to work hard and take care of my family the way I'm supposed to take care of a family, so he taught me how to be a man," friend Jonnie Brayall said. 



"He was my best friend. He definitely changed my life for sure and I'm never going to forget him. He's always going to be in my heart forever," friend Russell Frioli said. 



Shaun was hit and killed by an Amtrak train while trying to hook a vehicle stalled on the train tracks. The accident is still under investigation.
column95: Shaun was hit and killed by an Amtrak train while trying to hook a vehicle stalled on the train tracks. The accident is still under investigation.

column4: Man is fatally struck by Amtrak train - cbs8.com
column5:
An unidentified man was fatally struck by a southbound Amtrak train near Bay Park Sunday, the San Diego County Sheriff's Department reported.


SAN DIEGO (CNS) - An unidentified man was fatally struck by a southbound Amtrak train near Bay Park Sunday, the San Diego County Sheriff's Department reported. 



The fatal accident occurred at Ashton St. and Morena Blvd. around 11:14 a.m., according to the sheriff's department. 



A passenger on the train told authorities the pedestrian appeared to be standing on the tracks when he was struck by the train just before the Old Town Amtrak stop, according to a 10News report. 



Station personnel reported the train was delayed for more than an hour while sheriff's department investigated the fatal accident. 



Deputies found a man underneath the train when they arrived at the scene. The victim was pronounced dead at the scene, according to authorities. His name was withheld pending notification of next of kin.  



Amtrak train service was temporarily halt in both directions for the death investigation, a dispatcher said.
column95: An unidentified man was fatally struck by a southbound Amtrak train near Bay Park Sunday, the San Diego County Sheriff's Department reported. The fatal accident occurred at Ashton St. and Morena Blvd. around 11:14 a.m., according to the sheriff's department. A passenger on the train told authorities the pedestrian appeared to be standing on the tracks when he was struck by the train just before the Old Town Amtrak stop, according to a 10News report. Station personnel reported the train was delayed for more than an hour while sheriff's department investigated the fatal accident. Deputies found a man underneath the train when they arrived at the scene. The victim was pronounced dead at the scene, according to authorities. His name was withheld pending notification of next of kin. Amtrak train service was temporarily halt in both directions for the death investigation, a dispatcher said.

column4: Man Killed by Trolley Wore Headphones - NBC 7 San Diego
column5:
The man struck by a trolley and killed along Harbor Boulevard and Schley Street early Thursday was wearing headphones and didn't hear the train's horn, police said.

Officers investigating the death say Christopher Brian Roberts, 29, appeared to have been either on his way to work or just returning from work.

Roberts was found with the earphone wrapped around his neck according to a police spokesperson.

The accident happened directly across from the NASSCO Shipyard but there are several other businesses in the area including restaurants and auto repair shops.

There were no witnesses to the accident but officers said Roberts had to walk around the crossing arm to attempt to cross the tracks.

Trolley service was halted immediately after the accident but service was restored just after 6 a.m. with the trolley traveling past the tarp-covered body laying near the tracks.

Everyone Praying For The Family Of Olympic Medalist Who Lost His Life After Getting Hit By A Train
By Lou Flavius,
2025-05-09The rugby community is in mourning following the tragic passing of Castres Olympique winger Josaia Raisuqe.
Raisuqe, an Olympic medalist, was on his way to practice on Thursday morning when his vehicle was hit by a train. The France-based club has since confirmed the sad news.
‚ÄúCastres Olympique is in mourning.It is with heavy hearts that we learned of the death this morning of our player Josaia Raisuqe in a road accident,‚Äù Castres Olympique said in a statement published on their official website .
They added:
‚ÄúThe entire CO family is devastated by this terrible news. Josh had been a member of the club since 2021. He was a wonderful teammate, much loved by everyone, including the Castres supporters who had embraced him.
‚ÄúWe extend our sincere condolences and thoughts to his family and loved ones.
The rugby star represented Fiji in the 2024 Olympic Games in Paris, winning silver. He was only 30 years old.
Josaia Raisuqe meant a whole lot more than a great rugby player to the people of Fiji, whom he supported by giving back to. Castres Olympique president Pierre-Yves Revol described him as a ‚Äúradiant young man‚Äù and ‚Äúa pillar of the Fijian community.‚Äù
Josaia Raisuqe‚Äôs Sudden Passing Leaves Social Media In Shock
News of Josaia‚Äôs death prompted thousands of tributes from players, coaches, and fans.
‚ÄúThat is terrible news, RIP Josaia,‚Äù an X user commented.
‚ÄúJust read the story and it sounds appallingly sad. What a player as well,‚Äù added another.
‚ÄúHeartbreaking news. Rest in peace, Josaiaüôè,‚Äù said a third.
‚ÄúHeartbreaking news. Josaia Raisuqe‚Äôs loss is felt deeply by the rugby community and beyond. Sending condolences to his family, friends, and Castres Olympique. RIP,‚Äù a fan lamented.
Raisuqe had been with Castres Olympique since 2021, having played for several other clubs in France, including Stade Fran√ßais and Nevers.
He was known for his pace and powerful running and was an important player for both his club and his country.
Our hearts go out to his family in this time of mourning.
