column4: Woman struck, killed by NB Caltrain near Santa Clara station - ABC7 San Francisco
column5:
Woman struck, killed by NB Caltrain near Santa Clara station

SANTA CLARA, Calif. -- A woman was struck and killed by a northbound Caltrain in Santa Clara Saturday morning, a transit agency spokeswoman said.

Caltrain No. 423 was stopped at the Santa Clara station at 1001 Railroad Ave. due to an emergency, Caltrain officials posted on Twitter at 8:19 a.m.

Emergency crews responded to the scene and determined the incident was a collision between the train and a female pedestrian who died, Caltrain spokeswoman Jayme Ackemann said.

It appeared the woman placed herself in the train's path prior to the collision, Ackemann said.

The northbound train was carrying 125 passengers, who boarded off and transferred to the southbound platform where northbound Caltrain No. 425 was scheduled to pick them up, she said.

Two of the station's three tracks, have been cleared for trains running at restricted speeds, Ackemann said.

One of the two tracks opened is for trains heading south, according to Ackemann.

Service has been canceled on the train involved in the collision and other trains are arriving on time, Caltrain officials said.

The incident marks Caltrain's 18th fatality this year, Ackemann said.

Service has been canceled on the train involved in the collision, but other trains are arriving on time. This incident marks Caltrain's 18th fatality this year.

column4: Memorial Service for Danika Garcia, San Jose Girl Killed By VTA Train - NBC Bay Area
column5:
A memorial service and funeral for 14-year-old Danika Garcia will celebrate the life of the teen fatally struck by a Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority light-rail train last week.

 

 Danika, a freshman at Del Mar High School in San Jose, was hit while bicycling Friday around 7:35 a.m. near Stokes Street and Southwest Expressway on her way to a singing performance at her school, according to her cousin Jessica Williams.

 

 According to Williams, Danika was rushing to get to the performance on time when she was struck.

 

 Her family waited at a hospital for several hours before they were told Danika had suffered fatal injuries and lost too much blood in the accident, according to Williams.

 

 An online fundraising website has been set up to raise $10,000 to go toward funeral and memorial services.



 A memorial service will be held at 2 p.m. Sunday at the Willow Glen Funeral Home at 1039 Lincoln Ave. in San Jose. A reception will follow the service at the Fraternal Order of Eagles Hall across the street. 

 

 On Monday, a burial procession will begin at 10 a.m. at the Willow Glen Funeral Home and arrive around 11 a.m. at the Oak Hill Cemetery at 300 Curtner Ave. in San Jose.

 

 On the website, Williams wrote, "The entire family is deeply saddened by the loss of our sweet dear Danika."

 

 Danika leaves behind her parents and a brother who is in fifth grade.

 

 As of Thursday morning nearly $7,300 had been raised on the site.

 

 After the high school learned about the incident, additional grief counselors were made available to students and staff, Campbell Union High School District spokesman Michael Posey said.

 

 Support staff continues to be available for students and staff this week, he said.

 

 An informal vigil took place at the site of the crash Saturday night, which is near the school.

 

 A growing memorial with candles, teddy bears, and signs has gone on the side of the school near the train tracks in honor of Danika.

 

 Danika was hit by a northbound train on the Mountain View-Winchester line. There were 40 passengers on the train at the time of the accident, according to VTA officials.

 

 The crossing arms were down, warning lights were on and there were bells ringing at the time of the accident, transit officials said.
column59: Crossing arms were down, warning lights were on and there were bells ringing
column95: Danika Garcia, a 14-year-old freshman at Del Mar High School in San Jose, was fatally struck by a Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority light-rail train while bicycling to a singing performance at her school. The accident occurred around 7:35 a.m. near Stokes Street and Southwest Expressway. Danika was rushing to get to the performance on time when she was struck. Her family was informed of her fatal injuries and significant blood loss after several hours at the hospital. A memorial service and funeral are being held to celebrate her life, with an online fundraising campaign set up to support the costs. The crossing arms were down, warning lights were on, and bells were ringing at the time of the accident, indicating that safety measures were in place. The incident has deeply affected her family, school, and community, with additional grief counselors made available and an informal vigil held at the crash site.

column4: UPDATE: Woman Killed in Caltrain Accident Identified - Patch
column5:
Crime & Safety
UPDATE: Woman Killed in Caltrain Accident Identified
Woman was with her husband visiting family.
The Santa Clara County medical examiner's office has identified the woman killed when the car she was driving was struck by a Caltrain in Palo Alto on Friday as Judith Goldblatt.
Northbound train No. 369 struck Goldblatt's Nissan Altima rental car at Charleston Road near Alma Street at about 5 p.m. Friday, Caltrain spokeswoman Tasha Bartholomew said.
None of the 300-400 passengers aboard the train was injured.
Find out what's happening in Palo Altofor free with the latest updates from Patch.
Goldblatt, a 65-year-old resident of Indianapolis, IN, and her husband were visiting family in Palo Alto. Her husband managed to get out of the car.
San Mateo County Transit Police, a branch of the sheriff's office, did not know whether Goldblatt had attempted to escape from the car, Bartholomew said.
Find out what's happening in Palo Altofor free with the latest updates from Patch.
Caltrain service was halted in both directions after the accident, but resumed shortly before 8 p.m.
‚ÄîBay City News Service
Get more local news delivered straight to your inbox. Sign up for free Patch newsletters and alerts.
column36: Caltrain train No. 369 struck Goldblatt's Nissan Altima rental car
column95: Northbound train No. 369 struck Judith Goldblatt's Nissan Altima rental car at Charleston Road near Alma Street at about 5 p.m. Friday. None of the 300-400 passengers aboard the train was injured. Goldblatt, a 65-year-old resident of Indianapolis, IN, and her husband were visiting family in Palo Alto. Her husband managed to get out of the car. San Mateo County Transit Police, a branch of the sheriff's office, did not know whether Goldblatt had attempted to escape from the car.

column4: Tragedy on the Tracks - Morgan Hill Times
column5:
Robert Brancato cries as he kneels down in front of a memorial
While driver may face charges, friends remember the victim of
Monday night‚Äôs train accident
Morgan Hill ‚Äì Friends and co-workers of 18-year-old Jackie Gamboa gathered at a wooden cross near the railroad tracks Tuesday at San Pedro Avenue to pray and remember the radiant young woman, killed when the truck she was riding in was struck by an oncoming commuter train Monday night.
‚ÄúIf I wish I could have loved anyone, it would have been her,‚Äù said Robert Brancato, who came to the site to pay his respects to his friend.
Those who loved the petite teen all painted the same picture of her: Sweet. Happy. Beautiful.
‚ÄúShe was such a sweet, sweet girl,‚Äù said Carlota Martinez who worked with Gamboa at Fox Racing. ‚ÄúA beautiful lady.‚Äù
After learning of the death of her co-worker, Martinez and others came to the cross to grieve.
‚ÄúWe saw her yesterday. It‚Äôs very hard for us. We come to pray for her,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThis morning when we got to work we found out. We‚Äôve been crying all day for her.‚Äù
Michelle Ramirez, human resources manager, said Friday that when the announcement was made in the company about Gamboa‚Äôs death, employees were told that counseling referrals would be available if needed.
Meanwhile, Morgan Hill police are investigating the accident, which left the driver of the pick up, Morgan Hill resident Nathan Schrock, 20, in critical condition. He regained consciousness Tuesday but remains in serious but stable condition, police said Friday.
According to friends, Gamboa and Schrock had been a couple for the past three years.

The complete investigation may take months, as police wait to speak with Schrock, who witnesses say drove through warning signals and around closed gates at the crossing. The couple‚Äôs GMC Sonoma was struck by a southbound commuter train, which Schrock apparently never saw coming, police said.
Now he may face vehicle manslaughter charges for apparently attempting to beat the train across the tracks, punishable by up to six years in prison.
The incidents leading up to the tragic accident began about 7pm as Schrock headed southbound on Railroad Avenue. When he got to Tennant Avenue he saw the railroad arms down for an oncoming northbound freight train, according to police.
Schrock and a truck in front of him both made U-turns and headed back north on Railroad, apparently in an attempt to beat the northbound train to the next intersection at San Pedro Avenue, police said.
When they arrived the gates were down, police said, and Schrock was behind the other truck at the crossing.
Witnesses told police that he apparently became impatient and drove around the pickup in front of him and around the railroad arms. The driver of the first pickup yelled for Schrock to stop. A second train heading southbound saw the pickup and tried to stop, but plowed through the truck, splitting it in half. The bed of the truck ended up 150 feet down the rails.
Gamboa was ejected from the truck and pronounced dead at the scene. Schrock suffered serious trauma to the head and a gash to the thigh. He was flown to Regional Medical Center in San Jose.
Police are waiting for toxicology and alcohol reports for Schrock, which may take several weeks.
‚ÄúObviously, he is a big part of the investigation, and we cannot interview him when he is medicated or in any kind of altered state of consciousness,‚Äù said Cmdr. Joe Sampson of the Morgan Hill Police Department. ‚ÄúThis is very sad. Two young lives have really been destroyed. He will have to live forever with this.‚Äù
Once he is interviewed and test results are available, a full report will be given to the District Attorney‚Äôs office which will determine whether or not to press manslaughter charges. Passing through activated railroad warning signs is illegal.
The engineer is being provided with counseling services. Rail traffic was stopped until the train was released about 10pm.
‚ÄúThis is just an unfortunate and tragic error in judgment in the part of this young man,‚Äù Sampson said.
Family members consoled each other Tuesday and declined to speak with the reporters for South Valley Newspapers, saying that the matter was private.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a tragedy,‚Äù friends said as they gathered on the sidewalks of the Gamboa home. They erected a large wooden cross with pictures of the beautiful young woman at various stages of her young life. It was later placed at the San Pedro Avenue crossing.
News of Gamboa‚Äôs death caused staff members to break into tears at Mount Madonna Continuation High School, where she graduated last year.
Journalism teacher Marina Campos grew very close with Gamboa during her senior year.
‚ÄúI want to give my condolences to the family,‚Äù she said clasping a tissue. ‚ÄúShe was like a shining light ‚Ä¶ She was radiant ‚Ä¶ She was just that one student you just won‚Äôt forget. I won‚Äôt forget. You won‚Äôt forget her face, you just won‚Äôt forget her smile.‚Äù
Campos described a student eager to please her teachers, making sure she did the job right ‚Äì a woman whose personality was bigger than her petite frame.
‚ÄúThe essence of her beauty was just the type of person she was,‚Äù Campos said. ‚ÄúI am just shocked. This is probably the second time in my career that I can really feel the pain ‚Äì and it‚Äôs not easy. I feel very much for the family. I would tell her, ‚ÄòJackie ‚Äì I love you,‚Äô And I meant it. I meant it every time.‚Äù
Gamboa worked in the front office with Mt. Madonna staff and was close to former Principal John Perales, who met frequently with her and her mother to work with her towards reaching her goal of graduating.
She spoke of one day attending junior college.
‚ÄúHer boyfriend I know, was a big part of her life,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI just remember her passion for life. She just loved spending time with her family and friends. We spent a lot of time together dreaming and justifying why she was working so hard,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNothing was impossible for Jackie. She could conquer the world tomorrow.‚Äù
column95: The accident involved a pick-up truck driven by Nathan Schrock, who attempted to beat a northbound train to the next intersection at San Pedro Avenue. The truck was struck by a southbound commuter train, resulting in the death of Jackie Gamboa and serious injuries to Schrock. The incident occurred around 7pm, and the train was unable to stop in time after seeing the truck.

column4: Crash with Train Injures Motorist, 63, on Old Chittenden Rd near Hwy 129 in Santa Cruz County - The Legal Examiner
column5:
Santa Cruz County, CA ‚Äî A collision between a train and a car on Monday afternoon, June 17, 2024, has left a woman with minor injuries, according to KSBW.
California Highway Patrol (CHP) officials stated that the crash occurred around 1:45 PM on Old Chittenden Road near Highway 129. A 63-year-old woman from Watsonville driving a white Honda Fit was traveling north on a private road close to Old Chittenden Road. Simultaneously, a train was heading west on the tracks just ahead of her vehicle.
For reasons yet to be determined, the car and the train collided. Fortunately, the driver sustained only minor injuries and was promptly taken to a nearby hospital by ambulance for medical evaluation and treatment. None of the passengers or crew members on the train were injured in the crash.
The CHP is actively investigating the cause of the accident. Preliminary assessments indicate that drugs and alcohol do not appear to be contributing factors.
Personal Injury Claims
Determining fault in a collision can hinge on various factors, and in California, partial liability can be assigned to multiple parties. Assisting in establishing legal liability is one of the key roles that a personal injury attorney can fulfill for victims recovering from a traffic accident.
Suppose it is determined that the actions of another contributed toward the injuries. In that case, victims may qualify to file a personal injury claim with the insurance provider of those responsible. Such a claim can offer compensation to help offset hospital expenses, burial costs, and the loss of income from taking time off work for recovery.
Martin Gasparian is the founder of Maison Law, a California Personal Injury Law Firm. Martin is a graduate of Georgetown University Law School and has been practicing law in California 2004. His practice focuses on helping injury victims know their rights and recover just compensation.

None of the passengers or crew members on the train were injured. The CHP is investigating the cause of the accident, and preliminary assessments indicate that drugs and alcohol do not appear to be contributing factors.

column4: Updated: Fatal Amtrak train vs. vehicle accident - KTVL
column5:
[UPDATE: 1:07 PM]

The report of a crash between a car and an Amtrak train came in just before 8:30 a.m. Tuesday.

After a preliminary investigation, the Siskiyou County Sheriff's Office has released a statement, noting that the "a vehicle, operated by a driver allegedly observed driving at a high-rate of speed prior to the collision, was southbound on US 97 when the vehicle ran through the crossing gate and collided with the train‚Äôs engine."

The car had caught fire after the initial impact from the crash. The driver was pronounced dead at the scene. A dog was also found in the car after fire department personnel put out the flames. Authorities are withholding the man's identity until next of kin can be notified.



SCSO adds that all railroad crossing arm barriers and signals were working at the time of the incident.

The railway crossing is located just north of Railroad Ave, at US Hwy 97 in Dorris, California.

The SCSO worked in conjunction with the local Dorris Volunteer Fire Department, California Highway Patrol, CAL TRANS, and CAL FIRE.

KTVL

____________________________________



[UPDATE 9:20 AM] Amtrak has released the following statement:

On September 25, a vehicle obstructing the tracks in Dorris, California came into contact with Amtrak Coast Starlight train 14 on its way from Los Angeles to Seattle. There are no injuries to the approximately 210 passengers or crew members on board and the train has been delayed for approximately 25 minutes. Amtrak Police are cooperating with local law enforcement to investigate the incident.

Amtrak continues to work closely with Operation Lifesaver (OLI) to communicate the dangers of grade crossings. According to OLI, each year approximately 2,000 people are killed or injured in grade crossing and trespassing incidents nationwide. To raise public awareness in every community about staying off the tracks, we are collaborating with Operation Lifesaver. This collaborative national railroad safety initiative is one of several events scheduled during Rail Safety Week, which is being conducted this week from Sept. 23 ‚Äì 29.

_______________________________________

California Highway Patrol has confirmed that one person is dead following an accident involving an Amtrak train.

The train hit the car within Dorris city limits.

There are no injuries to the passengers on the train.

This is a developing story.

column4: Suisun City Train Collision Kills Pedestrian - sacramentoinjuryattorneysblog.com
column5:
Suisun City Train Collision Kills Pedestrian
Pedestrian Killed in Suisun City Train Collision Near Main Street
A Suisun City train collision on the Capitol Corridor route caused significant service disruptions on the evening of May 7. According to the Amtrak train status map, train 540, heading toward Sacramento, was halted just east of the Suisun-Fairfield station due to a service disruption on the tracks when a pedestrian was struck and killed.
Passengers Switched to Alternative Following Suisun City Train Collision
Capitol Corridor spokespersons reported shortly before 7:30 p.m. that arrangements were being made for passengers on Train 540 to transfer to an alternative train in Suisun City. The disruption follows an ongoing investigation at the collision scene, and exact details remain unclear. The Suisun City Police Department confirmed they are investigating the incident involving the death and noted that they will provide more information as it becomes available.
Railway Negligence and Legal Responsibility
Railway companies must follow regulations and perform routine maintenance to ensure the safety of vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians who may cross their tracks. Failure to fulfill this responsibility can lead to a Suisun City train collision that results in property damage, severe injuries, or even fatalities. Instances of railway negligence can create grounds for holding railroad companies accountable in the event of a train collision with another vehicle.
- Safety: Railroads and their employees are responsible for adhering to all safety regulations when operating on the tracks. Taking safety precautions at railroad crossings is vital, and railroads can be held liable for any damages or injuries caused by employees who fail to follow these standards.
- Maintenance and Repair: Proper maintenance of tracks and crossings is essential to prevent accidents such as derailments and collisions. Rail companies may be held responsible for damages resulting from train collisions if they neglect to maintain their infrastructure.
- Train Collisions Involving Pedestrians and Vehicles: To ensure safety, it is crucial for railroads to properly maintain crossings and tracks, as well as for individuals to exercise caution when crossing railroad intersections to avoid a Suisun City train collision. Failure by the owner of the tracks and crossings to do so can result in liability for the railroad company in case of accidents or injuries.
Seeking Justice After a Fatal Train Accident
Losing a loved one in a train collision is a devastating experience, and it is crucial to seek legal assistance promptly to ensure accountability for the damages. Consulting with a personal injury attorney can provide valuable guidance and help protect your rights. To recover financial losses and secure compensation for the emotional and psychological impact, families may consider filing a wrongful death claim.
Attorney Ed Smith shares insights to help you better understand wrongful death claims below:
Train Accident Wrongful Death Lawyers
I‚Äôm Ed Smith, a Fairfield wrongful death lawyer. If you have lost a loved one in a Suisun City train collision, our team of compassionate attorneys is here to help. We offer free and friendly advice to guide you through this difficult time. You can contact us at (916) 921-6400 or (800) 404-5400, or reach out to us online. We can provide a no-obligation case review, answer your questions, and discuss whether your family may pursue a wrongful death lawsuit to seek compensation for your loss.
Why Choose Our Injury Lawyers
Our injury lawyers have a proven track record of helping clients secure fair compensation for their cases. You can learn more about our achievements by exploring the following resources: Settlements and Verdicts, Yelp, and Avvo. These links provide insight into the dedication and results our team consistently delivers for clients.
We are also honored to be members of prestigious legal associations that highlight our commitment to excellence. These memberships include Top 1 Percent and Million Dollar Advocates. Being part of these organizations motivates us to maintain the highest quality of service and achieve the best outcomes for those we represent.

column4: Pedestrian killed by train on Capitol Corridor route in Suisun City - CBS News
column5:
CBS News Sacramento
Live




SUISUN CITY ‚Äî Suisun City police said a pedestrian was hit and killed by a train Wednesday evening.The collision with the pedestrian happened in the area of Sunset and Railroad avenues.The Intercity Rail Map, which shows the status of Amtrak trains, shows Train 540 on the Capitol Corridor route heading from Oakland to Sacramento was stopped due to a service disruption, just east of the Suisun-Fairfield station.Amtrak said Thursday that the collision happened around 5:50 p.m. and involved "an individual who was trespassing on the tracks."Solano County officials have identified the individual as 46-year-old Suisun City resident Jacqueline Roofner.


A spokesperson for the Capitol Corridor service said arrangements were made for passengers of the 540 train to transfer to a different train.Suisun City police said they would release more details when they are available.

Richard  Ramos


Richard Ramos is a web producer for CBS Sacramento who was born and raised in Sacramento. He graduated with a BA in Journalism from CSUS.
column95: A pedestrian was hit and killed by a train in Suisun City. The collision occurred around 5:50 p.m. on Wednesday evening at the intersection of Sunset and Railroad avenues. The individual involved was identified as 46-year-old Jacqueline Roofner, a resident of Suisun City. The train involved was Amtrak Train 540 on the Capitol Corridor route, which was stopped due to a service disruption just east of the Suisun-Fairfield station. The pedestrian was trespassing on the tracks at the time of the incident. Suisun City police are handling the investigation and will release more details when available.

OF COURSE, NOT ONLY SIGNIFYING THAT THERE IS NOT A POPE, BUT ALSO WE KNOW THE BALLOTS THEMSELVES ARE BURNED RIGHT BEFORE THEY ARE BURNED. IS EVERYONE IN THE ROOM? IS YOU UNDERSTANDING THAT THEY KNOW WHAT THE NUMBERS ARE AT THAT POINT? THEY DO. THERE ARE THREE CARDINALS WHO COUNT THE BALLOTS. THEY‚ÄôRE CALLED SCRUTINEERS. AND THE THIRD ONE ANNOUNCES THE WHO THE VOTE IS FOR AND KEEPS THE SCORECARD. AND THEN THERE ARE THREE OTHER CARDINALS THAT VERIFY THE COUNT TO MAKE SURE IT‚ÄôS RIGHT. SO THOSE CARDINALS IN THE ROOM HAVE A VERY GOOD IDEA OF WHO GOT THE MOST BALLOTS ON THE FIRST VOTE. AND NOW I THINK WHAT HAPPENS OVER DINNER AND AT BREAKFAST TOMORROW IS A DISCUSSION ABOUT WHERE THE VOTES ARE GOING TO GO IN THE SECOND BALLOT, WHO‚ÄôS GOT WHO‚ÄôS GOT MOMENTUM OR WHERE THE MOMENTUM COULD BE. BUT IN A SUPERMAJORITY VOTING SYSTEM LIKE THIS WHERE YOU NEED TWO THIRDS TO WIN. ONE OTHER THING TO ADD TO WHAT ANNE JUST SAID, INDIVIDUAL CARDINALS ARE KEEPING THEIR OWN SCORECARDS. NOW. THEY‚ÄôRE SUPPOSED TO HAVE THOSE DESTROYED BEFORE THEY THEY LEAVE, BUT YEAH. NO, I THINK TOMORROW MORNING THEY‚ÄôLL HAVE A MUCH BETTER IDEA OF WHAT THE CORRELATION OF FORCES, IF I MAY SAY SO. LIKE THAT IS. ALL RIGHT. LET ME GO BACK TO SAINT PETER‚ÄôS SQUARE. MOLLY IS STANDING BY THERE WITH THE CROWDS. THOUSANDS WHO PACKED IN FOR A VIEW OF A LARGE JUMBOTRON THERE IN FRONT OF THE BASILICA, SHOWING FOCUS ON THAT CHIMNEY. MOLLY. LESTER. VATICAN NEWS TELLS US THAT ABOUT 30,000 PEOPLE WERE HERE. I‚ÄôVE GOT TO SAY, AFTER THAT NEWS CAME OUT, IT LOOKED LIKE PEOPLE WERE STILL STREAMING IN. SO NOW YOU CAN SEE EVERYONE‚ÄôS LEAVING. IT WAS ABSOLUTELY PACKED. AND BEING HERE JUST ABOUT A WEEK AND A HALF AGO, WITH ABOUT 250,000 PEOPLE, THERE WAS STILL ROOM TO MOVE AROUND AND THERE WAS A LOT OF JOY. EVERYONE WAS VERY RESPECTFUL TONIGHT. AND AGAIN, WE SPOKE ABOUT THIS EARLIER, LESTER. BUT THIS KIND OF COMMUNAL ATMOSPHERE, THOUGH, FOR TOURISTS WHO WERE JUST CURIOUS, WHO HAPPENED TO BE ON VACATION FOR PEOPLE THAT FLEW DIRECTLY OVER FOR THIS, FOR PEOPLE THAT LIVE HERE IN ROME WHO KIND OF HEARD EARLIER THE ANNOUNCEMENTS, HEARD THE SINGING COMING OUT FROM THESE JUMBOTRONS AND WERE CALLED TO THE SQUARE. IT WAS THIS UNBELIEVABLE EXPERIENCE TO BE OUT HERE, VERY DIVERSE, LOTS OF DIFFERENT LANGUAGES, LOTS OF DIFFERENT FLAGS THAT WE STARTED TO SEE. LESTER. AND WE ARE KEEPING OUR EYES OUT, OF COURSE, FOR LITTLE POCKETS, KIND OF NATIONAL POCKETS POPPING UP WITH FLAGS. PEOPLE WERE CHANTING. THE OTHER THING WE NOTICED TONIGHT IS THAT OCCASIONALLY SOMEONE WOULD GET EXCITED SOMEWHERE IN THE CROWD, AND SOME APPLAUSE WOULD BREAK OUT, OR SOMEONE WOULD POINT AT THE CHIMNEY OR IN THE DIRECTION OF THE CHIMNEY, AND IT MIGHT HAVE JUST BEEN A BIRD, BUT PEOPLE WERE GETTING JUMPY BY THE KIND OF THREE HOUR MARK. LESTER. YEAH, WAITING. I THINK WE WERE ALL A BIT CURIOUS AS TO WHAT‚ÄôS TAKING THEM SO LONG. AND IF THERE IS NO POPE ELECTED ON THE FIRST BALLOT IN THE MORNING, THEY WON‚ÄôT BURN THAT UNTIL THE SECOND BALLOT HAPPENS. AND THEN THEY‚ÄôLL BURN BOTH OF THOSE TOGETHER. THE SENIOR CARDINAL DEACON, WHO‚ÄôS CARDINAL DOMINIQUE MAMBERTI, WOULD GIVE AND WOULD ADDRESS THE WHOLE GROUP. THERE WOULD BE A WHOLE DAY FOR PEOPLE TO TALK TO EACH OTHER AND SEE WHAT THEY WANT TO DO, AND THEN THEY‚ÄôD PICK UP THE VOTING AGAIN ON MONDAY. BUT WE HAVEN‚ÄôT GOTTEN THERE IN PREVIOUS NO REASON. column4: Fairfield Amtrak Train Collision Causes Fatality and Injuries - sacramentoinjuryattorneysblog.com
column5:
Fatality and Injuries Occur in Amtrak Train Collision at East Tabor Avenue

An Amtrak train collision occurred with a motor vehicle in Fairfield on April 26, resulting in one fatality and injuries. The accident happened at about 8:39 a.m. at the East Tabor and Railroad Avenues crossing. Authorities with the Fairfield Fire Department reported that the vehicle that was struck by the train initially hit another car, resulting in major damage.

Investigation Underway to Determine Cause of Train Collision

One person died in the collision, while several others suffered major to moderate injuries and were transported to trauma centers for treatment. The accident is being investigated to determine fault and how it occurred.

Negligent Railroads Can Cause Motor Vehicle Collisions

When operating on tracks, railroads are required to obey regulations and perform regular maintenance to protect vehicles, bicyclists, and pedestrians that may cross. Upon failing to do this, they may cause serious accidents that can damage property, cause injury and even result in death. Railway negligence can result in several ways of holding railroads responsible in a train crash with another vehicle:

Equipment defects: Railroads are responsible for ensuring their equipment, such as brakes, tracks, couplings and engines, are in proper working order. Railroads can be liable for train crashes caused by defective equipment if they fail to perform maintenance or use old, outdated machinery or parts.

Track maintenance resulting in negligence: Railroads are responsible for properly maintaining tracks to ensure they are free of debris or other hazards that might cause an oncoming train to collide. In addition, worn tracks can lead to a train collision or derailment, so maintenance and repair are especially important. Rail companies can be held liable for damages resulting from train-vehicle collisions if they fail to maintain their tracks and crossings properly.

Safety: Taking safety precautions when passing through railroad crossings and following all safety regulations is the responsibility of railroads and their employees when operating on the tracks. Railroads are liable for damages or injuries caused by employees who fail to do so.

Wrongful Death Claims After a Train Accident

In the event of the death of a loved one in a train collision, you should seek legal help as soon as possible so everyone is held accountable for the damages. Your case can be evaluated by a personal injury attorney who will fight for your rights. To recover financial losses and receive compensation for emotional and psychological trauma, the family may wish to file a wrongful death claim.

If an accident attorney determines that negligence by the railway company or others was the cause of death, the family of a deceased loved one can file a wrongful death claim. A person or entity must be proven to have caused the untimely death through negligence. It is possible for the estate administrator or members of the immediate family to file a claim. However, only one claim may be filed. If you would like more information, please do not hesitate to contact our office.

Amtrak Train Accident Lawyer

I am Ed Smith. I‚Äôm an Amtrak train accident lawyer. You may benefit from our free and friendly advice if you have lost a loved one or someone in your family has been injured in a train crash. If you have questions, please call us at (916) 921-6400 or (800) 404-5400. Additionally, you can reach us online.

See how our injury lawyers got fair compensation for our clients by clicking the links below:

The following associations make us proud to be a member:

column4: Amtrak train, vehicle involved in crash in Fairfield; 1 dead, several people hurt - CBS News
column5:
Amtrak train, vehicle involved in crash in Fairfield; several people hurt 






















Amtrak train, vehicle involved in crash in Fairfield; several people hurt
00:23




FAIRFIELD ‚Äì One person was killed after a crash involving a vehicle and a train in Fairfield on Wednesday morning.¬†The scene is near E. Tabor and Railroad avenues.An eastbound Amtrak train struck a vehicle near the intersection, Fairfield Fire says. The vehicle suffered major damage -- with the ricochet sending it into a second vehicle.¬†Several people were taken to the hospital with injuries ranging from moderate to major, firefighters say. One person has died from their injuries, Fairfield police said.¬†About 120 people, including passengers and crew, were on board the train but no injuries were reported to them.


Due to the crash, E. Tabor Avenue was closed between Clay Bank and Tolenas roads. Officials had reopened the road by early Wednesday afternoon.¬†The name of the person killed has not been released.¬†

CBS13  Staff


The CBS13 Staff is a group of experienced journalists who bring you the content on CBSSacramento.com.
column95: Amtrak train, vehicle involved in crash in Fairfield; several people hurt. One person was killed after a crash involving a vehicle and a train in Fairfield on Wednesday morning. The scene is near E. Tabor and Railroad avenues. An eastbound Amtrak train struck a vehicle near the intersection, Fairfield Fire says. The vehicle suffered major damage -- with the ricochet sending it into a second vehicle. Several people were taken to the hospital with injuries ranging from moderate to major, firefighters say. One person has died from their injuries, Fairfield police said. About 120 people, including passengers and crew, were on board the train but no injuries were reported to them. Due to the crash, E. Tabor Avenue was closed between Clay Bank and Tolenas roads. Officials had reopened the road by early Wednesday afternoon. The name of the person killed has not been released.

column4: Napa activist Jennifer Simi dies in car-train collision in Fairfield - The Napa Valley Register
column5:
Support local news coverage and the people who report it by subscribing to the Napa Valley Register.
The collision occurred at about 9:15 a.m. Wednesday on a track owned by Union Pacific Railroad, and involved an Amtrak train on the Capitol Corridor service heading northeast from San Jose to Sacramento, according to Kelly Just, an Amtrak spokesperson.
Train 524 on the Capitol Corridor struck a vehicle that was obstructing the track, and that vehicle in turn struck a second vehicle, she said Friday. It was not immediately clear which vehicle Simi was in at the time of the collision.
Several other people were hospitalized after the crash with injuries ranging from major to moderate, CBS affiliate KOVR-TV of Sacramento reported.
No injuries were reported among the train crew or the estimated 120 passengers, according to Just.
The wreck occurred at East Tabor Road and Railroad Avenue, and caused closures of both roads that lasted several hours, police said in a news release. The Amtrak train was delayed by nearly three hours, Just said.
YOUNTVILLE ‚Äî When the first Rock the Ride fundraiser to end gun violence was held last summer, the Napa Valley community was still reeling fro‚Ä¶
Simi rose to local prominence in the Napa Valley in the wake of Donald Trump‚Äôs 2016 election as president, which led her and three others to form Rise Up Napa in response to what they described as a rising threat of racism and intolerance.
‚ÄúWe have a president who doesn‚Äôt represent our beliefs,‚Äù she told the Napa Valley Register during a December 2016 march Rise Up Napa organized in downtown Napa against the then president-elect. ‚ÄúI realized complacency is no longer an option. We have to get off our couches and out of our houses and organize to stand up for what we believe. This is not politics as usual.‚Äù
Simi also was a member of the Napa chapters of the anti-gun-violence group Moms Demand Action, Indivisible and the Rock the Congress political action committee, according to Ermilita Bruce Gulliksen, a friend, neighbor and fellow Rise Up Napa co-founder.
A pair of attacks that killed Napa County residents ‚Äî the March 2018 Pathway Home shooting in Yountville and a mass shooting that November in Thousand Oaks in which the Napa native Alaina Housley and 12 others died ‚Äî moved Simi to urge quicker action against ‚Äúthe onslaught of gun violence ‚Ä¶ in our community and in our country,‚Äù she said during the Rock the Ride benefit in 2019 to fundraise for groups battling gun violence.
Lilea Heine, a former neighbor of Simi‚Äôs in Browns Valley and the executive director of First 5 Napa Valley, recalled the support Simi lent her and others involved in Rise Up Napa and Moms Demand Action.
‚ÄúShe was so comforting, reminding me of our work to shape the world we want for our kids and for our community,‚Äù said Heine, who first came to know Simi when both were serving as volunteer escorts for Planned Parenthood clinic visitors. ‚ÄúShe was a great comfort during our time (together).‚Äù (Heine is a member of the Napa Valley Register‚Äôs editorial board.)
Later Thursday, Bruce Gulliksen reflected on the loss not only of a comrade-in-arms in political activism, but also of a neighbor and loyal friend.
‚ÄúShe was so personable. She would just know you from the first time you met her; she‚Äôd find something you had and find something to connect with you,‚Äù she said of Simi. ‚ÄúShe was just beaming positivity; she was always a great relationship kind of a person.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm still in shock,‚Äù said Bruce Gulliksen. ‚ÄúEveryone who knows her is still in shock. She was gone too soon. She had so much life to live.‚Äù
Simi leaves behind her husband, daughter and son, along with her parents and two sisters, according to Bruce Gulliksen.
Photos: Napa Valley Faces and Places, April 23, 2023
Evacuation orders and warnings remained in effect Friday morning for communities near the Pickett Fire southeast of Calistoga, which spread to 2,133 acres.
The orders by the county Office of Emergency Services require people to leave the following Genasys zones, which were previously under evacuation warnings:POP-E001-B ‚Äì south of James Creek, west of Pope Valley RoadNPA E121C ‚Äì upper third of Dutch Henry Canyon RoadNPA E122B ‚Äì north of Friesen Drive

column95: The collision occurred at about 9:15 a.m. Wednesday on a track owned by Union Pacific Railroad, and involved an Amtrak train on the Capitol Corridor service heading northeast from San Jose to Sacramento. Train 524 on the Capitol Corridor struck a vehicle that was obstructing the track, and that vehicle in turn struck a second vehicle. Several other people were hospitalized after the crash with injuries ranging from major to moderate. No injuries were reported among the train crew or the estimated 120 passengers. The wreck occurred at East Tabor Road and Railroad Avenue, and caused closures of both roads that lasted several hours. The Amtrak train was delayed by nearly three hours.

column4: Deadly crash involving train, vehicle under investigation between Dixon and Davis - CBS News
column5:
SOLANO COUNTY ‚Äì An investigation is underway after a deadly crash involving a train and a vehicle between Dixon and Davis Tuesday morning.

The crash happened just after 9:30 a.m. near Tremont and Robben roads.

ALERT UPDATE: Train 531 is currently stopped west of Davis (DAV) due to a vehicle incident. We will provide an update as more information becomes available. #CapitolCorridor ‚Äî Capitol Corridor (@CapitolCorridor) April 4, 2023

California Highway Patrol's Solano division confirmed that at least one person has died.

Exactly what led up to the crash is not clear, but Amtrak says one of their trains with 62 people on board was involved. None of the people on board were hurt, Amtrak says.

Capitol Corridor is warning riders that Train 531 is stopped west of Davis due to the incident. Trains 544, 543 and 540 have been canceled, the service says; riders are being transferred to alternative transportation.

It's unclear how long the tracks will be blocked.

No other details have been released.
column95: An investigation is underway after a deadly crash involving a train and a vehicle between Dixon and Davis Tuesday morning. The crash happened just after 9:30 a.m. near Tremont and Robben roads. California Highway Patrol's Solano division confirmed that at least one person has died. Exactly what led up to the crash is not clear, but Amtrak says one of their trains with 62 people on board was involved. None of the people on board were hurt, Amtrak says. Capitol Corridor is warning riders that Train 531 is stopped west of Davis due to the incident. Trains 544, 543 and 540 have been canceled, the service says; riders are being transferred to alternative transportation. It's unclear how long the tracks will be blocked. No other details have been released.

column4: At least one person dead after crash between vehicle and Amtrak train south of Davis - Sacramento Bee
column5:
Amtrak Capitol Corridor Train 531 was stopped on railroad tracks south of Davis and north of Dixon, California, following a fatal incident involving a vehicle Tuesday morning, April 4, 2023.
    
    
        
        
            Courtesy of Bob Salladay

At least one person was killed after a collision between an Amtrak Capitol Corridor train and a vehicle Tuesday morning on railroad tracks south of Davis, authorities said.The crash happened near Tremont and Robben roads in Solano County, at a railroad crossing just east of Interstate 80 and northeast of Dixon city limits, according to an entry on the California Highway Patrol‚Äôs online activity log. The Solano County Sheriff‚Äôs Office was dispatched for at least one fatality, according to the CHP log.A vehicle struck Train 531 of Amtrak‚Äôs Capitol Corridor line about 9:20 a.m., Amtrak spokeswoman Olivia Irvin said in an emailed statement. Train 531 runs from Sacramento to Oakland on weekday mornings, and Tuesday‚Äôs incident happened between the train‚Äôs Davis and Fairfield stops. ‚ÄúThe locomotive separated from the passenger cars on the train, but no major damage occurred to the equipment,‚Äù Irvin wrote. ‚ÄúCustomers will be transferred to alternative transportation to get to their intended destination.‚ÄùAn alert on the Amtrak website as of 11:30 a.m. said the train‚Äôs route has been canceled for the rest of the day due to the ‚Äúvehicle incident.‚ÄùNo passengers or crew members were injured, Irvin said. There were 62 people on the train at the time of the incident.Video taken from the train showed the passenger cars were separated from the engine car on opposite sides of a crossing at Tremont and Robben. Both appeared to remain on the tracks.This story was originally published April 4, 2023 at 10:46 AM.

Michael McGough

The Sacramento Bee



Michael McGough is a sports and local editor for The Sacramento Bee. He previously covered breaking news and COVID-19 for The Bee, which he joined in 2016. He is a Sacramento native and graduate of Sacramento State.
column95: Amtrak Capitol Corridor Train 531 was stopped on railroad tracks south of Davis and north of Dixon, California, following a fatal incident involving a vehicle Tuesday morning, April 4, 2023. At least one person was killed after a collision between an Amtrak Capitol Corridor train and a vehicle Tuesday morning on railroad tracks south of Davis, authorities said. The crash happened near Tremont and Robben roads in Solano County, at a railroad crossing just east of Interstate 80 and northeast of Dixon city limits, according to an entry on the California Highway Patrol‚Äôs online activity log. The Solano County Sheriff‚Äôs Office was dispatched for at least one fatality, according to the CHP log. A vehicle struck Train 531 of Amtrak‚Äôs Capitol Corridor line about 9:20 a.m., Amtrak spokeswoman Olivia Irvin said in an emailed statement. Train 531 runs from Sacramento to Oakland on weekday mornings, and Tuesday‚Äôs incident happened between the train‚Äôs Davis and Fairfield stops. ‚ÄúThe locomotive separated from the passenger cars on the train, but no major damage occurred to the equipment,‚Äù Irvin wrote. ‚ÄúCustomers will be transferred to alternative transportation to get to their intended destination.‚Äù An alert on the Amtrak website as of 11:30 a.m. said the train‚Äôs route has been canceled for the rest of the day due to the ‚Äúvehicle incident.‚Äù No passengers or crew members were injured, Irvin said. There were 62 people on the train at the time of the incident. Video taken from the train showed the passenger cars were separated from the engine car on opposite sides of a crossing at Tremont and Robben. Both appeared to remain on the tracks.

column4: 1 dead in fiery crash involving Amtrak train, vehicle near Vacaville - CBS News
column5:
1 dead in fiery crash involving Amtrak train, vehicle near Vacaville 






















1 dead in fiery crash involving Amtrak train, vehicle near Vacaville
00:15




SOLANO COUNTY ‚Äì A fiery crash involving a vehicle and an Amtrak train has left one person dead near Vacaville early Thursday afternoon. The Vacaville Fire Protection District says they responded to the scene near California Pacific and Elmira roads just before 12:30 p.m. Crews found a vehicle fully engulfed after the crash.¬†
California Highway Patrol has since confirmed one person in the vehicle died; no one else was in the vehicle, officers say. The train crossing arms were down when the vehicle was hit.¬†Due to the crash, train traffic on the Capitol Corridor is delayed. Train 532 is holding in Fairfield-Vacaville, Capitol Corridor says, while Train 543 is being delayed from departing Sacramento.Amtrak released a statement Thursday afternoon saying more than a hundred people were on board the train and they were investigating the incident with authorities.On January 19, Amtrak train 541 was traveling from Sacramento to San Jose at approx. 12:40 when a vehicle obstructing the track came into contact with the train in Elmira, CA with 106 passengers onboard. Amtrak is working with local law enforcement to investigate the incident. According to the Federal Railroad Administration (FRA), trespassing along railroad rights-of-way is the leading cause of rail-related deaths in America, and railroad crossing incidents are the second leading cause of rail-related deaths in America. These incidents can affect everyone involved‚Äîthose who are injured or die and their families, our train crews, and our passengers. They also serve as critical reminders about the importance of obeying the law and of exercising extreme caution around railroad tracks and crossings. Amtrak continues to work closely with Operation Lifesaver (OLI) to #STOPTrackTragedies by emphasizing the obvious dangers of being on railroad property or disregarding warnings at rail crossings. For more railroad safety information, please visit StayOffTheTracks.org.¬†No other details about the incident have been released at this point.¬†

CBS13  Staff


The CBS13 Staff is a group of experienced journalists who bring you the content on CBSSacramento.com.

column4: Person Struck By Train In Suisun City Rushed To Hospital - CBS News
column5:
Person Struck By Train In Suisun City Rushed To Hospital
SUISUN CITY (CBS13) ‚Äî A man was left with traumatic injuries after he was struck by a train in Suisun City on Friday morning.
Suisun City Fire Department crews responded to the area of Sunset and Railroad avenues just before 6 a.m. after someone was reportedly hit by a train near the intersection. Crews eventually found the victim a couple hundred feet into Fairfield city limits.
The man's friend had tried to help him get help, apparently. First responders noted that the man had obvious traumatic injuries from the incident.
Medics rushed the man to a nearby hospital. His current condition was not stated.
Authorities say the incident should serve as a reminder to stay alert around railroad tracks.

column4: SMART train hits, kills pedestrian in Rohnert Park - CBS News
column5:
PIX Now - Morning Edition 11/3/23 






















PIX Now - Morning Edition 11/3/23
09:31




A pedestrian was struck and killed by a SMART train in Rohnert Park Thursday evening, authorities said.The collision happened at about 7:38 p.m. on Golf Course Drive between Commerce Boulevard and Roberts Lake Road. The Rohnert Park Department of Public Safety said a bystander called 911 to report the pedestrian being hit by the train.¬†Officers arrived to find the 42-year-old male pedestrian dead in the roadway. Rohnert Park DPS officers were joined by Sonoma County Sheriff's deputies and Sonoma-Marin Rail Transit personnel at the scene.¬†The DPS said it appeared that at the time of the collision, the crossing gates were down, the red lights were flashing, and warning bells and train horn were working.Further details about the circumstances of the collision were not immediately available.


The pedestrian's identity was withheld until the sheriff's office could notify the man's family members.

column4: Minivan Driver Suspected Of DUI In Collision With SMART Train - Patch
column5:
Traffic & Transit Minivan Driver Suspected Of DUI In Collision With SMART Train Police said the driver could not speak and was not alert. He was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence of prescription drugs.

The driver of this minivan is suspected of driving under the influence of prescription drugs and colliding with a SMART train Wednesday in Santa Rosa, according to police. (Santa Rosa Fire Department) A SMART train stops on the tracks near West Steele Lane in Santa Rosa after a collision Wednesday morning between a SMART train and a minivan. (Santa Rosa Fire Department)

SANTA ROSA, CA ‚Äî The driver of a minivan who collided with a SMART train Wednesday in Santa Rosa is suspected of driving under the influence of prescription drugs, Santa Rosa police said.

The crash was reported at 11:04 a.m. Wednesday on the railroad tracks at West Steele Lane, adjacent to Coffey Lane. "Initial reports indicated that after the crossing arms had lowered to stop traffic, the vehicle (a white minivan) drove through the arms and was struck by the oncoming SMART Train," Santa Rosa police Sgt. Josh Ludtke said. "The train struck the rear driver‚Äôs-side of the vehicle as it crossed the tracks, spinning it around, and it came to rest on the northwest side of the intersection."

These Are The Most Popular Dog Breeds In CA Read More

The driver of the minivan, a 57-year-old Santa Rosa man, was the only person in the car and was conscious when officers got there but he could not speak and was not alert, Ludtke said. Personnel with the Santa Rosa Fire Department responded alongside an AMR ambulance crew. Once firefighter-paramedics extricated the driver, who was trapped in the minivan, he was taken to a hospital, fire officials said.

The driver did not suffer major injuries, according to police. He was contacted by SRPD accident investigators at the hospital, where he was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence of prescription drugs, Ludtke said. Police did not disclose the driver's name.

"It appeared the vehicle had been traveling south on Coffey Lane and it had turned west onto West Steele Lane just east of the tracks," Ludtke said. "The vehicle likely drove into the opposing lane of traffic on West Steele Lane to go around the crossing arms and was struck by the train as it was clearing the intersection to continue west on West Steele Lane." No injuries were reported to anyone on the train, the Santa Rosa Fire Department said.

column4: Train suicide victim was caretaker accused of abusing disabled kids, Calif. cops say - San Luis Obispo Tribune
column5:
Suicide is on the rise across the United States. It is more than a mental health condition ‚Äî states and communities can adopt comprehensive strategies to prevent suicide.  By Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Deputies have identified a Northern California man killed on Sonoma County train tracks on Tuesday as a 68-year-old caretaker who was accused of sexually abusing disabled kids.Keith Marcum of Rohnert Park was struck by the SMART train south of Santa Rosa around 9:30 p.m., according to the Sonoma County Sheriff‚Äôs Office. Deputies said they are ‚Äúinvestigating the incident as a suicide as the train video clearly shows the man laid on the tracks in front of the train moments before impact.‚Äù The death is the third in two weeks on the Sonoma and Marin County train line north of San Francisco, which opened two years ago, according to the Santa Rosa Press Democrat.Marcum represented himself as a certified psychologist and ran an in-home care center for mentally and physically disabled children and adults in Rohnert Park for roughly 30 years, until he was arrested in April on charges of continuous child sexual abuse, sodomy, cruelty to a child and posession of child pornography, according to the Rohnert Park Department of Public Safety.Police said Marcum‚Äôs arrest came after a former resident revealed a pattern of sexual and physical abuse that began 10 years ago. Two more victims came forward following Marcum‚Äôs arrest and said they were sexually abused by Marcum as well from ages 6 to 14, according to police. Police said there could be more victims.During a search of Marcum‚Äôs home on Brenda Way in Rohnert Park, detectives discovered more than 600 images of child porn, according to police.‚ÄúDetectives called family members of the three residents who live there with Marcum to advise them of the investigation and assisted with getting them out of the house,‚Äù police said in April, adding that it was then unknown if those residents had been victims as well. Authorities booked Marcum at the Sonoma County jail, where he was held on $765,000 bail, police said. Marcum posted bail and was released, the Press Democrat reported. He was set to appear in court to face charges on July 23, according to KSRO.Sgt. Keith Astley said the investigation revealed Marcum‚Äôs clinical psychology bona fides were fraudulent, including claims that he had earned clinical psychology and neurophysiology doctorates, as well as education and cognitive psychology master‚Äôs degrees, according to the Press Democrat.‚ÄúWe never found any documentation supporting those degrees Marcum claimed to have obtained,‚Äù Astley said, according to the newspaper.Court records said Marcum was arrested in 1981 on child sexual assault allegations in Colorado, but got a deferred four-year sentence, the Press Democrat reports.Marcum wrote a goodbye post on Facebook hours before his death, per the newspaper: ‚ÄúFarewell everyone ‚Äî it‚Äôs been a wonderful life,‚Äù Marcum reportedly said.
Related Stories from  San Luis Obispo Tribune


Jared Gilmour

mcclatchy-newsroom



Jared Gilmour is a McClatchy national reporter based in San Francisco. He covers everything from health and science to politics and crime. He studied journalism at Northwestern University and grew up in North Dakota.

column4: Woman fatally struck by SMART train in Santa Rosa - ABC7 San Francisco
column5:
Woman fatally struck by SMART train in Santa Rosa

Officials said a woman was struck and killed by a SMART train in Santa Rosa Wednesday morning.

Officials said a woman was struck and killed by a SMART train in Santa Rosa Wednesday morning.

Officials said a woman was struck and killed by a SMART train in Santa Rosa Wednesday morning.

Officials said a woman was struck and killed by a SMART train in Santa Rosa Wednesday morning.

SANTA ROSA, Calif. (KGO) -- It happens to every major railroad, and SMART train is not immune.

This morning, a female was struck and killed by a Sonoma-Marin Area Rail Transit train in Santa Rosa Wednesday morning, according to a Sonoma County fire and emergency dispatcher.

The collision was reported at 7:36 a.m. in Santa Rosa at Hearn Avenue near Whitewood Drive. SMART says everything in the intersection functioned normally---the lights, the traffic arms, the horn on the train and a video camera on board that captured everything.

The train hit the victim at full speed, about 79 miles an hour, and the the body came to rest roughly 50 yards down the track.

SMART service was suspended but begin after the crash investigation.

The eastbound lane is closed, and drivers can expect long delays in both directions.

This accident comes one day after The Sonoma-Marin Area Rail Transit District announced it received more funding from the state, an estimated $10.5 million. It will help increase service because of its popularity.

Mead Clark Lumber confirms that an employee went gone home for the day after seeing the train hit this morning's female victim. They say he tells them that she made no effort to get out of the train's way. @smarttrain #abc7now pic.twitter.com/QX4YJoufwL ‚Äî Wayne Freedman (@WayneFreedman) January 31, 2018

SMART trains started rolling between Santa Rosa and San Rafael in August.

The trains have carried more than 300, 000 passengers since then, according to the district.

This may be the first fatality involving a SMART train.

Before you head out to your car, be sure to check out the ABC7 traffic maps for real-time information to help you navigate through traffic jams.

Bay City News contributed to this story.

column4: Investigation blocking train tracks in Escalon - Escalon Times
column5:
Motorists are being advised to avoid the area of the Yosemite Avenue ‚Äì Highway 120 railroad crossing in Escalon following a mid-morning train vs. pedestrian collision.

Officials said the incident occurred shortly after 10 a.m. Monday, Oct. 28, with a subject crossing the tracks on the south side of the highway. The unidentified victim was struck by a westbound freight train; authorities said the coroner was requested to the scene.

It was expected that the investigation would take a few hours and the freight train was stopped at the location, blocking traffic. A post by the Escalon Consolidated Fire Protection District about noon today indicated the closure could last for a couple more hours.

column4: Modesto woman struck, killed by Amtrak train while riding her bike, CHP says - Modesto Bee
column5:
A 49-year-old Modesto woman was killed when she was struck by an Amtrak train on Sunday night in Empire, according to the California Highway Patrol. The woman was riding a BMX bicycle west on Highway 132, just west of E Street when for ‚Äúunknown reasons‚Äù she rode around the crossing arms that blocked the highway‚Äôs intersection with the railroad, read CHP‚Äôs collision report.She crossed the railroad as the train approached, which collided with her. She was pronounced dead at the scene. No one else was injured during the collision. Highway 132 remained open during the investigation. Railways experienced ‚Äúsome delays during the investigation,‚Äù read the release. The woman‚Äôs identity had not been released as of Monday morning, pending notification of her next-of-kin. This story was originally published April 15, 2024 at 7:29 AM.

Trevor Morgan

The Modesto Bee

column4: SUV driver who died after being hit by train in Empire identified as Modesto man - Modesto Bee
column5:
A man was seriously injured after a train collided with his SUV Tuesday afternoon near Yosemite and Santa Fe avenues in Empire, the California Highway Patrol said. By Andy Alfaro
The man killed when a train collided with his SUV on Tuesday afternoon near Yosemite and Santa Fe avenues in Empire has been identified by the Stanislaus County Coroner‚Äôs Office as Rick Navarro, 60, of Modesto .The collision occurred about 3:25 p.m. Navarro was traveling west on Yosemite in a silver 2003 GMC Yukon and drove onto the tracks as the crossing arms were coming down, California Highway Patrol Officer Aaron Keller said at the scene.The Yukon stopped in the middle of the tracks, where it was broadsided by the northbound train. Navarro, who was not wearing a seat belt, was ejected from the SUV, a CHP news release says.He was taken to Memorial Medical Center. A few hours later, Clint Bray, battalion chief for the Stanislaus Consolidated Fire Protection District, confirmed Navarro had died.The CHP release said it‚Äôs not been determined if alcohol or drugs factored in the crash. This story was originally published March 10, 2021 at 9:23 AM.

Lydia Gerike

The Modesto Bee



Lydia Gerike began covering breaking news for the Modesto Bee in February 2021. She graduated from Indiana University with degrees in journalism and international studies. Lydia has previously reported as a fellow or intern at the Indianapolis Star, Hartford Courant and Oregonian.
column95: A man was seriously injured after a train collided with his SUV near Yosemite and Santa Fe avenues in Empire. The man, Rick Navarro, 60, of Modesto, was traveling west on Yosemite in a silver 2003 GMC Yukon and drove onto the tracks as the crossing arms were coming down. The Yukon stopped in the middle of the tracks, where it was broadsided by the northbound train. Navarro, who was not wearing a seat belt, was ejected from the SUV and later died. It‚Äôs not been determined if alcohol or drugs factored in the crash.

column4: Driver, passengers escape injury in train collision - Turlock Journal
column5:
A disabled vehicle stuck on the railroad tracks was hit by a train Saturday night, but fortunately there were no injuries reported from the incident.

The vehicle became disabled on the tracks at Monte Vista Avenue and Golden State Boulevard around 7 p.m. Saturday. Both the Turlock Fire and Police departments responded to the scene. Union Pacific was informed of the car on the tracks, but the train was already approaching the area and was not able to stop in time.

The occupants had all exited the car before it was struck by the train.

The incident left the train blocking the intersections at Monte Vista Avenue and Tuolumne Road for more than two hours.

column4: Oroville man killed after driving through railroad crossing in front of oncoming train - ABC10
column5:
CHP said the accident happened on Clark Road just west of Highway 99.


SUTTER COUNTY, Calif. ‚Äî A 59-year-old Oroville man was killed after driving through a railroad crossing and directly into the path of an oncoming train, California Highway Patrol said.¬† 

CHP said that at about 9:05 p.m. on Monday, the driver of a 1999 Nissan Sentra was traveling on Clark Road near Yuba City. The driver drove through the railroad crossing arms, which were down and working properly. The Oroville man was struck on by an oncoming Union Pacific train as he tried to cross the tracks, CHP said. He was ejected from the car and sadly died at the scene.¬† 

Clark Road was closed for several hours as Union Pacific crews checked the train and cars, and cleaned up debris. Traffic on Highway 99 was not affected.¬† 

CHP said that alcohol was believed to be a factor in the accident. No other details are available at this time.¬†

column4: Heartbreak in Los Molinos as Community Mourns Loss of Teen to Train Tragedy - SierraDailyNews.com
column5:
A tragic incident occurred late Wednesday night in Los Molinos when a 17-year-old girl, Olivia Freemyers, was struck and killed by a train just before midnight.

Olivia, who graduated from high school in May and planned to attend cosmetology school, lived across the train tracks with her grandparents, Luke and Melinda Freemyers. Family members say the Freemyers had raised Olivia after her mother passed away. According to the family, Olivia and her boyfriend were meeting with people who lived across the tracks when the accident occurred. Melinda had dropped them off just before sunset.

Luke Freemyers confirmed that Olivia was not under the influence of drugs or alcohol at the time of the incident, as the family had been enjoying dinner together earlier in the evening.

The Tehama County Sheriff‚Äôs Office is continuing to investigate the incident. Family and friends gathered near the train tracks on Thursday afternoon to leave flowers in memory of Olivia.

column4: Freight train smashes car, drags it and driver 100 yards - kmph.com
column5:
A freight train hit a car and pushed it down the tracks with the driver still inside on Friday.

Miraculously, the driver survived the crash but had major injuries.

The conductor of a small freight train called 911 to report the crash just after 10:00 a.m.

A California Highway Patrol Officer at the scene said the car was going north on Road 52 and the train was headed west.

For some reason, the driver didn't stop at the tracks and the train plowed into him, dragging the car for quite a distance.



Powered By 10 Sec Boots N' Booze concert happening this weekend in Madera Next Stay

CHP did get the 19-year-old male driver unpinned from the car.



This location is West of the town of Goshen, in Tulare County, on Road 52 just north of Ave 309.

column4: ‚ÄòIt doesn‚Äôt feel real‚Äô: Dinuba family mourns 29-year-old killed in stationary train crash - yourcentralvalley.com
column5:
DINUBA, Calif. (KSEE/KGPE) ‚Äì A family in Dinuba is mourning the loss of their loved one, 29-year-old Raymond Garza, after he was killed in a car accident just after 2:00 a.m. Saturday morning.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like a dream, it doesn‚Äôt feel real. He‚Äôs going to be missed‚Äù said Elsa Gonzales. ‚ÄúAt five o‚Äôclock in the morning I got a knock on my door from the sheriff‚Äôs department.‚Äù

The Tulare County Sheriff‚Äôs Office said it was just after 2 a.m. when Garza and his female passenger were traveling East on Nebraska when they slammed into a stationary train that was parked along the railroad tracks.

The female passenger suffered moderate injuries and Garza was killed on impact.

‚ÄúMy nephew was a loving person. He had a heart of gold he helped people he put others before himself‚Äù she said.

Albert DeLuna doesn‚Äôt believe his nephew saw the train. DeLuna said Nebraska Avenue is a dark road.

‚ÄúThe light‚Äôs weren‚Äôt on. He came and hit the train. Very dangerous for anybody else,‚Äù he said.

The family has set up a GoFundMe to help pay for funeral expenses.

column4: Person hit and killed by train in Tulare County - kmph.com
column5:
A person is dead after being hit by a train in the Goshen area.

The Tulare County Sheriff's Office received the call at 9:39 a.m. Wednesday about a train vs. pedestrian.

Deputies say the body was found under the Goshen overpass of Highway 99.

The conductor told Deputies he didn't see the person on the tracks.

Investigators are working to identify the person and determine if this was an accident, suicide, or something else.

Powered By 10 Sec Boots N' Booze concert happening this weekend in Madera Next Stay

The freight train was stopped on the tracks.
column95: A person was found dead under the Goshen overpass of Highway 99 after being hit by a train. The incident occurred at 9:39 a.m. on Wednesday. The conductor reported not seeing the person on the tracks. The freight train was stopped on the tracks. Investigators are working to identify the person and determine the nature of the incident.

column4: Woman dies after being struck by train - Moorpark Acorn
column5:
Arlene Stone may not have heard approaching Metrolink

A woman well known to many in the Simi Valley community died May 6 after she was struck by a Metrolink train in East Simi Valley, police said.

The victim, identified as 45-yearold

Arlene Stone, was homeless and frequently seen around the Simi Valley train station, according to residents. The Ventura County Medical Examiner‚Äôs Office determined she died of blunt head trauma. Her death was ruled an accident.

Simi Valley police said they were notified by Metrolink at 2:41 p.m. that one of its trains had struck a pedestrian along the tracks near the 5200 block of Katherine Street, behind a residential neighborhood near Katherine Elementary School.

Emergency crews from the Ventura County Fire Department responded and pronounced the woman dead at the scene.

The westbound Train 121 was en route from Chatsworth with approximately 35 passengers and crew when it hit Stone. No one aboard the train was injured.

Passengers were transferred to a bus while the train remained stopped for about three hours during the investigation.

Simi Valley Police Sgt. Rick Morton said it appeared the woman was standing too close to the tracks and may not have heard the train approaching until it was too late.

‚ÄúIt appears to be a tragic accident,‚Äù Morton said.

Following news of her death, many community members shared condolences online, recalling Stone‚Äôs familiar presence in the area.

‚ÄúRest in peace my dear niece Arlene, your whole family is heartbroken. We all loved you very much!!‚Äù a family member wrote.

‚ÄúRest in peace my friend. Your struggles are behind you,‚Äù another post read.

column4: One dead following collision involving Metrolink train, vehicle in Ventura County - KCLU
column5:
One person is dead following a collision involving a Metrolink train and a vehicle in Ventura County.

It happened at around 2 p.m. Monday near the intersection of Las Posas Road and Fifth Street in Camarillo.

The driver of the vehicle died. There were five passengers and three crew members on board the Metrolink train. No injuries were reported.

Last week, a Metrolink train and a truck collided at the intersection of Fifth Street and Rice Avenue in Oxnard, leaving a bystander seriously injured.

column4: Oxnard taco stand worker severely injured after Metrolink train, big rig collide - FOX 11 Los Angeles
column5:
A woman was hospitalized in serious condition after she was hit by debris from the crash. OXNARD, Calif. - A woman is fighting for her life at the hospital after a train and semi-truck collided in Oxnard. The victim was working as a food vendor when she was hit by flying debris from the crash.¬† 
 What we know: Officials said the crash between a Metrolink train and a semi-truck happened Tuesday night at Rice Avenue and Fifth Street around 7:15 p.m.¬†  The train was carrying over a dozen passengers. Following the crash, debris went flying and hit a taco stand where a woman was seriously hurt.¬† When first responders arrived at the scene, she was taken to an area hospital in critical condition. Officials said while severe, her injuries are not considered life-threatening.¬† Several passengers were triaged by paramedics. Three passengers were treated and released at the scene while one was hospitalized.¬† What we don't know: The name of the victim has not been released.¬† Dig deeper: A similar crash happened at the same intersection in 2015.¬† In that incident, a Metrolink engineer was killed and 30 others were injured. A truck driver from Arizona was sentenced to 30 days in jail in a plea deal.¬† The Source: Information from previous FOX 11 reports and the Oxnard Fire Department.
column95: A woman was hospitalized in serious condition after she was hit by debris from the crash. OXNARD, Calif. - A woman is fighting for her life at the hospital after a train and semi-truck collided in Oxnard. The victim was working as a food vendor when she was hit by flying debris from the crash. Officials said the crash between a Metrolink train and a semi-truck happened Tuesday night at Rice Avenue and Fifth Street around 7:15 p.m. The train was carrying over a dozen passengers. Following the crash, debris went flying and hit a taco stand where a woman was seriously hurt. When first responders arrived at the scene, she was taken to an area hospital in critical condition. Officials said while severe, her injuries are not considered life-threatening. Several passengers were triaged by paramedics. Three passengers were treated and released at the scene while one was hospitalized.

column4: 1 transported to hospital after Metrolink train hits tractor-trailer in Oxnard - Ventura County Star
column5:
1 transported to hospital after Metrolink train hits tractor-trailer in Oxnard
(This story has been updated with new information from Oxnard police.)
One person was hospitalized with critical injuries Tuesday night after a train struck a semitrailer in Oxnard.
The crash, between a Metrolink train and the big rig, was reported around 7:15 p.m. at Fifth Street and Rice Avenue, according to initial reports.
Battalion Chief John Cece√±a, with the Oxnard Fire Department, said at 7:45 p.m. that crews assessed the truck driver and two bystanders ‚Äî one working at a sidewalk vending location and a woman buying food from the vendor.
Authorities later said debris from the crash struck the patron. She was taken by ambulance to a hospital with a head injury, police officials said in a news release, and was said to be in critical but stable condition Tuesday night.
The food vendor and truck driver refused additional care, Cece√±a said.
Of the 13 passengers on the Metrolink train, two complained of pain, authorities said.
The semi had been stopped on southbound Rice when it was hit, Oxnard Police Department officials said in a release. The westbound train hit the rig's trailer.
The Metrolink train started at Los Angeles' Union Station at 5:30 p.m. It had been scheduled to arrive in Oxnard at 7:07 p.m., according to its social media and website.
Oxnard Police Cmdr. Kevin Baysinger said officers also assisted at the scene with the injured.
Because of the crash, both train and vehicle traffic in the immediate vicinity was stopped. Fifth Steet between Rose Avenue and Del Norte Boulevard was closed as were portions of Rice Avenue between Eastman Avenue and East Wooley Road, he said.
The commander said officers were investigating the collision. Alcohol didn't appear to be a factor, department officials later said.
Tuesday's crash happened at a deadly crossing where federal, state and city officials broke ground last month on a major project to build a bridge overpass.
The $134.5 million grade separation project at Rice Avenue and Fifth Street will add up to six lanes to carry vehicles, bicyclists and pedestrians over the railroad tracks.
On Feb. 24, 2015, the crossing was the scene of a fatal crash between another Metrolink train and a utility truck that got stuck on the tracks.
Anyone with information about Tuesday's collision is asked to contact traffic coordinator Cpl. Manuel Perez at 805-385-7750 or at manuel.perez@oxnardpd.org.
Stacie N. Galang is news director of the Ventura County Star. She can be reached at stacie.galang@vcstar.com or 805-437-0222.

Two passengers on the Metrolink train complained of pain. The semi was stopped on southbound Rice when hit by the westbound train. The train started at Los Angeles' Union Station at 5:30 p.m. and was scheduled to arrive in Oxnard at 7:07 p.m. The crash happened at a deadly crossing where a major project to build a bridge overpass is underway. On Feb. 24, 2015, the crossing was the scene of a fatal crash between another Metrolink train and a utility truck.

column4: Train collides with tractor-trailer in Oxnard; woman hospitalized - Ojai Valley News
column5:
A traffic collision involving a Metrolink train and a tractor trailer occurred at Rice Avenue and Fifth Street in Oxnard around 7:15 p.m. the night of Tuesday, March 25.
A Metrolink train and tractor-trailer collided at Rice Avenue and Fifth Street in Oxnard, causing one woman to be hospitalized at about 7:15 p.m. on March 25.
According to the Oxnard Police Department, the train, carrying 13 passengers, struck the trailer of a tractor-trailer as the train crossed Rice Avenue at Fifth Street. The tractor-trailer had been stopped on southbound Rice Avenue and the train was traveling westbound.
Debris from the collision struck a woman at a nearby taco stand. She was transported to a local hospital with a head injury, and was listed in critical but stable condition, according to the Oxnard Police Department.
Two passengers on the train complained of pain, and the driver of the tractor-trailer was not injured.
Alcohol did not appear to be a factor in the collision, according to the Oxnard Police Department's written statement. Traffic investigators also responded to the scene and assisted with the investigation.
The site is the same location where, in 2015, a fatal crash occurred between another Metrolink train and a utility truck that got stuck on the tracks.
The Ventura County Board of Supervisors voted in July to crack down on sidewalk vending throughout the county, which includes pop-up taco vendors on Rice Avenue.
The 20-month pilot program, costing $1.7 million, was intended to enhance roadside and traffic safety, according to Code Compliance Director Doug Leeper, who provided the supervisors with a presentation, including a video of a vehicle crashing into a food stand also in Oxnard from March 2024.
"It is an issue of safety," Leeper said at the July meeting. "Not just food-borne illness safety and food handling safety, but of personal safety as these folks stop, get out, walk along the roadway, stand and eat in some of these locations."
Rice Avenue was mentioned specifically during the meeting as the county location with the most vendors observed during the survey, also noting that none of the vending locations observed would be permittable under the ordinance.
Enforcement of the code began in November, with the hiring of a full-time senior code compliance officer, with an annual salary of between $85,068 and $119,302. Enforcement also required the staffing of a senior code compliance officer, a code compliance officer, and a technician, as well as funding for an extra-duty assignment for two senior deputies with the Sheriff‚Äôs Office.
For 2025-26, the 12-month pilot program was estimated to require $957,200.
Enforcement was intended to help respond to complaints, make proactive contact with vendors, investigate situations, issue citations and impound equipment and merchandise if it was deemed they presented a safety hazard.
Anyone with more information on the collision is encouraged to contact Corporal Manuel Perez, Oxnard Police Department traffic coordinator, at 805-385-7750 or via email at:manuel.perez@oxnardpd.org.

column4: 1 dead after train hits vehicle near Camarillo - Ventura County Star
column5:
1 dead after train hits vehicle near Camarillo
At least one person died when a Metrolink train collided with a vehicle just south of Camarillo Monday afternoon.
The California Highway Patrol responded to the crash shortly after 2 p.m. near the intersection of Fifth Street and Las Posas Road, according to initial reports. CHP's incident page lists the collision as fatal.
The man driving the SUV died at the scene, the CHP said in a news release.
A preliminary investigation indicated the man had been traveling southbound on Las Posas Road and stopped on the railroad tracks for a red light at Fifth Street. When the train approached the crossing arms and signals activated.
The SUV was still on the tracks when the train entered the crossing and struck the vehicle.
The crash, between a Metrolink train and a Lincoln SUV, at the rail crossing is the second in less than a week. On Tuesday, a train struck a tractor-trailer at Fifth Street and Rice Avenue, injuring one person who was a bystander.
Monday's crash caused closures of Los Posas Road between Fifth Street, also known as State Route 34, and Pleasant Valley Road. The force of the crash tore through the vehicle and wrapped the crossing arm around the traffic signal.
Metrolink train 118 was carrying five passengers and two crew members, said Jeanette Flores, assistant director of public affairs for Metrolink. The train, headed to Los Angeles' Union Station, was stopped after the incident, she said.
No one was injured on the train, according to the Ventura County Fire Department, which responded to the incident.
CHP said the crash is still being investigated. Anyone with additional information about the crash is asked to call the Ventura-area CHP office at 805-662-2640.
Ernesto Centeno Araujo covers breaking news for the Ventura County Star. He can be reached at ecentenoaraujo@vcstar.com.
