Medina said he felt the warning bells had not given the truck driver enough time to move out of the crossing. The truck had been carrying 37,000 pounds of strawberries.

column4: Deadly Isleton crash marks 7th fatal incident in 4 days on Sacramento-area roadways - Sacramento Bee
column5:
A 46-year-old Antioch man was killed in a solo-vehicle collision Sunday afternoon on Highway 160 in Isleton, according to the CHP.
    
    
        
            
                CHP South Sacramento
            

A man was killed in a single-vehicle collision Sunday afternoon in Isleton, according to the California Highway Patrol.Officers responded about 3:30 p.m. to a crash on southbound Highway 160 near Vieira‚Äôs Resort, where a green Dodge pickup truck had struck a tree in an embankment on the side of the roadway, the CHP South Sacramento office said in a news release.The victim has been identified by the coroner‚Äôs office as Philip Raul, 46, of Antioch.CHP did not say what caused the collision, but the news release urged drivers to travel at safe speeds in the Delta due to the area‚Äôs ‚Äúnarrow and winding levee roads.‚ÄùThe incident marks at least the seventh death resulting from seven separate collisions across the Sacramento area from last Friday through this Monday, according to the CHP and local law enforcement.An Amtrak Capitol Corridor train collided with a vehicle at a railroad crossing east of Davis, killing the sole occupant of that vehicle, the Yolo County Sheriff‚Äôs Office said in a news release. The sheriff‚Äôs office and CHP‚Äôs Woodland office are investigating the incident, and the victim has not yet been identified.CHP South Sacramento says two pedestrians were killed in separate hit-and-run incidents over the weekend, with a woman killed Saturday evening on Florin Road east of Highway 99 and a man killed Sunday morning on southbound Highway 99 near Grantline Road. The coroner‚Äôs office has identified Christine Wilbur, 34, of Sacramento, as the victim in Saturday‚Äôs incident.A 46-year-old Orangevale man riding a 2017 Ducati motorcycle died Sunday morning near Folsom Lake in El Dorado County, ejected from the vehicle after taking a curve on Salmon Falls Road at a high speed, according to the CHP Placerville office.A fatal collision occurred Monday afternoon in Folsom, near Empire Oaks Elementary School on East Natoma Street, according to the Folsom Police Department. No other details about that collision have been released.Another deadly vehicle-into-tree crash, this one involving an RV, happened about 12:20 p.m. Friday on westbound Interstate 80 near Marysville Boulevard, according to CHP North Sacramento. This story was originally published September 17, 2019 at 7:28 AM.
Related Stories from  Sacramento Bee

Michael McGough

The Sacramento Bee



Michael McGough is a sports and local editor for The Sacramento Bee. He previously covered breaking news and COVID-19 for The Bee, which he joined in 2016. He is a Sacramento native and graduate of Sacramento State.

column4: Train Crashes Into Car Left On Tracks Near Davis - CBS News
column5:
Train Crashes Into Car Left On Tracks Near Davis
DAVIS (CBS13) - A road between Davis and Sacramento is back open after a train struck a car left on the tracks early Monday morning.
The train was traveling east from Davis toward Sacramento when it struck the car around 3:30 a.m.
The car was not occupied at the time of the crash, authorities say. It's unknown at this point why the car was on the tracks.
Chiles Road, which runs along the tracks, was closed for a time while authorities investigated the scene. The road was reopened around 6:30 a.m.
column95: A train traveling east from Davis toward Sacramento struck a car left on the tracks around 3:30 a.m. The car was not occupied at the time of the crash. The reason why the car was on the tracks is unknown. Chiles Road, which runs along the tracks, was closed for a time while authorities investigated the scene. The road was reopened around 6:30 a.m.

column4: Stalled car demolished by train in Live Oak - appeal-democrat.com
column5:
The train was bearing down on her at nearly 40 mph.

The railroad crossing arms had fallen, and the warning bells were clanging ‚Äî but Mylicia Mailcoff could not move her car.

With seconds to spare, a man ran from a nearby shop and yelled at the teenager to get off the tracks. They bolted to safety moments before a northbound Union Pacific Railroad train demolished her Honda Civic to warped metal and shattered glass.

East-west traffic was cut off around Pennington Road and other nearby Live Oak railroad crossings for more than an hour Friday as the wreck was investigated and cleared. The Pennington crossing reopened at 4:45 p.m.

Mailcoff, 18, was driving east on Pennington Road but was stopped on the tracks because of cars backed up to the traffic signal at Highway 99.

When the light turned green, she tried to drive forward, but her car stalled and she could not start it again, said Sutter County sheriff's Deputy Adrian Perez.

A boy ran to help her, but they could not drive or push the car off the tracks, Perez said.

The Union Pacific Railroad conductor, whose name was not released, tried to slow down about one-half mile before the crash but was unable to avoid the wreck, Perez said. No one was injured in the crash.

Rudy Heredia was the good Samaritan who ran to help Mailcoff. He saw what was about to happen from his auto repair shop across the street.

"I was just being a good citizen," he said. "You see somebody that needs help, it's pretty normal."

He also attributed his response to parental instinct.

"I have a girl around that age, too," he said.

That stretch of Pennington, just before the lights at Highway 99 and adjacent to his shop on Broadway, is a notorious problem spot, Heredia said. The recent start of school only compounds the problem.

"The way they come flying around the corner," he said. "They need more lights. This'll probably wake the City Council up."

Another train accident stalled traffic in Live Oak for more than two hours in March, when a driver using an unapproved crossing just off Nevada Street, north of Kola Street, became stuck and his truck was hit by an approaching northbound Union Pacific Railroad train.

No one was injured.

This is a corrected story from the one that appeared in print. CONTACT Ashley Gebb at 749-4724 or agebb@appealdemocrat.com .

column4: Man, 59, dies after train hits truck in Wheatland - KCRA
column5:
A 59-year-old man died Friday after a train hit his truck just north of Wheatland on Highway 65.Just after 11:40 a.m., south of Dairy Road,¬†the driver of a 2011 Ford F350 turned down a private driveway that has train tracks across the width of it, according to a news release from the Yuba-Sutter California Highway Patrol.The Union Pacific train was heading south of the tracks, approaching the driveway when the truck driver crossed the tracks at the same time.The front of the UP train hit the driver's side of the truck, and the F350 got slammed down a ditch just east of the tracks.The victim, whose name hasn't been released, died at the scene.Ten UP workers were on board the three-car train. No one was hurt.Drivers were urged to avoid the area because of the investigation.¬†
					

WHEATLAND, Calif. (KCRA) ‚Äî A 59-year-old man died Friday after a train hit his truck just north of Wheatland on Highway 65.Just after 11:40 a.m., south of Dairy Road,¬†the driver of a 2011 Ford F350 turned down a private driveway that has train tracks across the width of it, according to a news release from the Yuba-Sutter California Highway Patrol.
The Union Pacific train was heading south of the tracks, approaching the driveway when the truck driver crossed the tracks at the same time.The front of the UP train hit the driver's side of the truck, and the F350 got slammed down a ditch just east of the tracks.The victim, whose name hasn't been released, died at the scene.Ten UP workers were on board the three-car train. No one was hurt.
Drivers were urged to avoid the area because of the investigation.
column95: A 59-year-old man died after a train hit his truck just north of Wheatland on Highway 65. The driver of a 2011 Ford F350 turned down a private driveway that has train tracks across the width of it. The Union Pacific train was heading south of the tracks, approaching the driveway when the truck driver crossed the tracks at the same time. The front of the UP train hit the driver's side of the truck, and the F350 got slammed down a ditch just east of the tracks. The victim died at the scene. Ten UP workers were on board the three-car train. No one was hurt.
